The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa)
took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: given the fact that there are nearly one million Australians unemployed, that our foreign debt stands at $180 billion and that Australia today recorded its worst balance of payments figures for almost three years, how does he justify the failure of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations to condemn the mass industrial action which will only further harm Australia's economic prospects?
—In so far as—
—Where is the national day of action for the unemployed?

—Certainly one would need something like that in Victoria. In so far as the national stoppage is concerned, I notice that Mr Bob Carr, the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, has described it as something which is not in the national interest. I agree with that and I believe that Senator Cook and the Prime Minister also agree with that. The fact remains that this so-called national day of action has taken place largely due to events in Victoria; where a government was elected on the basis that it would do certain things, including ensure that the standard of living and wages of the average Victorian worker would not be lowered as a result. It is not in the national interest that a government breaks that promise within two or three weeks of being elected to office.

para.tab: I regret the national day of action having taken place but, of course, one has to look at the causes of it. It is all very well for those opposite to huff and puff about it from the Opposition benches. The fact is that industrial disputes in this country are about half what they were under the coalition's former Government. Before the coalition went out of office we had a national day of action about every fortnight because the former Government had no wages policy and was quite incapable of managing industrial relations in this country—just as those opposite would be if ever elected again.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the Minister endorses part of what Mr Carr said in that he agrees that the strike is not in the national interest. But why will the Prime Minister not therefore go the extra step called for by Mr Carr; that is, to call off this blatantly political strike? Is not this yet another definition of national leadership by the Prime Minister—that he will encourage mass industrial action for some short term, perceived political gain?

—That is certainly turning the real situation on its head, suggesting that the Prime Minister would encourage massive industrial action. That is not what the Prime Minister has said at all. I am not going to have words put in my mouth or in the Prime Minister's mouth.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Can the Minister inform the Senate of progress on the development of the third runway at Sydney Airport?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —This is a good news question—good news for the economy and good news for micro-economic reform in Australia. This morning I attended with the Prime Minister at Mascot Airport when he, metaphorically, turned the first sod in the development of the third runway at Sydney Airport. It was an important ceremony which marked the beginning of the construction of greater capacity at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. This is very important because Sydney Airport is the main aviation hub for Australia, the main point of entry from overseas, and the main point of intersection for a lot of air travel in this country.

para.tab: Sydney Airport has a forecast of demand which runs at very high figures into the next century. This development enables the facility of the airport to be upgraded to meet that demand. That demand will take account of the tourist boom which we are experiencing and which will grow further. It will provide openings for business and will create employment in Sydney and New South Wales. It will particularly help country commuter traffic in New South Wales.

The Government decided to go ahead with this project in March 1989. We confirmed that in November 1991, following the receipt of the environmental impact statement which, as I have said before in this chamber, was one of the most comprehensive environmental impact statements ever undertaken in Australia. This project will create 200 jobs on average per year in direct employment and a further 200 jobs in the wider Sydney community will depend on those jobs at the coalface of airport construction. When the third runway is completed some 13,000 other jobs will be created in the operation of the expanded airport facility.

This airport, with all of its importance, is part of an overall airport upgrading program. The developer is the Federal Airports Corporation which, in this decade, is spending $2.8 billion on improving the infrastructure of Australian airports. The sum of $1.6 billion has immediately been approved and when that money finds its way into the community it will create several thousand new jobs. Of that $1.6 billion, $650m has already been spent; another $300m will be spent this financial year.

This is an important day for the improvement of airline facilities in Australia, involving the upgrading of our main point of entry, our ability to capture the international tourist market and our ability to provide efficient and safe facilities for air travel in this country.

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Keating-Kelty-Halfpenny political strike which is designed to further damage the Australian economy for blatant, short term political considerations of the Prime Minister and to protect the power and privileges of a few big union leaders. I ask the Minister: does he agree with Mr Carr's comments that the day of sledge-hammer stoppages is well and truly over and that Australia cannot afford today's massive industrial shut down just to make a political point?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —I am amazed at the Opposition's one dimensional view of reality. It would add some statesmanship and perspective to those opposite if they could actually see things in the whole, not with one eye closed against the truth. There is no doubt that this national day of action—I should be careful about the words I use, because those opposite want to make it appear to be a national strike when, clearly, it is not—has been provoked by the actions of the Kennett Victorian Government. There is no doubt about that. Any independent commentator who has observed this situation factually recognises that and says that, but the continuing position of the Opposition in not recognising that reality—
—I thought you believed in federalism. You are a jackboot thug.
—Order! Senator Alston, I ask for that remark to be withdrawn.
—I withdraw.

—But the Opposition here, in not recognising this reality, in fact propounds the fiction that this is somehow or other simply a union matter. It is not. It is a question of the rights and protections of ordinary Australians at work. That is fundamentally what it is about.

para.tab: We are proud that in this country we have evolved a system of arbitration whereby, by resort to independent assessment—after an argument has been put by unions on behalf of workers, after an argument has been put by employers on behalf of employers and after these arguments have been independently assessed against the criteria of justice, equity and the substantial merits of the case—a decision is made and an award comes forward which guarantees for Australians minimum protections and standards in the workplace. It guarantees them protections on wages, working conditions and their rights in employment, including in dismissal.

What Mr Kennett has done is set that almost century-long tradition on its head. He has denied people access to fundamental award protection. It is, to me, absolutely unbelievable that one should think that, when people are denied access to their basic entitlement and overnight have their basic entitlement unilaterally reduced, they would not take action to protect themselves. But, if they do, they are branded somehow or other as traitorous. I do not support the stoppage but I certainly understand why it is that people, many of whom have never taken industrial action in their lives, are forced to.

I cite to the chamber the example of a nurse, who is a dedicated and idealistic worker who is not in there for avaricious return. Under the Kennett legislation, that nurse will lose 25 per cent of his or her income—a reduction in household expenditure of 25 per cent. No wonder there has been a reaction.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: what is the difference between a national day of action and a strike? Is this not just Labor double-speak? Does the Minister agree with the New South Wales Opposition Leader, Mr Carr, who said that the Federal Labor Party must take responsibility for high unemployment which would make this the `bleakest Christmas since the Depression'?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —There are two questions here and in the short time allowed me I will try to do justice to both, but I make that caveat in respect of the time available to do so.

para.tab: On the first question, the ACTU, as I understand it, has called for a national day of action which will take the form, in most places, of meetings of protest, and nothing more than that, and work will not be disrupted significantly. But this will be an expression of protest. I know those opposite want to make it out to be a strike so that they can say that the strike has failed. It essentially will be a protest, but in some areas there will be strike action. That is the definitional difference; I thank Senator Parer for his question.

I do not agree with Bob Carr if what Bob Carr was saying is that industrial relations in Australia have been a contributing factor to the level of unemployment. They have not. The best indicator of that is to look at the inflation rate. There is no wages pressure in the economy to push up inflation and the inflation rate is below the average of the OECD and the lowest rate in Australia for over 25 years. That is the surest indication that our wages policy works, not like the wages policy of those opposite.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of reports that profits have improved? What do these reports signify for the economy?

—Senator Childs is, as normally, astute. He picked up Senator Crichton-Browne's interjection—which said that it has all come out of profits—and straight away asked me a question about it. Pre-tax company profits improved 26 per cent in the September quarter to reach $4.1 billion.
—Of what?

—The September quarter rise means that profits have risen 37 per cent over the past year and are 67 per cent above the recession trough. Senator Hill asks from what sort of base. Let me deal with that part of the answer, which I propose to give straight away. Even in 1991-92, the worst years of the recession, the profit share at 14.1 per cent was above the level reached in each of the years of the last Liberal Government when the average was 12.6 per cent. So when we talk about—
—How long ago is that?
—It does not matter. We are talking about a percentage profit share. The honourable senator asked the question and will have to cop the answer.

para.tab: The fact is that the improvement in company profits is widespread and across most industry groups. The recovery in profits is a positive sign for employment, because improving profits boosts a return to investment and is, thereby, an encouragement for improved employment.

The Opposition is very vocal about this issue. Those opposite would take $6 billion to $7 billion out of the Budget and put the recovery at risk. Mr Rob Ferguson, Managing Director of BT Australia and the 1992 banker of the year, is reported to have said that reductions in Government spending would reduce company earnings and delay the recovery. That comment is relevant to the policy of the Opposition.

Of course, some of the increase in profits has been due to reduced interest rates. On the first six occasions that this Government implemented reductions in interest rates, they were opposed by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson. The Opposition's policy of changing the Reserve Bank charter to make inflation the only target would increase interest rates and reduce profits and investment. The structurally sound profit share that this Government's policies created is the reason why employment grew strongly out of the last recession and the reason why it will improve as we come out of this recession.

talk.start.para:
—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to my question to Senator Button in September concerning job creation through local government and I note today's
Telegraph Mirror
headline which reads `Jobs sham'. I ask the Minister: can he confirm that much of the money for job creation projects granted to local government areas with high unemployment is actually being used on projects employing existing staff or contractors? In fact, they are not providing jobs to any unemployed people at all.
—You should have said something about this months ago.

—I am the one who is asking the question, not Senator Panizza. Secondly, how does this fit in with the guidelines of creating jobs at the local level and, finally, how many unemployed people have in fact been employed because of this job creation targeting?

—I have not read the
Telegraph Mirror
mentioned by Senator Kernot. I give priority to the Hobart
Mercury
in my daily reading of the media. In so far as the headline and the tenor of the question are concerned, they misrepresent or misunderstand the whole nature of the project. This was not some cynical exercise to take people off the CES list—that could be properly criticised. It was an exercise to take up the willingness of local government throughout Australia to participate in an attempt to generate national recovery by ensuring that activity was undertaken in local government districts with high unemployment in a way which generated the economy and the flow of money around the community, with job consequences and, in some cases, the direct employment of those who were unemployed.

para.tab: As to the 13,000 jobs which were to be involved at an average of six months each during the course of this program, the idea was that in many instances those who had part time employment with council gangs or who were working with subcontractors who would be taken on by councils using this scheme would have their employment secured or would be among the extra people taken on by the subcontractors in order to undertake the work. In these ways the 13,000 jobs which will be sustained, secured and in some cases created by this expenditure of money will certainly improve economic activity in the districts concerned.

I know from going around many areas in Tasmania—the north-west, the south; right across the State—the local councils are very appreciative of the opportunity to receive this assistance, which enables work to be undertaken which could not be supported by ratepayers alone or through other sources of funding available to those local government areas. In so far as they have secured employment and undertaken economic activity in those municipalities, I believe that the program has been worth while and continues to have benefit for the local government areas concerned.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer; I also understand that local councils are appreciative. That is a good starting point. However, is the Government sticking to its prediction of 13,000 jobs being created? When can the Minister actually tell us how many unemployed people have been employed by this targeting?
—As I was explaining, one has to understand that the 13,000 jobs which were predicted to be sustained during this period—
—You didn't say sustained.

—Those opposite have nothing to talk about. Under Fightback, they will take 5 per cent off local government throughout Australia and create an absolute inability on the part of councils to sustain their present levels of employment, let alone create new job opportunities or sustain those of their work forces and subcontractors.
—Rubbish!

—That is not rubbish. The Opposition is proposing a 5 per cent cutback in local government grants, and Senator Patterson knows it. We are proposing to harness local government to the national effort to create economic activity in the various regions around Australia, particularly those where there is high unemployment.
—All you are doing is pork-barrelling.

—It is not pork-barrelling because it goes without political differentiation to those municipalities which have above average unemployment. Senator Campbell knows that and in fact, if I needed to, I could give evidence of it over many hours.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of five research projects, administered by the Council for Equal Opportunity in Employment, which are looking at ways to adopt what might be called `family friendly policies'? How do these projects fit with the Federal Government's strategy to help workers balance their work and family responsibilities?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —This Government has a clear perspective of its role in leading workplace reform and change in Australia. One of the most important elements of that change, with an increasing work force made up of women, is to balance family responsibilities with the demands of work. It was for that reason that in March 1990 we adopted the International Labour Organisation convention on work and family responsibilities. It is for that reason that we have set up in my Department, the Department of Industrial Relations, a work and family unit.

para.tab: The five research projects referred to in this question are research projects whereby particular Australian companies, and in one case the New South Wales Employers Federation, have agreed to develop programs which will highlight the flexibilities needed in the Australian workplace for workers with family responsibilities to balance the demands of both their families and their careers and future employment prospects. Because, in sociological terms, most women seem to be the primary care givers in the family, it is specifically a policy that helps women pursue a career while taking their family work seriously and responsibly.

In order to ensure a safety net and a series of proper and fair protections for workers, we have an independent authority, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which makes awards and which, as I said in an earlier answer today, guarantees basic protections for Australian workers as to their rights. That award system is also flexible enough to negotiate a spread of hours working at different times during the day and to be adapted in ways in which family responsibilities and work can be merged.

It was therefore with some degree of pleasure that the week before last I took part with the Business Council of Australia and the
Australian Financial Review
in presenting awards for family friendly companies in Australia. The
Australian Financial Review
and the Business Council ran a competition among Australian industry to see who was conducting programs in the workplace that illustrated the way in which these responsibilities are best balanced. A number of leading Australian companies got recognition under those awards. The overall winner was Esso Australia and, as a consequence, we are involved in five research projects, one of which is with Coles-Fossey, which is about developing more flexible working arrangements for managers, and a project with Esso, which is about developing training for senior managers, supervisors and shop floor employees to help them introduce more family friendly work practices.

The results of all this research will be published when they are available. Australian companies will have some guidelines as to how to help balance these responsibilities and offer Australian workers some hope for the future.

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs, His Excellency Mr Wong Kan Seng. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome him to Australia and to the Senate.

para.tab:
Honourable senators
—Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the Keating-Kelty-Halfpenny strike which is designed to damage the Australian economy for the blatant short term political considerations of the Prime Minister. What estimate has the Government made of losses of jobs, income and production from the strike? On top of the 30,000 businesses which the Government's failed policies have sent bankrupt in the last two years, how many more businesses will be forced into receivership as a result of today's action? How many more Australians will lose their jobs as a result of the Keating-Kelty-Halfpenny strike?

—I recognise the rhetoric, and I am glad that Senator Chapman could read the writing, because the rhetoric is that of his Deputy Leader, Senator Jim Short. Of course, there has been no estimate of the losses occasioned by the national stoppage.
—What, not interested?
—It would only be a genius like Senator Alston that could work it out in advance when nobody knows how many people are participating.
—Do you condone this strike?

—As I have already said, the national stoppage is not condoned. We very much regret that it took place. But one has to look at the reasons for it, and the reasons for it have been the subject of an earlier answer by me in this Question Time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer, how does he explain to more than one million Australians seeking work the lack of action on the part of Mr Keating in consistently refusing to condemn this strike?

—As I said earlier, this national stoppage has been occasioned by events in Victoria, where a government elected on the basis of certain promises regarding the living standards of the Victorian people broke them within two weeks of being elected. That is what this is all about. That is the reason for it. As I mentioned earlier, we talk about the costs of industrial stoppages. The costs of industrial stoppages in this country are half what they were when we last had a Liberal government in this country. That should not be forgotten because it is not only a lesson of the past but a lesson for the future, and today's events illustrate the point about its being a lesson for the future, if we are ever unfortunate enough to have a coalition government in this country.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the Australian Government's foreign policy approach to the region of southern Africa. What is the Australian Government's strategy to assist the people of Mozambique, particularly now that the recent peace accord in that country has opened up previously inaccessible areas? How is the Government working to ensure that Australia plays a purposeful role in the provision of aid to Mozambicans in real need?
—Ask him about the amnesty.

—If Senator Hill has a smart question he should ask it, or is that beyond his competence these days? He should not just sit there snipping—feel free; we have another half an hour yet. If he has a question, he should ask it. As I announced last week, and it was greeted with the kind of media reaction that usually greets good, constructive, helpful initiatives of this kind, Australia will provide a $6.6m package of assistance for displaced people in Mozambique and for Mozambican refugees in Malawi. Although the recent peace accord in Mozambique has brought hope for the five million Mozambicans severely affected by 10 years of civil war, the combined effects of war and drought have created a situation where, unhappily, mass starvation is a real possibility. Our assistance will primarily be made up of Australian food. It will be delivered by non-government organisations from Australia and by the United Nations.

para.tab: This most recent package of assistance helps to demonstrate the Government's concern for the tragic situation confronting a number of people in Africa. It comes on top of drought assistance worth $4.8m which we provided to Mozambique earlier this year. It comes on top of the $8 1/2m that we have contributed since the beginning of the year to help the millions of people in desperate need in Somalia, which is also being supplemented by our contribution to the UN military operation there. It comes on top of Australian relief worth more than $15m for the Horn of Africa—that is, Sudan and other countries—announced on 10 November and the Government's continuing program of long term development assistance to Africa, which currently stands at $110m over three years.

I believe that this response to the crisis in many African countries does reflect the overwhelming concern of the Australian community for the plight of many people in that continent. I think it has to be acknowledged, finally, that making a contribution in this way is an expensive business; it is a major impost on the aid budget. In that respect, in fairness, it has to be acknowledged that the Opposition's plans to slash $209m from the aid program would savagely cut our capacity to respond in this way, particularly, as it has already indicated, with bilateral aid programs to Africa, with a resulting detrimental effect both on assistance to Africa in its present plight and to that continent's sustainable long term development.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the release today of the October balance of payments figures, which show the highest current account deficit—$1.8 billion—for almost three years, despite the economy's continuing in the worst recession for 60 years and the highest unemployment rate ever recorded in the postwar period. Given this further clear evidence of the massive failure of the Government's economic policies and the acknowledged collapse of the Government's phoney One Nation package and of the basic Budget figures, when will the Government revise upwards its official balance of payments deficit forecast for 1992-93? What new policy measures will the Government adopt to correct the massive problems and hardship its current policies have caused? When will these new policies be announced?

—If the Government has policies to announce, we will announce them in accordance with our timetable. Those opposite ought to know about this because they announced policies just over a year ago and they have been talking about them ever since. They have distributed 80 million pamphlets—according to their Deputy Leader—about them into letterboxes and down drainpipes; that is where Fightback has gone: down drainpipes. It is going down the tube. That is what their Deputy Leader has said about it. It is all very well for those opposite to come in here like children and hold up little banners like the little flags in the House of Representatives.

para.tab: Of course the balance of payments figures are disappointing. We have always warned against taking one month's figures and abstracting them from all the other figures which come out on a monthly basis. In so far as any revision upwards or downwards of the Budget figures is concerned, it is too early for any revision of them to be made.

talk.start.para: —Oh!

—It is, because Opposition senators were asking exactly the same questions this time last year, and the Budget deficit figures—the external account figures—came in below target. They should not get overexcited yet; they have a fair way to go before they hit the fence.

para.tab: I turn to the other issue which Senator Short asked me about. In this month's figures, imports were down by 4 per cent and exports were down by 11 per cent. That is very difficult to explain in terms of the range of metal exports which were down. Some further analysis of the figures will be done and hopefully I will be able to give Senator Short a more detailed analysis tomorrow.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I point out to Senator Button that I was hardly wishing for an extrapolation from one month's figures. Is he aware that this is the ninth successive monthly rise in the deficit? Is he aware that for the first four months of this financial year the accumulated current account deficit is $6.6 billion; an annual rate of $20 billion, compared with the Budget forecast of $15 billion? Is he seriously suggesting that the failed policies of this Government will do anything to turn that around? I ask him again: when will the Government make new policy announcements, or is it a simple fact, as we all surmise, that this Government has run out of ideas and has no new policy ideas at all?

—I suppose that might be described as a supplementary question. It is just a bit of old hand rhetoric from Senator Short, in fact. I have already answered the first part of the question regarding the revision of the external account figures and when was the appropriate time to do that.

para.tab: Senator Short, in all the many years he has been floating around here in opposition, always asks these sorts of questions about this time of the year. He is making the same allegations again. I have nothing new to add on the basis of the answer which I have already given.

Senator Short and some of the children in the Opposition are getting very excited—they are holding up their little placards and things—about the fact, they say, that the Government has no new policies to deal with particular situations as they arise. What have those opposite got? They should look at their Deputy Leader yesterday—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to the statement by Mr Corbin, the American pro-gun lobbyist, as reported in the media `We play hard-ball politics, and we don't take prisoners'. In view of recent incidents in Australia involving hostages and gun murders, I ask: does the Minister agree that such statements are inflammatory and serve to perpetuate a culture of violence? What steps will the Minister take to ensure that Federal and State parliamentarians are not intimidated by the high pressure politics advocated by Mr Corbin and by Australian shooters' organisations? In particular, can the Minister advise what action, if any, the Commonwealth Government has taken towards uniform gun control legislation throughout Australia?

—I think that, rather than being inflammatory, this will all be a damp squib because I do not think that what passes for rhetoric in the United States on the firearms control issue really strikes a responsive chord here in Australia, certainly amongst responsible shooters—recreational, competitive and those involved in various hunting pursuits. I believe that they will see this for the sort of extremist rhetoric which it is. As I say, I do not think it will strike a real chord here in Australia.

para.tab: Senator Spindler asked me whether Australian politicians might be intimidated by this sort of language and any response it does get. Back in November at the Premiers Conference, I think it was in Perth, the leaders of all Australian jurisdictions took a united stand in relation to firearm control measures. This will not strike any fear into the hearts of Australian politicians because, quite irrespective of political allegiance or whichever States and Territories the Premiers and Chief Ministers come from, they were united in saying that in Australia we should have a philosophy which certainly puts the community and its safety as a priority of paramount concern and that we have a perfect right to regulate the use and possession of firearms in the community, in particular the sale of those military style semi-automatics which featured in some of the massacres which Senator Spindler no doubt had in mind.

I recall that the day after the Strathfield Plaza massacre, which led to the decision to ban the sale of military style semi-automatics throughout Australia, the Commonwealth already having stopped the importing of them, Mr Graham Edwards, the Minister for Police in Western Australia, who is in a wheelchair—I think he had both legs blown off during the Vietnam war, where he served with distinction—phoned me and said, `I have just seen the photographs of the weapons associated with the fellow who carried out the Strathfield massacre. That semi-automatic was exactly the same as I faced in the jungles of Vietnam'.

I believe that there is no place for such weapons in Australia. The measures taken by all jurisdictions to ban the sale of these military style semi-automatics, supported by all political parties from whatever part of Australia they come, at the highest political level of the Premiers Conference, means that we will not be intimidated by this attempt by some United States lobbyist to change our culture and the move in Australia to ensure that we are not a gun-ridden society when it comes to violence and reaching for a weapon in order to solve a problem. I believe we are moving very well, in a concerted way and a way full of solidarity, across all jurisdictions, and that is our best protection against this sort of United States propaganda.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I appreciate the Minister's concern about semi-automatics, and I certainly share that as a priority. However, there is plenty of evidence—not least in the United States—that the ready availability and storage of guns in private homes in cities as well as in the countryside is in direct proportion to the deaths caused by guns. Is the Minister prepared to extend the Commonwealth policy to control of those weapons and to ensure that the storage of such weapons in private homes is reduced to those cases where people require it for safety or professional purposes? Is the Minister getting support from State governments for that policy?

—It has to be clearly understood that in fact the Commonwealth's role is reduced to the question of regulating imports of weapons into Australia. We can take a leadership role in trying to encourage State and Territory governments in relation to such questions as storage of firearms, but I would not want to see a situation arise where police might have more or less an unrestricted capacity to go into the households and farmhouses of Australia to check on the possession and storage of weapons.

para.tab: I believe that where there is domestic violence there is a very real responsibility on police forces to withdraw any weapons from that household. That, of course, is based on an incident or a report of an allegation concerning such violence. I do not think that we would want to get to a situation where every household would be under some sort of threat of being visited by the police to see whether weapons were being stored. Therefore, at the moment I am not persuaded that the political effort would be worth while to try to encourage the States to, for example, have a central repository in various suburbs and towns for these weapons. Nevertheless, it should be a matter for discussion by the Australian Police Ministers Council.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of the bonus scheme which operates at Gladstone through the Gladstone Port Authority whereby equal bonuses are paid to all workers from the lowest paid worker to the engineers when a ship is loaded and sails on time? Is he also aware that this bonus system encourages workers to perform and has given Gladstone a trouble free waterfront for many years, although perhaps it might not be trouble free today? Can the Minister tell the Senate why such a bonus scheme system should not be put into place in other waterfronts throughout Australia to ensure similar progress and trouble free ports as an aid to our economic turnaround, which could be useful at the present time in view of the industrial strife brought upon Australia by the union leaders in Victoria?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —I congratulate Senator Bjelke-Petersen on asking, except for the end remark, a very constructive question. It touches on the significant gains in waterfront reform that have been possible under our Government. Here I must compliment my colleague Minister Collins, who presided over the most dramatic period of waterfront reform this country has ever seen. One of the elements of that reform, one of the important structural changes on the Australian waterfront, was the change from the pool system of employment, whereby all waterfront labour was in a pool and hired as needed by companies, to a direct employment system which was underpinned by a universal award to set basic standards and conditions of fairness and then within which enterprise agreements were reached.
—There are no wharfies at Gladstone.

—Senator Parer is busting to make the point that there are no WWF members at Gladstone. But the point I am coming to is that it is possible under the enterprise based agreements in the ports, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen has asked, for the wharfies, who were formerly in the pool system and now are direct employees of each particular stevedoring company, to make the change to a bonus structured system if they choose.

para.tab: Each port in Australia where waterside labour is now engaged directly by companies has completed an EBA—an enterprise based agreement—in which management and those employees, protected by the safety net of the award, have worked out the most efficient way of delivering waterfront services in those ports. Hence, it is because of those changes, or in part affected by those changes, that we now have internationally competitive loading rates at Australian ports.

In the last report of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority I indicated that, on average across Australia, the loading rates of containers per Australian port per hour is now at an internationally competitive level. That is in part because of the very type of direct bargaining, protected, as I have said, by an award which guarantees fairness, that our reform process has brought about. So, in answer to Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question, yes, it is possible to adopt the bonus system. But it is up to the people concerned in each port to decide the way of working that best suits them.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the Minister's recent visit to Korea to open Promotion Australia 1992. What was the rationale for the promotion? What were its objectives? How successful was it in addressing these objectives?

—Promotion Australia 1992, which was held in Seoul and a number of other Korean cities simultaneously from 5 to 15 November, was the first in a series of such promotions organised by the Australia Abroad Council—which was established as a new coordinating body a couple of years ago—designed to showcase Australian achievements and attractions in business, education, culture and tourism. I visited Korea on 5 and 6 November to open the promotion and the major exhibition associated with it. Mr Kerin went there a week later to attend business seminars and a number of other functions.

para.tab: We chose Korea for the first such promotion of its kind because it is our third largest export market and our fifth largest trading partner and because our relationship with Korea is one of the most important burgeoning new relationships in the region, but in a context where our image in that country does not simply reflect in any accurate way contemporary Australia. A recent image survey confirmed that, although Koreans hold very positive views of us, the predominant impressions are out of date. We wanted to correct those misconceptions and enhance that understanding.

The flagship event was a major exhibition involving trade promotion; education and tourism displays; science, technology and industry exhibits, as well as an Australian wine and food promotion. That was accompanied by department store and hotel promotions of Australian products and a series of business seminars and conferences, including the fourteenth annual meeting of the Australia-Korea/Korea-Australia Business Council. There was a series of cultural events—an art exhibition, chamber music festival and film showings—and a series of sports events.

Judging by the extent of Korea's participation in the various events associated with it, the very extensive media publicity that we received and the positive feedback from participants, the promotion can only be described as an unqualified success. Preliminary estimates indicate that some 50,000 people passed through the main exhibition, which lasted only three or four days, and that there was strong attendance at all the other events in capital and regional cities.

In particular, the promotion seems to have impressed our specific target groups in Korea, particularly in terms of what we have to offer in tourism, education, environment protection and investment. Generally speaking, what we were trying to do, very simply, was to reinforce the existing image of Australia as a supplier of industrial raw materials and a very attractive tourist destination, together with adding a new layer of imagery of ourselves as a country supplying sophisticated goods and services. On all the evidence, I think we succeeded in that aspiration.

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —To an earlier question today, I said that we stand by a fair award structure in Australia and a proper, independent arbitration system. I think that most Australians want to see that. Most Australians support that notion and want to see it continue so that they can cooperate in their workplaces with their employers to generate higher productivity but in a way in which they are protected from unfair exploitation. That is our position.

para.tab: There are many elements of the Kennett legislation that are absolutely regressive. One of the elements is that it involves retrospective legislation. I know that the Opposition in this place has a proud record—certainly, it would cite it—of opposing retrospective legislation. It has described it as morally and ethically wrong. My question is: would all those in the Opposition who support retrospective legislation in this case please put up their hands? Let the record show that no-one put up a hand to support the Kennett industrial relations legislation in Victoria. So, even among members of the same party in this chamber, there is not unanimous support for the Victorian industrial relations legislation.

I did not see those remarks by Jennie George, if she made them. I say `if she made them' because in questions from the Opposition I have become used to unfair reporting of what people have said in order to mislead or gull listeners to Question Time into believing something that is not true.

I can certainly tell Senator Crane that a number of employers in Victoria have approached me and asked the Federal Government to help them remove their award coverage from the now disfigured Kennett jurisdiction to the proper and principled jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Government. They want us to open the doors of the existing Federal legislation wider in order to make that shift. They want to treat their work forces properly and they want to have the recognition and protection of the award. There may be some employers in Victoria who do not feel that way.

I have just seen a so-called individual work contract that was presented to Victorian workers. It means that one works from 8 o'clock in the morning until 6 o'clock at night, six days a week. It means that if there is no work one is put aside and stood down and gets no income. It means that all the standard conditions one would have enjoyed in one's award are taken away. It is a work contract that applies at a prefabricated building company. It is straight out exploitation.

If the Opposition wants to exploit Australian workers, it should stand up and say so. The Government will be saying that the independent award system will remain intact and we will protect it. Australian electors can choose between awards and individual work contracts.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question.
—Why doesn't he tell the truth to start with?

—Yes, that would be a good start. I ask the Minister whether he supports the statement which was reported in the

Is this award made in competition with contenders from the private sector, and on which criteria was the APS judged to be the national winner?

—Most honourable senators will be aware of the work of the Australian Protective Service, not only around Parliament House but also in the major airports where we travel, where, of course, it has a first response counter-terrorist role. But it is also involved in many other duties, including at residences such as those of the Governor-General and the Prime Minister; and in sensitive locations around Australia, such as the Australian-US facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar.

para.tab: There are many situations where its services are used to great effect. It was therefore very pleasing that the Australian Protective Service was awarded the security Australia annual achievement award for being the most outstanding security organisation in Australia in 1992. I understand that Mr John Mackay, the Director of the APS, received that award at an industry function last Thursday night.

I believe this demonstrates that this Government's commercialisation program, which of course the APS has been working within over the last several years, has enabled that organisation to develop a commercial edge and practices that make it as efficient as any private security firm. But it has also retained that high professionalism which is very necessary to ensure that it properly discharges its duty of protecting many vital government organisations.

I believe, for example, to sell off the Australian Protective Service—which I understand is one of the proposals under Fightback—would be to lose the advantage of a body which has peculiar and very sensitive obligations to protect and to guard installations of high national significance. I believe that that should not be the case with the Australian Protective Service.

This is the first time a public sector organisation has been so recognised by the security industry. It is based on factors such as professionalism, commitment to training, responsible business practices, good service and consistent high standards. I believe that you, Mr President, would also be one of those to acknowledge the excellent work done by the Australian Protective Service.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I ask the Minister to explain the situation as reported in the

this morning under the heading `Jobs sham', where in Byron Bay $400,000 allocated under the local government capital works program was spent on street rejuvenation and not one new job was created. para.tab: In this way, we believe that the stimulus which will be offered to the economy in local government districts through the expenditure of money, as well as through the flow of money in the further purchase of goods and services, will enable us to have local government as a partner participating in this stimulation of economic activity which does create employment and those sorts of activities within districts which are, of course, selected on the basis of having higher than average unemployment.

talk.start.para: —Marginal seats.

—They are not marginal seats—far from marginal seats. In many instances, they bear no relation whatsoever to some crude political barometer that those opposite might wish to apply. I have found, in going around local government districts in Tasmania over the last several weeks, even over the weekend, a very great appreciation of the way in which ratepayers have been assisted to provide for economic activity, good works and good infrastructure within their districts in a way which would not otherwise be possible.

What is more, the people of Byron Bay will have some good urban infrastructure as a result of the implementation of this program. Overall, I think it is an excellent program which will bring benefits to local government districts and help sustain employment within local government gangs and for subcontractors. talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to the balance of payments figures released earlier today.

speech.para: Today's balance of payments figures for October showing a further deficit of $1.8 billion in Australia's current account deficit in one month are nothing short of disastrous. They are disastrous not just because of the overall magnitude of the figure, horrendous though that is, but also because of its composition.

para.tab: The result has occurred following an 11 per cent fall in exports and a minor fall of 4 per cent in imports, which is largely explained by changes in civil aircraft imports. This deficit comes at a time when Australia is still in the deepest recession it has had in its postwar history—I notice that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) does not even show the Senate the courtesy of staying to listen to this debate or to participate in this discussion—at a time when our unemployment rate is the highest in postwar history, at a time when nothing short of 30,000 bankruptcies have occurred in this country in the last two years alone, and at a time when, as a result of today's balance of payments deficit, there has been a further escalation in our foreign debt to the tune of another $1.8 billion.

Today, we have a debt to the rest of the world, a foreign debt, of approximately $190,000m in gross terms, and a net debt in excess of $150,000m. That is a figure that compares with about $25,000m when this Government came to office almost 10 years ago. The policies of this Government over the last 10 years, year by year, month by month and day by day, have put this nation and all Australians in debt to the rest of the world. That is a legacy that we will leave future generations, particularly our immediate generation—our children and, beyond that, our grandchildren. That is a legacy that no other generation in Australia has ever left to its children and grandchildren. It is a legacy that will cause great hardship in terms of living standards for this nation for decades to come.

What does the Government do about this? What did Senator Button say today when asked, `What policies are you going to adopt to change the situation'? He said, `If we have no policies, we will announce them at an appropriate time'. The short answer is that the Government has no new policies. It has run out of ideas. It is a tired, divided Government, bereft of any initiative, any prospects or any views as to how to remove the fundamental malaise that it has caused this country.

We need a fundamental change in direction in this country. This Government has run out of ideas. It has no idea what to do. The sooner that there is an election in this nation and a Hewson government is elected with the mandate and the policies for change that the Opposition has so publicly announced and which are so clearly in the interests of the nation, the better it will be.
(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 30 November, from Senator Parer:

interject.para: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I propose to move that, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The refusal of Senator Cook and Mr Keating to call on Labor's accord partner, the ACTU, to abandon mass industrial action—which will only further damage the economy and lessen the chances of Australia's one million unemployed finding jobs.

tab.emphasis: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

speech.para: The refusal of Senator Cook and Mr Keating to call on Labor's accord partner, the ACTU, to abandon mass industrial action—which will only further damage the economy and lessen the chances of Australia's one million unemployed finding jobs.

Today is what the industrial arm of the Labor Party, the ACTU, calls a day of industrial action, with some 250,000 Australians being told by union bosses to go on strike. It should be called a day of disgrace or a day of union sabotage of Australia.

para.tab: Australia is going through its worst recession in 60 years, with no end in sight. The unemployment rate is running at 11.3 per cent, with the youth unemployment rate up around 30 per cent. There is a continuing balance of payments crisis and, consequently, we have a net foreign debt approaching $160,000m. Today we find out that the net foreign debt for the last month is $1.8 billion—the highest it has been in three years. It is a debt of Third World proportions.

A few weeks ago, the people of Victoria threw out a discredited Labor Government, a Labor Government which, hand in glove with John Halfpenny and the unelected Trades Hall, had reduced Victoria from what had been the financial and manufacturing centre of Australia to an absolute basket case. When the Liberal-led coalition applied remedies, for which it was elected and which it must responsibly apply, the industrial arm of the Labor Party—which now finds itself out of government—decided to organise a national strike.

The waterfront, the Achilles heel of Australian exports, will be on strike. Our coalmining industry, our largest exporter which sells $7 billion worth of exports overseas to oversupplied world markets, will be on strike. Some 200,000 metalworkers in that beleaguered industry, which is desperately trying to increase productivity, will be on strike, notwithstanding the comments made by the Chamber of Manufactures, which has stated quite categorically that what is needed in Australia today is flexibility within the industrial relations system while maintaining minimum standards. It says that forcing employers and employees to involve unions is not the way to go. It says: let them have a choice. That is what the Jobsback policy is all about.

These are the sorts of things that these people engineering the strike out of Melbourne are revolting about. I ask the question: all for what? The answer is simply because, when it is all boiled down, the trade union movement desperately seeks to hang on to power over little people and will not accept that, in the area of micro-economic reform, there is an urgent imperative to reform our outdated, ramshackle industrial relations system.

The real concern of the ACTU sheltered workshop is that, with voluntary unionism and genuine enterprise or workplace agreements, it will have to work to retain or obtain members. It will have to convince Australians that there are benefits in paying substantial union dues. I suppose it is understandable as its record over the past 20 years has been that of destroying the very jobs for those whom it was supposed to protect.

What will this strike achieve? It will be a lose-lose result. I know the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) commonly talks about a win-win result. This will be a lose-lose result. About a quarter of a million workers will lose a day's pay. Companies will lose production. There will be no exports out of Australia today. All exports out of Australia today have been stopped. Companies will still be required to pay interest to financial institutions and pay the rent and other fixed costs. The Government will lose taxation revenue. More importantly, productivity measured on a unit cost of production basis will decline. This is all because of the macho antics of a clique in the ACTU which, hand in hand with its political servants in the Labor Party, is responsible for our massive level of unemployment—the highest it has been in 60 years.

The Government itself has moved towards enterprise-based agreement, but it has done so in a manner which entrenches its union leader mates. An enterprise-based agreement cannot be recognised under this Government without the imprimatur of a registered union. That is the basic difference. Genuine enterprise-based agreements and voluntary unionism are the reason for this anti-Australian display we are witnessing today. The people who have engineered this strike are traitors to Australia's desperately needed recovery. They will not recognise that the vast majority of private sector employees already work under a free system. They are hell-bent on coercing that majority against their will to become part of the rigid centralised structure which puts enormous power of economic life and death in the hands of a few.

The Minister, Senator Cook, was quoted at the weekend as saying that the industrial action could place our international reputation as a reliable supplier in jeopardy, but he had no plans to avert the strike. Words without action are dead—a very old saying with a lot of truth in it. All suppliers to our export markets, with ships in port or arriving, are required under their contracts to advise their customers of this strike. That is the real nature of exports in the competitive world in which we live. Another nail is driven into the coffin of reliability. In that respect, Minister Cook is absolutely correct: in a world where commodity demand is at best subdued, another reason is given for our overseas customers to divert supply to our competitors. We hear today of the balance of payments figure, that the current account deficit for the month is a record for the past three years, yet these people have no regard for the consequences on their fellow human beings, their fellow Australians; they are interested only in themselves.

The embarrassing part is that customers overseas have to be given a reason for strikes—why a ship is delayed, why a ship may not be able to come into port tomorrow, the next day or next week as a result of this strike today. The question I have to ask is: what on earth does the exporter say that he has not said over the years which is different in a valiant effort to retain his customers? Another little bit of the market disappears, a few more jobs are lost, all because of the short-sighted use of industrial muscle aided and abetted by the Labor Government—the political arm of the trade union movement—and all because of a big and protected union which will not accept the fact that, like every group in our society, to survive it must be competitive.

What is the Labor Government doing about it? Absolutely nothing. It is doing nothing because it is locked into supporting and entrenching a small and powerful interest group which not only pays enormous amounts of other people's money into Labor Party coffers but also determines who gets preselected and becomes the leader of the party, the Prime Minister. All this is determined by the trade union movement. This strike has all the stench of yet another deal between an elected government or supposedly elected government and the unelected power brokers of the ACTU. It is about time that the people of Australia realised just how insidious and destructive is this relationship between a government and a handful of power brokers. Every time this issue or the question of union funding of the Labor Party is raised, anyone who raises it is accused of union-bashing.

I believe that all Australians should read Peter Hartcher's article in the
Sydney Morning Herald
of 27 November if they doubt what my colleagues and I say. The article states:

The political and industrial arms of the Labor Party are now devising strategies for dealing with Jeff Kennett as they prepare for an intense and protracted struggle to preserve power under a hostile regime.

They don't think that they can continue mobilising major strikes, stoppages and industrial confrontations for many more months. The search for more subtle and sustainable methods is on and it is likely to go into the Cabinet room in Canberra next week . . .

speech.para: It is `likely to go into the Cabinet room in Canberra next week' because the two of them are together devising the strategy. What can be clearer than that?

para.tab: The article goes on to say that other strategies will be used, but time prevents me from going through them in detail. It talks about the second phase and it is interesting to note what it says. It states:

speech.para: The unions, however, had already begun the second phase of their campaign. The ACTU and its affiliates already have decided that step two is to concentrate not on the Government or the political process—
that is, the legitimate process—

but on individual companies. The intention is for each union to press specific companies to commit themselves to the award system, rather than Kennett's preferred system of individual employment contracts for each worker.

para.tab: This process was described by a senior union figure last night as involving the unions—

speech.para: that is, the industrial arm of the Labor Party—
as saying to employers: `You will commit yourself to the award structure. If you don't, you will get hit.'

talk.start.para: —And this, of course, is with the support of the Labor Government.

—They are working hand in glove; there is no difference, one from the other. This is mafia stuff—`If you don't, you will get hit'. The article goes on further to state that all this will be engineered by the storemen and packers and says:

speech.para: But the unions hope that this approach of intimidating employers into perpetuating the award system will concentrate negotiations, continue the centralisation of power in union hands, protect their influence, and protect the entitlements of their members.

It is there for everyone to read and it should be noted. These sorts of above-the-law, standover tactics should have no place in Australian society. Under a coalition government, they will have no place in Australian society because they are clearly against the best interests of every Australian and, thus, Australia itself.

para.tab: The President of the ACTU has drawn a parallel between the 1890s and the 1990s. It is scandalous, scaremongering stuff. In the 1890s people were prevented from joining trade unions. The coalition is saying that in the 1990s individual Australians should have a choice: the freedom to join or not to join an organisation, whether that organisation be a union or a professional organisation. That freedom of choice does not exist in Australia today where there are union-controlled closed shops.

In my own State a contract shearer, Mr Barry Hammond, has just spent some days in gaol because he did not sign an 1890s shed agreement. And Government members have the gall to come in here and talk about other people living in the past! Mr Hammond was told that if he and his workers joined the AWU, the charges would be dropped. This is more intimidation and coercion. He now faces gaol again because he and his fellow workers committed the absolute, ultimate crime of working on a Sunday. The boss of the AWU, Bill Ludwig, was quoted as saying:

speech.para: If we allowed weekend work there would be anarchy.

That is what he said. This country is crying out for increased productivity and for a reduction in unit costs of production. We do not want to reduce real wages, but in fact increase real wages. They say that if we allow workers to make an agreement, in this case in the interests of the graziers and shearers themselves, it will lead to anarchy. I ask you!

para.tab: Is this the sort of attitude we should tolerate at a time when not only the wool industry, but also the whole of Australia is in trouble? There are no jobs and there is a desperate need to be more competitive. We should be not only exporting more, but also producing more of the goods in Australia which Australians want to buy.

Recently Gazel Enterprises worked out an agreement to the satisfaction of the workers and the company. This agreement was rejected by none other than Anna Booth, who was then told to go back to Melbourne by the employees, who all promptly resigned from the union. The examples go on and on. One can go back to Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets, Metway Bank, Power Brewing and so on. In every case, employees have emerged with a better deal; a deal which is in their interests and in all cases has meant higher real wages and the removal of restrictive work practices which has substantially increased productivity and, hence, job security.

The unions, and thus the Labor Government, apparently cannot tolerate job security and increased real wages because it means they lose relevance. Australians are crying out for change; they want reform. If the Labor Government was concerned about job security, if it had any concern at all about the desperate plight of the unemployed, it would stand up to those who are hell-bent on just keeping their own jobs and positions of power.

That is what the coalition's Fightback and Jobsback policies are all about. They are about creating real jobs, being more productive, increasing real wages, and giving people freedom of choice. The Labor Party has no plans or policies to restore our economy. The Fightback and Jobsback programs offer those plans. All that the Labor Party is offering is more of the same. That is something we in Australia cannot tolerate.

speech.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
speech.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talker.name: Senator COOK
talker.role: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

talk.start.para: —There is no argument, I do not think, between the major political parties about the need to reform the Australian economy to make it world competitive. There is a considerable argument about the way in which that is best achieved.

para.tab: On our side, we argue that it is best achieved by working with Australians to create reform and progress, not against them—going to the workplace and creating a framework of cooperation; and the generation of higher productivity and sharing the rewards of that higher productivity fairly among the workers who helped generate it, among the shareholders who own the company and among the clients who buy the goods and services from that company. It is an ethic of cooperation.

On the other hand, we have the confrontationist approach of the Opposition. The problem for Opposition members is that they are ideologically blinkered: they hate trade unions, although they pretend otherwise. Their rhetoric, as we just heard in the serving that we just received, is all anti-union propaganda.

The important thing here is to recognise that unions exist in Australian society as an institution because about 43 or 46 per cent of the Australian work force want them to. It is a sensible approach by a government to harness the positive and constructive sentiments within the union movement to achieve reform; not to approach the issue of reform from the point of view that one must first destroy this institution before one can move to a new system of change.

One can certainly move to a new system of change if one wishes to do that. Jeff Kennett has proved that. If nothing else, Jeff Kennett has returned Australia to the days of industrial conflict and confrontation that were wreaked on this country in the period of the Fraser Government.

The inescapable fact is that, for the comparable period, industrial disputation in Australia under Labor is 62 per cent below the level of industrial disputation under the Fraser Government. The inescapable fact in Victoria is that, under Labor in that State, industrial disputation was off the bottom of the graph of the Australian Bureau of Statistics; it was at the lowest level since statistics were recorded in the history of the Bureau. That is the record for Victoria.

Comparing Victoria, a partly industrialised State, to the other major industrialised State, New South Wales—if one were to make the comparison of a Liberal governed State to a Labor governed State—New South Wales was well above the national average for industrial disputation and, in its confrontationist ap-

speech.para: proach with its so-called reforms last year, pushed the national average up by inciting disputation and provoking strikes; whereas Victoria was well below the national average. That is a comparison of who manages industrial relations in this country better. Confrontation is the Liberal way and disputation the outcome. Cooperation through working together is the Labor way and the outcome is a reduction in disputation and an increase in industrial harmony. That is the issue here.

para.tab: The other issue here is a move by the Opposition in this place to shift the blame and responsibility. It has no perception of the fundamentals of cause and effect. What is the cause? I have just given some statistics to show the effects of better management compared with the effects of poor management. Before I go to the cause and effect element, we do not welcome a national day of protest, which will mostly be a day of protest meetings carrying resolutions and of discussing the Victorian legislation but in some places—particularly in Victoria—will be a day of industrial action. We do not welcome that. But it is idle then to blame the effect as if the effect of actions taken is the cause of them.

There is no doubt that the cause in this case is the Kennett Government in Victoria, and the uncomfortable and unpalatable truth for the Opposition is that the Kennett Government is a forerunner of what the Opposition would do were it ever to take the treasury bench in this Federal Parliament. The unpalatable fact is that the actions of Jeff Kennett are the blueprint of John Howard and John Hewson. The unpalatable fact is that the cat is out of the bag before the Opposition has been able to spring its ploy of soft language and cajoling on the Australian people without revealing the true dimensions of the industrial relations horror it wishes to visit upon this economy.

I have given the figures on strikes as a comparison. We have been successfully increasing cooperative industrial practice in Australian workplaces at the enterprise level. Our best practice program is aimed at Australian companies, management and workers identifying which companies in the world in their area of competition perform the best and developing a corporate plan to bridge the gap and put Australia in front. They are working together to be more competitive. Under our best practice program, the companies that have entered and been selected—selected not by the Government but by a commercial board headed by John Prescott, the General Manager of BHP Australia—are predominantly in Victoria, if one looks at the State by State distribution. The sad reality of the events in Victoria is that an industrial cooperation ethic was emerging in that State, a new industrial relations culture was mushrooming, and along came the bull in the china shop, Jeff Kennett, who is now threatening to sweep away the attitudinal change and the change in workplace custom that we were developing.

It is easy for governments in Canberra to pass laws, it is relatively simple for governments in Canberra to proclaim regu-lations, but the mark of a true government with real leadership is to change the human attitudes of people in the work force—to move them from one way of seeing the world to a more cooperative and positive way of seeing the world. We were evolving that attitudinal change, and elsewhere in Australia we are evolving it by practical, hands-on example. Many companies such as Sheraton Hotels, Asta Aviation, Olympic Tyres, Dulux Paints, Bendix Mintex—I can keep going on—were developing that positive attitudinal change of creating higher productivity with the certain knowledge that the outcome of that higher productivity is shared fairly with all sides and is not pocketed by one side.

Along comes Jeff Kennett. It requires us to pause here for a minute and look at the facts of the ascendancy of Kennett in Victoria. I think it is fair and reasonable to observe that most Victorians did not vote for Kennett but voted obviously against the Labor Government in Victoria. However, they have moved from the frying pan into the fire. If one looks at all of the exit poll surveys, most people would have preferred anyone but Kennett. But, in the circumstances, that is who they got.

Let us look at the next development. Before the election, what did Mr Kennett promise? He promised that `no-one would be worse off by a single cent'. That is a direct quote; that is what he promised. After the election, what did he do? He immediately removed, by legislative fiat, holiday leave loading and weekend penalty rates to guarantee that his promise—only days old—was broken immediately, and he and his Liberal Government in Victoria misled the community that had voted for it. Do not take my word for that; take the word of John Howard and take the word of Peter Reith. Both those people—in leadership positions in the Opposition—said, on the public record on the
Sunday
program and on
Meet the Press
, that Kennett had misled the Victorian voter. So Kennett remains condemned by his own side.

Let us move to the next important development. The Victorian Government brought down an economic statement which exacted a poll tax on Victorians. It meant that the pensioner in Coburg paid exactly the same amount on property as the wealthy landowner in Toorak, on the grounds that this was somehow fair: it is flat tax; everyone pays the same. At the same time as the Victorian Government did that—not taxing according to means, but taxing flatly, according to where it could get the money—in the dead of night, without the press in attendance, it put through Victorian Parliament a Bill which increased the salaries of members of parliament; in the case of the Industrial Relations Minister, by $8,000 per annum, when he was already $14,000 per annum ahead of the salary of a Federal Minister.

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I know that we do allow a certain amount of latitude in debates such as this, but I fail to see the relevance of what the Minister is talking about to the urgency motion in front of us.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)
—There is no point of order.

talk.start.para: —There is no point of order. It is vexatious and it is meant to take up time because those opposite do not like the message they are receiving from me. They know it is true, and they hate it being told. The next point is that the Victorian Government introduced, at a cost of half a million dollars, the white-gloved waiters and the silver service into the ministerial dining room in Victoria while it was putting a poll tax of $100 on pensioners in Coburg based on their property holdings. What is the relevance of this? The relevance of this is morality. If you do not treat people fairly, people protest.

para.tab: Let us look at what Jeff Kennett has done to nurses. Nurses are hardly an example of workers in Australia noted for trying to use industrial muscle to improve their income. A nurse is a worker in Australia widely recognised by Australians as dedicated to her or his profession. Because nurses are 24 hours a day, seven days a week workers, if the advantages of weekend penalty rates and shift loadings are taken off them, as Jeff Kennett has done, by our calculations it will decrease their salary by 25 per cent. It will cut their income by a quarter.

If the income of any Australian is cut by 25 per cent without that Australian having access to a fair and just independent Industrial Relations Commission to referee his or her claim, or without having access to any protections of a legitimate award, and that Australian then protests—as nurses are going to this Wednesday in Victoria, I understand—the nurses are blamed. The cause and effect here is: look who did the act in the first place.

What marks out statesmen from politicians in the world is that statesmen bring harmony and a sense of national purpose; politicians bring ideological preconceptions. Dr Hewson has this ideological fixation with a consumption tax—as if the economic issues of Australia could be solved by taxing people differently and more. They cannot be. It is an ideological obsession. We have an approach, despite the economic difficulties, of trying to bring harmony and a sense of national purpose and unity to the community, and then of trying to tackle our industrial problems as one Australia. That was the nature of our statement.

A nurse in Victoria now loses 25 per cent of her or his income. What else has the Government down there in Victoria done as a prototype for Australia? I will tell those opposite what else it has done. It has made it impossible for that nurse or any other worker who feels aggrieved under that system to have access to independent arbitration—an Australian institution since the beginning of the Australian Federation, an institution of free independent arbitration based on equity, justice and the substantial merits of the case. The Victorian Government has denied them access to that, so they cannot go anywhere and resolve their grievance.

The Victorian Government has also removed their award. Most Australians know what an award is. Most Australians know that an award consists of the legal minimums that protect their employment; that is what an award consists of. What has the Kennett Government in Victoria done? Everybody is tipped out of awards. Nobody has any basic protections and to get their protections back they have to negotiate them back. There are now emerging some prime examples of the alleged `negotiation'. Those on the other side do tell some big lies about negotiation. They tell some huge fibs on their side about negotiation.
