—I think what we are doing here is debating an urgency motion. The urgency motion contains a number of assertions and also some things which we are asked to consider. There is no doubt that we can agree with some of the content of it.

para.tab: If we look at the last part of the urgency motion, we read that the action that is being taken today `will only further damage the economy and lessen the chances of Australia's one million unemployed finding jobs'. I can but agree with that part of the assertion that the action today will adversely affect Australia's economy. One would have to be a fool to suggest otherwise. The action today will reduce productivity because products will not be produced today. It will reduce profitability. It will cost this country money and it will cost us our reputation internationally.

There should be nobody in this place or anywhere in Australia who can be satisfied that this turn of events has come about. In fact, nobody is accepting the sole responsibility for today's occurrences. All groups involved are madly thrashing about, madly trying to lay the blame on another group—any group except themselves.

I suggest that none of this bickering and blame laying is of any benefit to the huge number of Australians who are unemployed at the moment. We would all be much better off if we saved all this bickering—let it cease entirely—and all parties involved sought to become cooperatively involved in employment creation projects. That is a blithe statement that many people could make quite cheaply, and it is reflective of the sort of endorsement that we have—everybody is interested in job creation programs and jobs—but when we come to commitment that is the real test.

We have had criticism in Question Time of the sorts of temporary, space-filling jobs that are involved in the local government initiatives that are now taking place. That is not the sort of employment creation project that we should be creatively attending to. The sort of employment creation that we ought to be seeking is the long lasting, economically beneficial—when I say that, I mean the sorts of benefits which accrue to the nation rather than to individuals—employment creation programs which are sustainable in the long term. In order to do that, we need the Government's leadership, intervention and acceptance of its responsibility to recognise initiatives which have the potential to create the sort of employment that I have just described.

It is not as though we have to look very far for it. We know about the orbital engine and the gene shears and the sagas attached to them; we know about Memtec and its inability to attract the sort of intervention that I have just mentioned; and we know about solar cells and their associated technology—the ridiculous spectacle of seeing a fine Australian development needing to be developed further in Switzerland and carted around on a foreign test bed before it could prove in Australia that we are at the forefront of the development of viable, compact and economically attractive solar energy cells.

I want to talk about inventive developments which have not been given the support necessary, both government and financial, for their development and full productive fruition in Australia for Australia's benefit. We should have heard more about the laser microscope which is being developed in Australia but which could well leave Australian shores for further development overseas for want of a few investment dollars from this Government now.

We should have heard more of the process to utilise used lubricating oil. At present, huge quantities of sump oil, especially in Tasmania, are discarded or burnt inefficiently for want of the proper development of a proposal which could well bring great economic attractiveness to Australia. I met only recently Mr Panton in Tasmania, who has a proposal which would use that oil.

talk.start.para: —A very excellent proposal, Senator.

—The Minister for Justice agrees that the proposal is a wonderful thing. The proposal would require quite a low level of government responsibility to be recognised—something less than $1m. It would see a recycling plant established in Tasmania, employing people in collecting, processing and redistributing this oil, all saving money and resources for Australia. This would result in a lessening of those very figures which alarm us today—the escalation of our overseas debt and the continued expansion of our unemployment figures.

para.tab: The very figures that concern us so much today are being ignored by the deliverance of this Government's policies. The Government deserves criticism for its failure to endorse, support and intervene on behalf of such projects. We have a bipartisan recognition of the market as being the sole determinant of the success of such ventures. Instead of the Government accepting the responsibility to intervene and recognise technological development, what do we have? An abrogation of responsibility.

I mentioned in this place last week the success of the Barrett family near Ballarat, which had an enterprise that utilised a previously wasted material—pig manure. I am sure that we are familiar with this stuff; we have disregarded it for almost 200 years. But here we have an enterprise which has now utilised this waste material and produced methane and then electricity from it.

We have too many examples of wasted resources throughout Australia, especially manure. It is quite a joke. I see that Senator Boswell is amused by it; most of us are. We have invariably disposed of this particular resource—which is typically wasted in Australia—in our waterways. I am a member of a committee which has spent some time examining the phenomenon of blue-green algae. The consensus is that the entry of nutrients into our waterways is largely responsible for the more regular blooms which are now occurring in our major waterways. To reduce that incidence we now know that we should do more to keep sewage, especially, out of our waterways.

We sit here and bicker about unemployment while both the Government and the coalition increasingly endorse the economic rationalist model that dictates that governments should not get involved; they should not intervene in the market; they should keep well out of it, and abrogate that responsibility to lead, encourage and provide financial incentives. That is where we should be directing our attention today, rather than trying to lay blame for a situation of industrial relations that has evolved in Victoria, and rather than trying to skitter away from accepting responsibility for that and putting it onto the other party.

The unemployed of Australia want to see us recognise the folly of this economic rationalist model, accept the responsibility of intervening in the investment market, recognise employment opportunities and put time and attention into that. The Australian Democrats believe that that is what governments are for—to lead, to provide incentives and to retain and develop the technological initiatives which arise within Australia.

The history of Australia is littered with far too many fine inventions which have been either acquired or stolen in other ways from Australians. We have just sat here and watched another tribe of them disappear overseas through the ideological bent that seemed to be the flavour of the 1980s. We have seen it fail. We have seen it produce the sort of economic situation we have in Victoria. For a while we had a bunch of corporate clever dicks who thought that they could copy the style of international speculation, shuffle money around and thereby convince everybody that they were becoming millionaires. We saw them fall flat on their faces one by one, ten by ten, almost dozen by dozen. We should have learnt from that and realised—

talk.start.para: —Gross by gross would be a good term.

—It was almost gross by gross. There were enough of them to infect the nation with an attitude which was very far removed from real employment and real investment in productive activities. We should be recoiling from the speculation, the greed and the gluttony of the 1980s, but we are not really. We are not realising that so many of the problems of Victoria are associated with the sort of speculation and financial wizardry which commonsense said could not be sustained. Commonsense said, `There's something going on here; there's something funny in this money business'.

para.tab: We ought to be looking away from all that, away from trying to lay blame in the industrial relations area—an area where we have had so little disputation over the last 10 or 15 years—and towards realising that the real role of governments is to support the initiatives of technological development, inventiveness and Australian developers to the extent that they are developing real initiatives.

We should look towards them and invest in them. I am sure the Minister in the chamber, the Minister for Justice, would recognise this as well. They range from small propositions such as that put forward by the Scamander Council on the east coast of Tasmania to the one I mentioned earlier. The Scamander Council wants to pump the wasted sewage resource of that little settlement onto a timber plantation. It requires some $20,000 to get going on that particular enterprise—an enterprise which would create a capital resource with the potential of providing employment in the future. But, no, it cannot win with that proposition. No government will accept responsibility for recognising that proposition as potential for creating employment. No government wants to do anything about it, and we continue to waste the resource.

They range from that proposition right up to the one I mentioned earlier, the laser microscope, which can do wonderful things internationally. It can save us money and expense in the health area. It also has the potential to bring us an incredible amount of money internationally. While we sit here and ignore those possibilities, while both the Government and the Opposition believe that the market rules and that governments should not intervene to bring these inventions about—

talk.start.para: —What do you believe?

—I believe the Government should intervene, Senator Parer. I have said that throughout my little contribution today. That is why I would like to amend this matter of urgency, which I propose to do now.
—Pursuant to the contingent notice and on behalf of Senator Coulter, I move:

para.tab: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Coulter moving an amendment to the motion.

talk.start.para: —I will be brief, because I do not want to take up people's time. The coalition is opposed to this move to suspend the Standing Orders. The Democrats have a habit on which they pride themselves—they move very juvenile amendments to any urgency motion that is raised in this chamber. It is their major contribution to the Parliament of Australia, to the unemployment problem, to the size of our foreign debt and to the current account deficit. On all these things, the only thing the Democrats can bring themselves to do is move for a suspension of Standing Orders to move an amendment to an urgency motion in an attempt to neutralise it and shift the blame, and, I must say in fairness to the Labor Government on the other side, in an effort to have a foot in both camps and say that both parties are wrong while not offering any positive solutions to fix the most disastrous economic conditions we have had in this country since the Depression.

—On behalf of the Government, I wish to indicate that, in the interests of the democratic functioning of this chamber, we are happy to give the Democrats such support as they need in order to move an amendment to this motion. We think that that is only appropriate.

—We understand the situation the Democrats are in. They do not want to have to vote on Senator Parer's urgency motion, so they have undertaken this political ploy to avoid doing so. It is a simple matter. Here is a State government endeavouring to take some action to overcome the problems created for it by the ALP and all the Democrats can do is criticise that State Government. In moving this motion we ask the Democrats to face up to the lack of leadership of the Federal Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and to address the question which is set out in the urgency motion. What do the Democrats do? They enter into a simple political ploy that will enable them to avoid voting on that urgency motion. They will say, `Oh well, you didn't support our amendment to your urgency motion, so we didn't support the motion as it stood'.

para.tab: It is a simple political ploy and the people of Australia ought to understand that that is what it is all about. It has nothing to do with the Democrats believing anything, because they do not believe in anything, other than, like Mr Keating, finding how to get some votes from somewhere. They feel that if they were to vote for our urgency motion someone in the trade union movement might criticise them. So what do they do? They go down this path of moving an amendment. They do not really care what the amendment says, one way or the other, but in this particular case they criticise Mr Kennett for trying to overcome the problems in his State. They go down that path and are able to say at the end of the day, `Well, we didn't vote for the urgency motion moved by Senator Parer because they didn't accept our amendment'. The people of Australia ought to realise that it is a simple political ploy to avoid having to vote on the particular urgency motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —We have just listened to Senator Bell talking about one of the Australian Democrats' hobby horses, waste disposal, and some other issues that were not particularly relevant to the debate. The motion that we are discussing at the moment concerns:

speech.para: `The refusal of Senator Cook and Mr Keating to call on Labor's accord partner, the ACTU, to abandon mass industrial action—which will only further damage the economy and lessen the chances of Australia's one million unemployed finding jobs.'.

That is the issue that faces us today with a number of Australian workers striking in a day of dispute. In this chamber we all agree—the Government, Liberals, Nationals and Democrats—that this day of dispute should not take place. But we disagree with the Government in that we believe the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, have shown no leadership in this matter whatsoever—unlike the leaders of the Labor parties in Western Australia and New South Wales who have condemned the strike action.

para.tab: At this time of crisis, Australians are calling out for leadership. But that leadership has not been displayed by either Mr Keating or Senator Cook, who could have used their influence to prevent this strike. We have seen a coalition formed by an ex-communist, Mr Halfpenny, who has been spoiling for a fight in order to flex his muscles.

talk.start.para: —Who said he was an `ex' communist?

—He is now a member of the Labor Party. He may be a communist, too, but he is a member of the Labor Party. He has been trying to flex his muscles. For the last six or eight weeks, since the people of Victoria made their decision at the ballot box at the Victorian election, he has been trying to cause confrontation in strikes. They clearly said that Victoria could no longer put up with the economic chaos that it had experienced over the last period of government. They made that decision at the ballot box and, ever since that day, Mr Halfpenny has been trying to provoke a strike. He has been trying to provoke a strike for six weeks.

para.tab: Everyone knows that Australia cannot afford to have a strike. Everyone knows that these strikes have now become an anachronism that Australia can no longer afford. With this stoppage today, Australia is losing a day of production. Workers are losing a day's pay, which will be a loss nationally of $33m. In Queensland, ports will close down; 300,000 workers will protest; 10,000 miners will strike, at a cost to the State of $18m; and 20,000 metal workers will strike, affecting 10,000 companies. Many companies in the metal industry are not in any financial shape to withstand any sort of strike. Abattoirs will close, affecting overseas deliveries and graziers.

talk.start.para: —Very sad.

—Senator Bjelke-Petersen rightly points out that it is a sad day for Australia when this is allowed to happen. The Prime Minister said that he had Mr Kelty in his pocket and that he has the unions in his pocket. The Prime Minister used the left wing leadership of the union movement to defeat Mr Hawke and get leadership of the Government. The Prime Minister needs to display a bit of backbone. He is talking about his vision for Australia and how he is going to help Australia. How will a decision made by the Government of Victoria affect what happens in Queensland or New South Wales? How will a decision made by the Premier of the Victorian Government affect other States? Why should the people in Queensland, Western Australia or New South Wales go on strike because a decision is made in Victoria that the ACTU does not like? There is no point in it at all. The people of Queensland cannot have any effect on the decisions made by the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett.

para.tab: The real issue is that the Prime Minister relied heavily on the left wing union leaders in Victoria to remove Mr Hawke from office. He is in bed with them; he is beholden to them; he has formed a coalition with them. He has provided proof for the old adage: if you lie down with dogs, you get up with fleas.

Senator Cook is hoist with the same petard. He knows only too well that these strikes are futile, that they will not achieve anything, and that they are stupid. They will not achieve anything for Australia other than to swing back support to the conservative forces. Senator Cook has often said—and I have heard him say it a number of times in this chamber—`I do not condone industrial disputation. I am one who has stood on a record of bringing industrial harmony to this country'. That is one of his famous quotes.

Where is he today? He will not condone the strike, but he certainly will not condemn it. He has not used any of his influence within the union movement to stop the strike going ahead. There is no worse time in Australia for a strike such as this to take place. We have unemployment standing at 11.3 per cent, with nearly 20 per cent of people either underemployed or not employed at all, and we have $150 billion in net foreign debt. The last thing Australia needs or can afford is a series of strikes such as this.

Bob Carr and Carmen Lawrence have condemned these strikes. Why can this Federal Government not develop a bit of backbone and also condemn the strikes? It is condoning the strikes by not taking a firm position against them. When Australia is crying out for leadership, this Government, including the Prime Minister and Senator Cook, the Minister for Industrial Relations, is displaying none whatsoever.

As one of the previous speakers said, in the days of the Bolte Government and later, Victoria was the inspiration for Australia. Victoria's manufacturing industry was the driving force of the Australian economy. It was the centrepiece of the Australian economy. During its term in office, the Labor Government got itself into an absolutely disgraceful basket-case position: the State Bank has lost nearly $3 billion; Moody's Investors Service Inc has just delivered a two-notch downgrading to the State's debt rating; it lost the Tricontinental bank; the Pyramid Building Society went broke; and Victoria's public sector debt now stands at nearly $32 billion, which represents $7,130 for every man, woman and child in Victoria. What does this Government expect the Victorian Government to do? It was voted into office to take actions that would bring Victoria back to its great state.

This Government has got into a coalition with Mr Halfpenny. He is calling the shots. He is the Secretary of the Victorian Trades Hall Council. He ended 27 years membership of the Communist Party of Australia in 1979 to join the ALP in 1982. Mr Halfpenny has been described as an old-style Leninist whose leadership style remains true to the Communist Party traditions in which he was nurtured during the 1950s and 1960s. He attended full time training at a party school in the Soviet Union in 1964. As Victorian leader of the Metal Workers Union during the 1970s, Mr Halfpenny played a key role in the strikes of the time, including an eight-week strike which delayed construction of Melbourne's underground loop in May 1976, a four-week garbage strike in 1978 and a nine-week power strike in 1977. The point I am trying to make is that this is the person calling the shots whom those opposite are bowing their knees to and supporting. He is the person that called the strike that those opposite are condoning, and they should be ashamed of themselves.

speech.speaker: Crane Sen W.

talk.start.para: —I support this motion by Senator Parer which is before us today. There is no way possible that I can support the amendment to the motion of the Australian Democrats. All I want to say about the amendment by the Democrats is, `If you stand in the middle of the road you will get run over' or `If you try to put your legs across a barbed wire fence, you will get into trouble'. This motion is about who is running this country. Is it being run by the elected government, whether it be State or Federal, or by anarchists? That is what this motion is about.
—What is your source?

—That is precisely and exactly what it is about: a government that cannot govern. Before I move on to that, I make one point about what occurred here at 3.55 p.m. today when the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, was able to call four of us sitting across this chamber liars but when I responded I had to withdraw and the Minister did not have to withdraw. I think that position needs to be looked at very carefully under the Standing Orders of this place. I do not think one should be allowed to refer collectively to two, three or four people sitting on this side on the chamber as liars and get away with it.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I believe this is a reflection on the Chair. These points were made by way of points of order and a ruling was made. I believe that it is not right for Senator Crane effectively to question that ruling merely because some 20 or 30 minutes have past.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)
—Senator Tate, it would be wrong to reflect on the Chair. I do not hear Senator Crane specifically doing that, but rather referring to a matter that he wishes the Senate to consider further. I ask Senator Crane to continue with his speech on the urgency motion and the amendment that Senator Bell has moved.

talk.start.para: —It was certainly not my intent to reflect on the Chair. My intent was to raise this matter because I think it should be dealt with through the appropriate channels. I make that point in all seriousness. We have heard some remarkable things in here today, particularly from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in his blaming of Premier Kennett for the situation which exists in Victoria. The situation which exists in Victoria is a result of incompetent Labor governments there for the last 10 years, the Cain-Kirner governments. That is why Victoria is probably the most bankrupt State in this nation.
—Tasmania leads the way.

—I do not know whether Tasmania leads the way or not, but it has also had a fair dose of Labor governments. The position which exists in Victoria needs highlighting in terms of this particular debate and the further losses that will occur.

para.tab: If Mr Halfpenny, Mr Kelty and the others involved in calling this national day of sabotage were really and truly honest and concerned about the Victorian situation and the Australian situation, they would have been speaking up loud and clear a long time ago. They failed to do that. In the last day or two the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, Mr Carr, said that the call for this national day of action—as those opposite call it, which in effect means strike—was purely political. That is borne out by the fact that Mr Halfpenny and Mr Kelty failed to take any action prior to this date. It reflects very badly on them.

This motion also reflects disgracefully on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Minister for Industrial Relations and, in fact, the total Government when they have not come out loud and clear in their condemnation of the action that has been taken in Victoria. Goodness only knows, this nation cannot afford it. The one million unemployed and the further one million or so underemployed cannot afford it. This nation cannot afford it with the figures released today for our current account deficit—an additional $1.8 billion adjusted.

Let us look at some of the industries that are affected by this national day of action. We find that the AQIS inspectors have gone out in Victoria. In Western Australia, with the harvest just starting, Co-operative Bulk Handling workers have gone out in Esperance, Kwinana and Geraldton. If we look further, there is a national 24-hour strike in mining. In Victoria there is a 24-hour meat workers strike. In the wool industry, the shearers, shed hands, wool pressers and cooks are to stop work across Victoria for 24 hours. When one looks at all these things and the current account figures which came out today, all one can see is disaster—action that will make things worse for next month and for this year. What do we get from this Federal Labor Government? We get virtual silence. Today in Question Time I asked the Minister this question:

speech.para: Does the Minister agree with the statement made by Mrs Jennie George, Assistant Secretary of the ACTU, that `sooner or later the employers will have to decide whether they can afford to operate with their work force out on strike' . . .

One would have thought that, if there was a semblance of leadership in this place, the Minister would have said, `No, we can't agree with that. That is not the way to do business in this country'. That would have been the right, correct and proper thing for him to say. But he could not answer the question; in five minutes he could not answer that question.

para.tab:
The headlines in today's
Financial Review
relate to the next action to be taken in this matter—tackling individual workplaces, holding them to ransom and blackmailing them. That is what we see reported in the
Financial Review
concerning this action.

talk.start.para: —It is workplace bargaining.

—Is Senator Sherry saying it is workplace bargaining to hold them to ransom, to keep them out there until they are knocked to the ground? The Labor Government has already put 30,000 businesses in this country out of business in the past two years. This Government should be the last to talk about how things should be in this country. It has almost destroyed this nation with its incompetence, its inability to govern in a proper manner and its inability to address the real situation as it applies in Australia today. This motion is about addressing those issues. It is about looking at an alternative plan, something which can give future Australians a chance, something which can give today's Australians a chance, something which can give those one million unemployed people just a little bit of hope in terms of what they might be able to see down the track in the next one, two, three, four, 12 or however many months it might be.

para.tab: There is no chance of that while we have the current situation. If the Prime Minister of this nation really believed in this country, he would have stood up and said, `No, that is the wrong way to do business'. We have often heard the Minister for Industrial Relations talk in this place about the accord partners. We have heard about the accord partners many times. I have had some problems with some of the arrangements that have been made with the accord partners, but I put it to the Minister, who is in the chamber, that if that relationship was so good, strong and effective, the Government could have come out quite clearly and publicly and said, `We have said to our accord partners that this country cannot afford the type of anarchy that we have today'.

I will conclude my remarks by re-emphasising the point that I made at the start. This motion is about who is running this country, who is running the State of Victoria and who is running the various States in this nation. Today we see the nation being run by a group of people who can be described as nothing but anarchists.

speech.speaker: Sherry Sen N.

talk.start.para: —The motion which has been placed before the Senate by the Opposition attempts to draw an analogy between the industrial actions that are taking place around the country today in a variety of forms and the alleged damage being done to the economy in a situation where there are one million people unemployed. That is a false analogy, one which I will deal with shortly.

para.tab: Today various activities are taking place around the country, including strikes in some areas. The day of action includes a variety of activities; I notice that meetings and rallies are being held. The Opposition has not made it very clear whether it supports or condemns that sort of activity. I notice that a fair took place yesterday in Melbourne. I would hardly describe those sorts of actions as particularly militant or Marxist-Leninist in their approach. From the rhetoric that is being thrown across the chamber, one would have to believe that we were back in the 1950s hearing about some sort of communist plot to undermine the future economic structure of this country. That is the sort of rhetoric into which the Opposition's contributions are degenerating.

I would like to make a few comments about strikes in general. I was a union secretary. I am proud of it and do not apologise for it. From my general experience in industrial relations and with industrial disputes, union secretaries and union officials—who are dealt with in abusive terms by those opposite and referred to as union bosses—cannot get up and simply say, `Look, go on strike'. It just does not work that way. Workers in a dispute have to have a good reason for taking industrial action.

In all the disputes in which I have been involved in my 10 years, I can say quite honestly that workers who took part in those disputes did so because they wanted to: they were motivated by a desire to either protect or improve their conditions. Unions are made up of workers and workers are not fools; they know what is in their best interests. An individual getting up in front of them simply does not pronounce, `There shalt be a strike'. There has to be, in the overwhelming majority of cases, good reasons for a strike to take place.

As to strikes in general, the record of this Government is a very good one in terms of the number of strikes that have occurred whilst we have been in office; there has been a significant decline in industrial action in this country. There are a variety of reasons for that and I will be quite frank: it is not just because of the accord. The accord has played a very important role in the very rapid decline in industrial disputes in this country, but certainly the recession has also had an effect. But the very rapid decline in industrial disputation commenced well before this recession occurred. I think that is to the credit of the trade union movement. Indeed, whilst the number of strikes has declined, there has been—except for the last two years—very significant economic growth and very significant employment growth.

So to draw a connection between industrial disputes and the one million unemployed is a very simplistic analogy and one that is not correct. If we look around the world today we see that the unemployment rate in the United Kingdom is fast overtaking Australia's—and if we think we have some economic problems here, we should look at the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom has the so-called free labour market that the Opposition is advocating. It is the same in the United States; its unemployment rate is not quite so high, but it again has the so-called free labour market. This continual claim that so-called free labour markets and free wage negotiations between individual employees and employers means that we do not have unemployment is a total myth. There is no evidence that that is the case. There is no evidence around the world that free labour markets lead to lower unemployment. There is not one clear case study that the Opposition has pointed to.

People in Victoria are angry and we have to ask ourselves why they are angry. I come from Tasmania, and I will make some comments about what has been occurring there. Victoria has attracted a lot of press, but we have had similar sorts of circumstances in Tasmania. Workers are angry in both Victoria and Tasmania because many of their award wages and conditions are being taken away from them by government legislation.

Their annual leave loading is being taken away. It does not matter whether we agree with the annual leave loading or not—and I will give honourable senators a frank view again: I think the annual leave loading is unsustainable; I just think it is too easy a target. It is not sustainable in the long term, even though it is a very small proportion of labour on-costs, and keeping that target there is not doing the industrial movement any good. But things like weekend penalty rates and shift payments are made because workers are legitimately disadvantaged for working those very unsocial hours and for suffering those sorts of disadvantages.

Yet the State Government in Victoria wants unilaterally to take away those sorts of provisions. It is not willing to put a case before the Industrial Commission because the Industrial Commission has been wiped out in Victoria. It is not willing to argue a case. It is making a judgment which is counter to all the empirical evidence that has been produced that there is strong justification for weekend penalties and shift provisions because workers suffer very clear demonstrable disadvantages. It costs more to go to work at weekends because there is no public transport, and child-care centres are usually not open. Honourable senators should work at night on shift work and just see what it is like; it is not a very pleasant lifestyle. But the Victorian Government has decided unilaterally that workers should not be paid anything extra.

The Victorian Government wanted individual work contracts. This is the great theory that we continue to hear about from the Opposition: that the individual employee and the individual employer know what is best for them. They can sit down sensibly and all arrive at a win-win situation. Everyone will be happy and everyone will be better off. That is the sort of glowing world that the Opposition would have us believe will occur under individual work contracts.

The reality is much harsher. Perhaps some members of the Opposition have not negotiated with employers in the past before coming into this place, but I ask: how would they like it if their children had to go out and negotiate with their employers about annual leave, superannuation, sick leave and basic rates of pay? I suggest that most people—including most honourable senators—would not know what an employment contract looks like, let alone what the contents of an employment contract should be. How on earth can individuals who are not educated and trained in employment contracts and employment contract law be expected to negotiate with employers on equal terms?

Generally, employers have accountants, lawyers and security guards who are there to enforce the employers' will. They have the ultimate sanction over the employee—the power to hire and fire. They can say to an employee, `If you don't like it, lump it. You don't have a job'. Those sorts of individual negotiations are cut to suit the employer. I challenge any member of the Opposition to talk to their children, suggest they negotiate their contracts individually and see what comes out of it. I do not think they would be very pleased with some of the conditions which would be imposed on workers in those circumstances.

In Victoria unions do not even have a right of entry—that is, the right to go into the workplace in order to recruit and protect workers—apart from this issue of compulsory unionism which the Opposition uses as a smokescreen. In Tasmania there were some reforms of the industrial relations system as well, although they were certainly not as extreme as in Victoria. I will give the Tasmanian Government that; they were much more moderate changes. They include such things as restrictions on the right of entry and individual work contracts, albeit they are vetted by a tribunal in Tasmania so at least there is some safeguard.

A similar pattern has emerged in Tasmania as has emerged in Victoria. Workers are also angry in those two States because they were misled before the elections in both Victoria and Tasmania. Plenty has been said about what happened in Victoria, but not a lot has been said nationally about what happened in Tasmania. In fact, a much more blatant case of misleading the public occurred in Tasmania.

Prior to the election of the new Tasmanian Government, the Liberal Party was full of praise and platitudes for the union movement in Tasmania. I have in my possession a speech by the President of the Liberal Party in Tasmania, Mr Eric Abetz, who is also a Senate candidate. He gave a speech to the H.R. Nicholls Society on 4 April this year entitled `Tasmania's window of opportunity: the potential for industrial relations reform' from which I will quote. Mr Abetz said:

speech.para: In the booklet entitled `1992 State Election—Liberal Party Policy Statements' the Liberals summarised all commitments made by its leader, Ray Groom, and its spokespeople. The booklet contained 180 pages. Three pages, or more properly two and a half pages, are devoted to industrial relations and the heading of the section is most telling. It is entitled `Industrial Relations—Policy Statement' and sub-titled `Answers to the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council Questionnaire'. So, the Party went into the campaign without an industrial relations policy and only addressed the issue when requested to do so by the TTLC. The intellectual giants of the TTLC . . . were able to develop a comprehensive and in-depth questionnaire. It contained three questions. The question with which we ought concern ourselves is Question 3. The question was:

para.tab: Question 3—"Will you give a commitment not to introduce industrial relations legislation in any way similar to the recent New Zealand and New South Wales Acts and as proposed by the federal Liberal Party?

Answer: "There is no present intention of a State Liberal Government implementing any special new form of industrial legislation. Any need for change that emerges would be subject to full consultation with you at all stages.

talk.start.para: —This is before the election.

—This is before the election. And what happens after the election? This is an example of blatantly misleading the Tasmanian electorate and also boasting about it after the election. No wonder people get angry with what is happening in Tasmania and Victoria. In Victoria, we had a promise, a commitment, from Mr Kennett that there would be no reduction in wages. In Tasmania, we had a Tasmanian Liberal Party that was so interested in industrial relations it did not even have a policy on it but said, `If we did have a policy, we will consult with unions and workers first'. But it did not do that.

para.tab: The blatant hypocrisy of those two Liberal governments is the added reason why workers are so angry in those two communities. So we can understand why when people get angry they take industrial action. I can understand that. I do not like strikes. I was a union official and I do not like them. They are unproductive, bitter and lead to economic losses. But, in a democracy such as we have in this country, there is a price for democracy. I would much rather live in a system where there are strikes—they are inconvenient and there is economic loss—than the type of system that existed in Nazi Germany or in the Stalinist Soviet Union. We have seen what happens in those systems.

The Opposition is always claiming that the unions are at fault. Bear in mind that unions are workers, not just institutions. They are made up of individuals who do make decisions. Where are the calls for management improvement in this country? We always hear about productivity from the Opposition. I do not think the Opposition knows what productivity means or, at least, the distinction between efficiency and productivity. I was reading a very interesting article about Australian international competitiveness. Australia ranks sixteenth out of 23 industrial nations. The Opposition is always talking about that. This report by the Swiss based International Institute for Management Development and the World Economic Forum ranked Australia poorly in domestic economic strength, internationalisation and finance.

Why is Australia in that situation? It attributes the major blame for this performance not to workers but to the quality of management. If we are to criticise unions and workers, where are the positive suggestions? Indeed, where is the legislation in Victoria and Tasmania to assist in improving the quality of management in this country? So let us put industrial action into some perspective. Indeed, in this country, until recently with the dispute in Burnie in Tasmania and the recent disputes in Victoria, there was less production lost from industrial disputes than from sickness and ill-health in the work force.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Lewis Sen A.W.R

talk.start.para: —Today will certainly go down as a blot on Australia's political landscape—a day of shame really—when the trade union movement of Australia called a 24-hour strike with one million Australians unemployed and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) making no criticism of the strike. One has only to say it to think: what a terrible situation it is in Australia, without the leadership of a Prime Minister condemning the action of the trade union movement and with this country in a desperate economic situation, when the Prime Minister is not prepared to say to the ACTU, `This is wrong. You have done the wrong thing. Don't do it. The nation cannot afford it'.

para.tab: Listening to Senator Sherry and Senator Cook—honourable senators on the Government side—one would not appreciate that out there in the real world one million people are looking for jobs while the trade union movement is having a 24-hour strike. The debate we are supposed to be conducting in the Senate is:

speech.para: The refusal of Senator Cook—
he is the Minister for Industrial Relations in this Government—
and Mr Keating—
the Prime Minister—
to call on Labor's accord partner, the ACTU, to abandon mass industrial action—which will only further damage the economy and lessen the chances of Australia's one million unemployed finding jobs.

Indeed, Senator Sherry conceded that such a strike creates great economic difficulty for the nation. He also referred to the bitterness and other concerns about such a strike, but he did not condemn the strike. That is what we are saying about Mr Keating. Why did the Government not recognise that political leadership is needed at this stage? Political leadership means going to the trade union movement and persuading it to call the strike off. It does not mean passing some Bill, which is what Senator Sherry implied we were on about, but simply fronting your mates in the ACTU and telling them the country cannot afford it. That is the sort of political leadership that the Government should give us at this stage. But did we get it from the Prime Minister of Australia? Not on your life.

para.tab: More than a million Australians are fed up with looking for jobs. Just think of the thousands and thousands of applications for jobs that have been rejected, some of them probably not even responded to. People are desperately looking for jobs. Their lives are falling apart as they try to cope with the situation of being unemployed. Today, the trade union movement called for a 24-hour strike. There can be no reason for it other than it being a political strike. The Prime Minister sits quietly and allows the trade union movement to do it. Of course, the Prime Minister is only interested in one thing: how can he get himself re-elected? If in some way or other this strike persuades some people to fear a future Liberal-National Party Federal government, then the Prime Minister will have achieved his aim today in not criticising the strike. Indeed, one would say that he is welcoming the strike because he sees that it may frighten some people into not voting for us at the next election. The fact that the nation cannot afford the strike is not relevant; the economy has collapsed.

I talk to business people regularly all around Australia and they tell me that, for example, when the Prime Minister of Australia announced that he was not to have an election before Christmas a lot of them simply cancelled orders they had put in in anticipation that there would be an election, that the whole nonsense of this Federal Government would be over and done with and that people would be able to get on with their lives. I have warned this Government in the past as to when there have been crisis points. There was another crisis point this month when the Government announced that it would not be calling an election.

Today, we have discovered that Australia lost over $2 billion on its current account in October—another month of loss; the ninth loss in a row. I say to the Prime Minister: just think about what this means. Back in the late 1980s, the Prime Minister squeezed the economy by raising interest rates until they were up to 25 per cent. He did that because we were losing so much money every month on the current account. He raised interest rates until he strangled this economy. Certainly, for a short period of time, we stopped losing money on the current account, but the result was over one million people now unemployed. That is the consequence of that policy of the Prime Minister. Having eased interest rates, back we go again: for nine consecutive months there has been a loss on the current account. It has increased until the stage last month where there was a loss of over $2 billion.

Look out, Australia! The only policy Mr Keating knows to overcome that problem is to raise interest rates again and to create more unemployment by squeezing the economy once again. That is the problem that this country may face under this Prime Minister of no policies, no leadership and no criticism of today's strike. We have nothing from him but re-election schemes—and he should be thrown out as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —The claims made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about Australia being leaner and meaner, poised to compete with tough overseas industrial competitors after Labor's restructuring of our economy, are nothing more than his own rich, vivid and spirited imagination at work; in fact, they are nothing more than a mere illusion. As all of us can easily see, sections of the union movement are acting like a group of Luddites in the face of pending privatisation and industrial relations reform initiatives which are desperately needed right across this country. That is why this matter of urgency, regarding strike action, raised by the Opposition today is so important.

para.tab: Despite an OECD average unemployment rate of 7 1/2 per cent, we have a nation with more than 11 per cent unemployed—a nation in which the pace of critical reform measures is too leisurely; in which some industries have received increased protection; and in which productivity is moving backwards. The buck stops with Labor. Over the past decade, it has not had the gumption to take the hard decisions because it would have stepped on the toes of too many of its union mates. We have a labour movement in this country which, in recent times, has not had to flex its industrial muscle because it has long had direct representation in the Cabinet room. But now it perceives that the honeymoon is over.

With some Liberal governments now elected at State level able and willing to end this nonsense, the union movement has, with the overt support of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), brought mass chaos, disruption and disorder to most States in Australia—particularly, in recent times, to New South Wales and Victoria. We have had disruption not only to the millions of other workers not directly involved in these protests but across the country in numerous industries, slowing productivity and retarding growth. And all for what end? Where will it stop? Will it cease when even more Australians have lost their jobs? Will the union bosses be satisfied when there are two million in the unemployment queues because they had to make a point?

The Kennett Government has, by its win at the Victorian polls some weeks ago, restored hope to what was once a proud and great State; a State which was sent into bankruptcy and economic ruin by years of inept and financially incompetent Labor governments. Hope has been restored by the election of the Kennett Government. But these hopes of recovery are already being strongly undermined by a determined, vicious and selfish union movement which is railing against Premier Kennett's intended industrial reforms.

These mass action movements are not confined to Victoria, where thousands of workers are told by their union bosses to oppose the Victorian Government's industrial relations policy. The saddest feature about these nationwide industrial stoppages and days of protest action, as they are called, is that there will be no winner. The union bosses' strategies to castigate employers outside Victoria for the political reforms of the Victorian Government are nothing short of deranged. All these days of action around the country will have absolutely no effect on Premier Kennett's reform policies, because they will go ahead. Indeed, they must go ahead or Victoria will continue to go right down the drain and unemployment queues will grow larger day by day, as industries close down or move elsewhere.

The stoppages will, however, damage the speed of recovery for industries and the expansion of employment prospects of those already reliant on the public purse. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations have both encouraged this blatant abuse of union power to try to destabilise the coalition Government ever since Premier Kennett was swept to office. This is the strategy they have been working on for months, in concert with the ACTU and thugs such as Halfpenny, in the face of the inevitable defeat of Labor in Victoria.

The blame for Victoria's economic and ensuing industrial disharmony lies squarely at the feet of the ousted Cain-Kirner Labor Government and not with Premier Kennett. It was the former Premier's Government which constructed and maintained the largess for thousands of public sector employees throughout Victoria. Even some Labor supporters have realised that government should no longer support the totally unsustainable featherbedding evident in some public sector jobs.

New South Wales Labor leader Carr was summarily dismissed by ACTU officials when he condemned these stoppages as inappropriate, given the country's current chronic economic problems. The union bosses do not listen to him, so they are not about to listen to anyone else. Even Bob Carr can see that the days of sledge-hammer industrial action are well and truly over. It is a pity his union mates are blinded to truth and reason because they would have even more workers lose their jobs and their income when ports, factories and mines close, just to make this futile political point.

It is not just Labor leaders who are giving the union bosses a bit of stick about the country and where it is headed. Respected Industry Commission Chairman, Bill Scales, has made it quite clear in that organisation's annual report that the mythology created by Mr Keating is damaging and disfiguring this country. He talks about a 6 per cent underlying rate of unemployment remaining with us even after the end of this recession, and the government of the day needing to push ahead vigorously and aggressively with micro-economic reform if unemployment is to go below that 6 per cent. This is exactly what Jeff Kennett is doing—meeting the challenge of industrial and micro-economic reform which the Federal Labor Government has failed to meet.

Even the Industry Commission agrees that that reform must be embraced more wholeheartedly than in the past, yet we have these Luddite unions roaring in and saying, `No, thank you very much; not this century'. They are saying that they do not want prosperity for all Australians if they are going to have to give up some power to achieve it. They are saying that they are going to remain exactly as they have always been, even though our economy is shot to pieces and over one million people are out of work. They are saying, `Don't give an inch', because they do not give a damn for Australia or anyone else living here.

Australia has a too inflexible labour market and it is well and truly caught in a roller-coaster economy. We must face up to our declining international competitiveness and unions must put to their membership the question of their relevance in an era when productivity principles and enterprise bargaining will become as commonplace as industrial go-slow and down tools of an earlier decade.

The Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations could do some real good for this country for a change by showing some leadership and by reigning in their misguided union mates and advising them that the long term ills created by their own Government require long term solutions for all Australians and not merely the self-serving actions taken by a few that we have seen taken in these industrial disputes.

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —The subject of this debate on a matter of urgency has been explained already, but I would just like to add some other thoughts to those that have already been put forward today. It is not simply a matter of people protesting for the sake of protesting. What has been done is not simply a matter that this Parliament can, with a sense of righteousness, condemn, because there have been things in Victoria, perpetrated by the Government down there, which this chamber has been very silent about when it should not have been.

para.tab: It is not simply that the Government in Victoria has tried to remove certain rights from workers, such as the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading; it has, in fact, removed those institutions which were set up to protect people's rights. For example, the Accident Compensation Tribunal was abolished without any word of protest from this chamber, even though the Law Council of Australia was concerned about it, and even though the Bar Council in Victoria and the Law Institute of Victoria were concerned about it. A letter dated 3 November and signed by Mr Hughes, the President of the Law Institute of Victoria, and Mr Jessup, QC, Chairman of the Victorian Bar Council says:

speech.para: Abolition of the Tribunal.

The Bill does not make provision for the futures of the judges by way of recognising their security of tenure. As this threatens judicial independence, we urge you to ensure the continued judicial status in employment in some appropriate way of all presidential members of the tribunal. Judicial independence is fundamental to the maintenance of respect for the rule of law and good government. Expertise in this highly technical legal area cannot be acquired overnight. The judges should not be cast aside.

What is the propriety, as a chamber of the Parliament, of our condemning people who are protesting about their treatment when the sorts of institutions that have been set up to protect them are abolished without one word of protest from this chamber? What has this chamber said about the attack on judicial independence that was made with the abolition of the Accident Compensation Tribunal, which was there to see that there was justice for people injured in the workplace and for employers? What was said in this chamber about the abolition of the Victorian Industrial Relations Commission, again, a body which was set up to protect people employed in the State of Victoria?

para.tab: Perhaps the most shameful episode of all is the fact that we have not protested about the reduction in the ability of parliamentarians in Victoria to go about their duties. When the Executive—that is, the ministry whom parliamentarians, as members of the legislature, attack day after day in Question Time and bring to account—is increased in Victoria, both in terms of numbers and facilities, and, at the same time, the ability of parliamentarians to do their duty is reduced, nobody gets up in this chamber and protests. The legislature is important; it is there to protect people. When people in Victoria and elsewhere see the way those institutions which have been established to protect their rights are reduced, no wonder there is a protest.

With respect and apologies to Martin E. Muller, when the Victorian Government attacked the Victorian Industrial Relations Commissioner, I was not concerned. When the Victorian Government attacked the Accident Compensation Tribunal, I was not concerned. When it attacked the unions, I was not concerned. When it attacked the very institution of parliament, I was not concerned. Then, when it attacked me, there was nobody left to be concerned. When people see the traditional rights that they have come to rely upon attacked in the way they have been and no-one in this Parliament protests about it, what are they to do but to try desperately to bring some attention to it?

When people do that, what are they condemned for doing? They are condemned for being subject, so it is said, to union bosses. Conciliatory phrases, such as `thugs like Halfpenny', have been used in this chamber. The use of that phrase indicates that the other side perceives that this dispute has been caused by `thugs like Halfpenny'. Mr Halfpenny is the very respected secretary of the Trades Hall Council in Victoria.

There is a laugh from those opposite. If Senator Parer and Senator Crane checked this, they would find that Mr Halfpenny has brought more good to industry in Victoria—by the statement of those industrialists—than he has caused otherwise. It is just a sign that there is a blindness on the part of those opposite to see the good that has been done by workers and their representatives in Victoria.
I want to know why Mr Gordon Hughes, President of the Law Institute of Victoria, and Mr Jessup, Chairman of the Victorian Bar Council, said this about the Acts and Compensation Work Cover Bill:

speech.para: It is a cause of grave concern that common law rights are removed and introduced retrospectively.

That is how the sentence reads. I think it should read, `It is a cause for grave concern that common law rights are removed and rendered nugatory retrospectively'. But the point is that it is retrospective legislation that has removed rights from people in Victoria.

para.tab:
I would have thought that the motion today would at least have contained a provision that, in so far as the Government of Victoria has reduced, and even destroyed, long held rights that not only workers but people generally had come to rely on, that should be reversed. I would have hoped that those opposite, who are of the same political persuasion as the Government in Victoria, might have said something about all that. But apparently that has not happened. On Friday, the
Age
had this to say:

speech.para: Workers who breach an employment contract, or anyone who induces a worker to breach any provisions of the contract, are liable for fines starting at $1000.

Why should a worker who breaches his or her employment contract, perhaps by arriving late or taking a day off when he or she should not, be find $1,000? That is not how contracts are normally enforced. The criminal law is not used to enforce contracts. Does Senator Crane say that the breach of contracts should be visited by criminal penalties? When people protest, who are condemned?

talk.start.para: —What was that?

—This is an article from the front page of Friday's
Age
. I invite Senator Crane to read it. It says:

speech.para: Workers who breach an employment contract, or anyone who induces a worker to breach any provisions of the contract, are liable for fines starting at $1000.

talk.start.para: —Did you say I said that?
—Senator Crane was laughing when I said that that was something to be condemned.
—I was talking to Senator Parer.

—I am sorry. I withdraw that statement. I mistook what he was doing. But is it not shameful that a wife, for example, who asks her husband to stay home for the day because the children are sick—thus causing him to breach the employment contract—in looking to the welfare of the child should be liable for a fine starting at $1,000 because she induced her husband to breach the contract?

para.tab:
Just how devastating this is is borne out in the article and the picture which appeared in the
Age
last Saturday, headed `Eight faces, six sacked. Who's minding the children'. These eight women were looking after children in hospital who might need some comforting in their hour of stress, who might be facing an operation, and who might be without their parents. Six of those people will be dismissed.

talk.start.para: —Oh!

—Senator Parer ridicules that. He should read the article and look at the picture. Senator Parer is not prepared to accept the evidence that is before us today. I simply say: let us get to the cause of all these problems—this outrageous stepping on the traditional values that we have all nurtured so well over the years. Let us get rid of this vicious attack on our common law rights. Let us get rid of this attack on the great institutions that have underpinned our democracy. Having done that, we might condemn people who protest.
(Time expired)
