talk.start.para: —Order! For the information of the Senate, I present three papers on procedural matters which I forwarded to all senators on 17 November 1992, in accordance with undertakings I gave in the Senate.

speech.speaker: Kemp Sen R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the documents.

speech.para:
Mr President, I wish to comment on two of the three statements that you tabled today: the first one,
Criticism of the Senate by the Prime Minister
and the second,
Questions relating to Opposition policy
. These are very important statements because they involve what I believe to be significant issues of principle. The first statement relates to the duties of the President and the behaviour of the Prime Minister, and those are the principles which I wish to canvass. The second statement relates to the nature of Question Time and the constraints which are placed on Ministers in answering questions.

para.tab: Let me preface my remarks by suggesting that the roles of the Presiding Officers—the Speaker and the President—are probably receiving closer scrutiny than at any other time in memory, and possibly since Federation. I believe that this has come about as a result of a number of factors. First, there is the widespread perception that parliamentary standards have declined dramatically in the 1980s, and the community is looking to its parliamentary leaders to take action to raise those standards. You, Mr President, as one of the ranking officers of the Parliament, hold an office which encompasses a very long tradition, and I believe that you are one of those people that the community is looking to.

Secondly, the advent of television broadcasting of Question Time I believe has given further focus to the key role of the Presiding Officer. Thirdly, I think there would be general agreement that the controversial activities of the Speaker in the other place has led to widespread media debate over quite a long period of time. Finally, there is the perception in some quarters at least that Presiding Officers must take some of the responsibility for the decline in parliamentary standards. For example, I draw your attention to a recent paper released by a former Speaker, Dr Ken Coghill, and a former President, Mr Hunt, of the Victorian Parliament, where it was suggested that the decline of Question Time had resulted in part because of the rulings by the Presiding Officers.

Of course, we all have a responsibility for maintaining parliamentary standards. In the context of these remarks I do not pretend to say that you, Mr President, and the Speaker, have the key role, but I think you have an important role to play in ensuring that parliamentary standards are maintained. We have enough examples, which I do not wish to canvass today, of what happens when a Presiding Officer is perhaps not prepared to use the full authority of his office to maintain standards in the Parliament.

I think the challenge facing Presiding Officers in this Parliament has become particularly significant because of the key role that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) himself has played in the degeneration of parliamentary standards. Are Presiding Officers going to accept the standards of the Prime Minister? Whatever the decision of the Speaker in the other place may be, there is in my view no reason why the President of the Senate should not stand up to the Prime Minister when the matter relates to the conduct of the Senate, and when we believe that proper parliamentary conduct has not occurred.

I think it is true to say that, unlike any other Prime Minister in Australian history, Mr Keating seems to have an unbridled contempt for the political institutions that have served this nation so well for almost a century. I believe the abuse of Question Time in the other place is the most obvious manifestation of this contempt. In addition, Mr Keating has attacked the role of the head of state and, in his most recent remarks, attacked the Senate. It seems to me that no part of our constitutional arrangements is immune from the Prime Minister's venom.

The question before this chamber, I believe, is: can the community look towards the Presiding Officers to assist in the improvement of parliamentary standards? Mr President, I believe that this was the challenge you were faced with when the Prime Minister referred to senators as `unrepresentative swill'. I believe that a statement by you would have made a very substantial and important community impact. The statement, I believe, that would have been appropriate—and I put this on the table—would be along these lines: it would be appropriate if the Prime Minister adhered to longstanding tradition and avoided reflection on members of the Senate. Such a statement would have been widely welcomed in the community. It would have affirmed the importance of your office in maintaining parliamentary standards and certainly affirmed in the community the view that parliamentary standards are worth defending and that you see your role in that light, as well as the other duties that you have.

Such a statement by you would have been fully in line with Standing Orders, longstanding traditions and relations between the chambers, and based upon appropriate precedents. There seems little doubt that Mr Keating's reference to senators as `unrepresentative swill' was offensive, both in terms of the Standing Orders of the other place, and contrary to the tradition, outlined in
Australian Senate Practice
, that `members and senators should refrain from reflections on members and proceedings of the other chambers'. In other words, what I am putting to you, Mr President, is that it was not a complex problem that you were faced with; it was a clear breach of the courtesy which should exist between the chambers. I believe that, because of your office, an immediate response from you would have affirmed in the community mind the importance of high standards in parliamentary conduct.

In your paper you said that you had examined the papers of your predecessors and could find no examples of Presiding Officers responding to such criticisms. That may well be the case, but I suggest that this is probably because this is the first time a Prime Minister has launched such an insulting attack upon senators. I do not pretend that the chamber has not been criticised from time to time by other political leaders, and there may well be examples from my own Party, but I suspect that the disgraceful, insulting terms in which that attack was launched are unprecedented in Australian history. It is not surprising that you could not find precedents. Mr President, I wonder whether you are able to provide the chamber with examples of any other Prime Minister who has indulged in such demeaning language about senators as a whole.

There are precedents where Presiding Officers have made statements when the Parliament has been attacked. I draw your attention to a statement by the President of the Western Australian Legislative Council. The President criticised a magistrate who, among other things, said:

speech.para: . . . maybe the lowest form of life is in the Parliament.

A magistrate made that comment in sentencing an offender. You will be interested to know that the President of the Western Australian Legislative Council took considerable objection to that statement by a magistrate. He suggested, among other things, that the magistrate should note the comments of Lord Denning, which I propose to incorporate in
Hansard
, and should avoid making privileged statements offensive to the legislative arm of government and members of the House that invite retaliation resulting in further damage being done to the standing of members of parliament and the reputation of judicial officers. I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
the remarks of Lord Denning that were quoted by the President of the Legislative Council.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The document read as follows
—

speech.para: The President quoted the comments of Lord Denning in a 1968 case dealing with criticism of the courts and individual judges when he said:

"It is the right of every man, in Parliament or out of it, in the press or over the broadcast, to make fair comment, even outspoken comment, on matters of public interest. Those who comment can deal faithfully with all that is done in a court of justice. They can say that we are mistaken, and our decisions erroneous, whether they are subject to appeal or not. All we would ask is that those who criticise us will remember that, from the nature of our office, we cannot reply to their criticisms. We cannot enter into public controversy. We must rely on our conduct itself to be its own vindication. . .

talk.start.para: —If the President of the Legislative Council in Western Australia could censor in moderate language the conduct of a magistrate, how much more important is it that when challenged we should censor foul language and abuse by the most powerful man in this country, the Prime Minister? Mr President, I would like you to reflect on the fact that a Presiding Officer, when faced with a similar problem, decided to adopt a different course from the course that you chose to adopt.

para.tab: In contrast to the language of Mr Keating, it is worth recalling the views of another Labor leader, Mr Chifley, who said:

speech.para: Honourable Members should not forget that in the life of a democracy, it is important that the public should respect, not necessarily a party, but the Parliament. And everything we do to destroy that respect, deals a blow to democracy itself . . .

Mr President, it is not a matter of asking you to respond to all public attacks on the Senate or seeking to have you become involved with continuing exchanges with critics. I think you made those points in your statement and I would endorse those views. But the Prime Minister is not just another critic; he holds the most powerful office in this country. Mr President, I suspect that, as a result of his comments, you were faced with a special challenge. Regrettably, I believe, you did not respond to that challenge and, as a result, the possibility of striking a blow for higher standards in this Parliament did not occur.

para.tab:
Mr President, you said that you did not want to involve your office in a public exchange with the Prime Minister. As might be expected, given Mr Keating's standards, his office had no such compunction and was prepared to tell Michelle Grattan, as was published in an article in the
Age
on 7 November that, having made contact with the Prime Minister's office, you should `shove it'. I think it was a mistake, to be quite frank, for you to have made contact with the Prime Minister's office. In her article, Michelle Grattan said:

Earlier, Sibraa had told Keating's senior staffer he might have to write Keating a brief letter about the approach he'd had from the Liberals. He was seeking advice from the Senate clerk. The PM's advice to Sibraa on such a letter was unequivocal: "Shove it". Sibraa told the Senate on Thursday: "It is not my role . . . to enter into a political debate between members of the two houses.

speech.para: Mr President, I put it to you that you were conscious of the problem involved here. As to whether you should have approached the Prime Minister's office—I note that you said that you approached the Prime Minister to inform him that such a statement had been made—the Prime Minister was quite happy to enter into a public debate with you and his office leaked to Michelle Grattan the substance of those comments; so your courtesy and your efforts to fulfil your duty as you saw it, and there is some debate about that, was not reciprocated by the Prime Minister.

para.tab: Mr President, I thought some interesting points were made in the debate surrounding your decision. I recognise that it is a debate. I suspect that men and women of goodwill will come down on either side on such an issue. From my own research and reflecting on it, I think the issue is quite clear-cut. Nonetheless, I accept that it is a debate and that others will differ.

Senator Terry Aulich, a distinguished senator and more recently a distinguished author, raised an interesting issue in his contribution when he suggested that your actions had been as scrupulously fair as any President can be, given that you are a member of a political party. It seemed to me that what he gave so generously with one hand he took away with the other. The reality is that, unlike the House of Commons, in Australia we have presiding officers who are members of political parties.

We are all aware that this creates special problems and special challenges. I do not think that all the challenges are minus, although there are some concerns in this area. It is not clear to many people that you, unlike most other presiding officers, I suspect, preside over a chamber in which a substantial majority of members do not belong to the same political party as yourself. Mr President, you are a well-respected Presiding Officer and well liked on this side of the chamber and, I assume, amongst your own colleagues. That sort of respect provides you with a stronger basis to maintain Standing Orders and to assert parliamentary standards than might be apparent at first sight.

I happen to agree with Senator Aulich that we should be looking at whether it is possible in our parliamentary system to create a non-party presiding officer, a so-called independent presiding officer. There are complications with that, but it is certainly a challenge which should be taken up. I would like to see more research done on that particular issue. Speaker Snedden canvassed it very extensively before he left office. With my own parliamentary experience and after reading what Speaker Snedden said, I have some sympathy with the views that he expressed. It is interesting that Speaker Rozzoli of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly has said:

speech.para: I do not attend party meetings. I don't attend party functions, except in the electorate, where I've obviously got to go back and fight an election and I have an electorate so I've got to be party-political to some extent there.

Speaker Snedden held a similar view. Those are the sorts of issues that should be considered by both sides of the Parliament: to what extent we can buttress the office of the Presiding Officer from party influence. For example, to the extent that this happens, it is probably a bad thing for the presiding officers to be present at meetings where parliamentary tactics are discussed. It puts the presiding officers in a very difficult position and leaves them open to attack.

para.tab:
Mr President, I want to briefly look at the questions which relate to Opposition policy. This is another challenge that you have been faced with in this chamber. It has become a contentious issue, again in part because of the behaviour of the Prime Minister, who generally believes that Question Time should be a launching pad against the Opposition rather than for questions about his administration. The purpose of Question Time as outlined in Odgers'
Australian Senate Practice
is as follows:

speech.para: Without doubt, to the onlooker the most obvious manifestation of responsible Government, i.e. the direct accountability of the Executive to the Parliament, is question time. For about an hour, Senate Ministers are subjected to the questions of private Senators, both Government members and Opposition members, with respect to the administration of their departments and the departments they represent in the Senate on behalf of Ministers in the House of Representatives. With a variety of questions, the searchlight is thrown on to all aspects of government activities, and Ministers must account for their administration.

I suggest that is a somewhat purist view of Question Time. I happen to agree with Senator Robert Ray that Question Time is inevitably a robust period when great clashes of values and ideas occur. I think those clashes are by no means a bad thing, and it is important that they be exposed in a public forum.

para.tab: I do not dispute with Senator Ray that questions about Opposition policies have occurred. They have occurred with increasing frequency in the other place and they have occurred in this chamber. Senator Ray brought to our attention four or five examples of where the previous Government asked questions about Opposition policies. I had a cursory glance at all the references that Senator Ray made. My impression is—and, as I say, it was a cursory glance—that the questions appear to be more one-off questions rather than a constant, deliberate strategy to ensure that a significant proportion of the 40 to 50 minutes which is taken up by Government Ministers at Question Time is taken up with attacking the policies of the Opposition.

It is a problem that we have to face up to in this chamber. It is clear from the previous rulings of the Presiding Officers, including some of your rulings, Mr President, that questions on Opposition policies are out of order. I think it is a pity, on reading the examples given in the paper that you tabled, Mr President, that your 1987 ruling tended to dilute the previous rulings of Presidents which made it pretty clear that, whatever had been the examples in the past—and Senator Ray has brought us those examples—certainly, until 1987, those questions were largely out of order.

It is inevitable that, in the context of Question Time, there is going to be a very heavy debate in this chamber and, from time to time, this will involve questions on the policies of the Opposition. I suggest that that is a different matter from having question after question and answer after answer constantly devoted to attacking and, in some cases, misrepresenting the policies of the Opposition.

This problem has been highlighted by the fact that the proceedings of this chamber are now televised. It may not have been such a problem when the public scrutiny was not so obvious, but to imagine that Opposition senators are going to sit quietly while Minister after Minister gets up and drops buckets on their policies and refuses to answer reasonable questions about their own activities is expecting a great deal of tolerance on the part of Opposition parties.

In my view, this is a major issue. Having looked at the way questions have been asked and answers given in recent weeks, again we see Ministers adopting a bit of the tactic we have seen in the other place where the sole focus of Question Time has been to attempt to attack the Opposition rather than account for the administration of the Government as outlined in Odgers'
Australian Senate Practice
. I notice that Senator Ray has a large wad of papers in front of him, so he is obviously going to query my comments.

I suggest this issue has to be addressed. It is certainly one view that Ministers have to answer for their own policies and administration, but when it tips over so that one-off examples of Ministers attacking Opposition policies become a matter of deliberate strategy, the whole nature of Question Time has changed. Therefore, we have to reflect on what must be done in terms of your rulings, Mr President, to see whether we can attempt to at least bring Question Time back into a position where people have the right to hear what the Government policies are, rather than ceaselessly hear attacks on the policies of the Opposition.

Mr President, whereas I have differed from you in relation to your approach to the Prime Minister's disgraceful attacks and, to a certain extent, in relation to your Question Time rulings, I stress that I make these comments in a constructive manner. But unless we deal with the problem of Question Time, I suspect that it is asking an awful lot of the people on this side of the chamber to remain quiet while Ministers get up and ceaselessly attack and, on many occasions, misrepresent the Opposition's policies.

speech.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —I like these debates because I get an indication of who, a hundred years hence, will be nominated for sainthood. It is quite a long process from beatification through to canonisation, but I like to be here on the ground floor to listen to the pious statements from some of those opposite when it comes to matters of Standing Orders—their rigid adherence to the rule and their humble subservience to the great virtues of this chamber. It is a pity that most of their activities the rest of the time are diametrically opposed to what they preach in here when we come to procedure debates.

para.tab: Of course, there will always be a decline in parliamentary standards. For 90 years people have probably been whingeing, on and off, about a decline in parliamentary standards. What happens in this chamber changes from decade to decade, and past precedent is sometimes useful and sometimes absolutely useless.

I have been in this chamber only a few years, but the first matter greatly exploited here was petitions. I remember when one Wednesday—because, of course, that was a broadcast day—we went for 47 minutes, with honourable senators jumping up and reading petitions. In the end, I think we were all sick of it. If anyone started that trend, it was this side of the chamber rather than that side. So one of the great leaks, if you like, in Senate procedure was blocked off and now the Clerk of the Senate reads out petitions. There was then a little variation in procedure. We would get petitions which were not in conformity with Standing Orders and they would be read out on radio broadcast day. But I think an Opposition initiative suggested that those could be read out only on non-broadcast day.

The second great explosion was in notices of motion, where we had a proliferation not only in numbers but also in length and content. But, again, that has been restricted. Then we had the great noting of answers to questions episode. In the Fraser years, probably five answers were noted after Question Time in seven or eight years. But within a year, I think in excess of 100 to 150 answers to questions were noted. So we have cut that back and introduced Standing Orders that restrict the noting of answers to questions to half an hour, and four minutes per speaker. Of course, today, the new puerile trick is to hold up newspaper headlines in unison around the back of the chamber. That is supposed to be a wonderful innovation in the Senate.

Frankly, the authority is best held in this chamber, if there is a little more discipline shown by both sides. But I do not blame the Presiding Officer for not enforcing anything. When he has had to take the ultimate step to enforce discipline, on three occasions that I can remember no-one on that side supported him—yet most, in their heart of hearts, would have thought that the President's actions were justified. There was the naming of Senator Walters five years ago—and I am not trying to harp on that; I use that as one example—and the naming of Senator Kemp when he was actually thrown out of the chamber and then we had to bring him back.

talk.start.para: —I was invited back.

—We invited him back because we all know that, using the procedures of this place, it is easier to have him speaking inside this Senate than outside the Senate speaking in—to use a phrase. Senator Alston was then named for, quite clearly, a strong breach of Standing Orders. Those opposite did not back the President in any of those debates. So if they come in here and want presidential authority exercised, maybe they should show a bit more commitment to that presidential authority when it is justified.
—But perhaps they were not justified.

—Of course, these cases are never justified according to Senator Knowles; she never supports them. The only one she ever supported was when we barrelled out Senator Vallentine; we all agreed on that. But we knew that she was going to be thrown out that day because she was reading that particular section of Odgers and Standing Orders. So we knew that she was going to misbehave deliberately in order to be thrown out.

para.tab: It comes back to what a glass jaw this chamber has. I have been embarrassed to be a senator and hear the weak and wimpish attitude of those opposite. Just because the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gets into us, it is the end of the world. The Prime Minister makes a statement about us, and what do we do? We take our bat and ball and go back home. We do not even send him a message from this chamber to his chamber to say what we think of that view. Those opposite are very thin skinned. The Prime Minister makes a reference to Senate `swill' and that is the end of the world and the most important issue around, when it should be regarded as just a trivial issue and criticism.

This chamber is very robust in its criticism of all sorts of people in the community. Therefore, we should cop any criticism that comes back. However, there is a big difference, because most people are not covered under law in terms of defamation or anything else when they make a criticism of this place. However, with a few exceptions and if we are reasonably careful, there are no laws of defamation applying to things said by senators in this chamber.

I think it is pretty weak to carry on in the way Senator Kemp has today about this issue. It is not the first time this has happened. Points of order have been taken and pompous speeches have been made about the number of questions asked here. It is true that from 1980 to 1983 more questions were asked. But, if we go back and check the record, we find that a record number of questions were placed on notice. No wonder so many questions were got through. I invite Senator Kemp and those opposite to go back and have a look, as I have in the last week, at the length of some of the answers in that period; it was well and truly equal to anything we have done in the last few years, and sometimes well and truly in excess.

Senator Kemp started quoting the President of the Western Australian Legislative Council. That is hardly the most democratic body I have ever struck but, according to Senator Kemp, it is supposed to be setting the record. If it had not been so obdurate in 1988-89 or so committed to rigging the electoral system and had let the original Bill through on the distribution of electorates—as Senator Chaney was forced to nominate in this chamber—the Liberal Party would have won the 1989 election. So Senator Kemp need not tell me about the Western Australian Legislative Council and hold it up as a particular example that we should follow.

Senator Kemp went on to quote a great Labor Prime Minister, Ben Chifley. I dare say that anyone in Ben Chifley's position would absolutely laud Parliament if they had a majority in both Houses. But this mob opposite will not walk out next week and advocate that the Victorian Government give up its majority in the Legislative Council in Victoria. Oh, no! Dr Hewson is on the record as saying that he desperately wants to control both chambers. If this chamber under a Hewson government had the impertinence to reject anything, he would go straight off to the Governor-General the second time around and there would be a double dissolution. That is what has been promised and that is how much the Liberal Party is committed to non-party rule in the Senate.

All we are hearing today are bleatings from people who do not have a majority. We do not have a majority either and we have to live with that. Senator Kemp went on to ask for higher standards. This comes from someone who interjected a minimum of 30 times today at Question Time in breach of Standing Orders.

We then went on to discuss the question of the political allegiance of Presiding Officers. We do not have a system which allows us to follow the British system. Britain has 635 seats and a long tradition in this way. The first moment the Liberal Party decides to have an independent Speaker and we agree to it, that Speaker would come from the most marginal seat, as would be the case with the Labor Party. Golly, gosh; that locks up one seat at the next election, does it not? Those opposite need not tell me they would not do it. We would do it; they would do it. They would do the same with the President. Would they run the President as No. 1 one or No. 2 on their ticket? Of course not. They would run him down at No. 5 or No. 6 so that he automatically had to be elected. That was a silly suggestion. I am sure Mr President would not mind going one berth higher but, with your track record, Mr President, I know you will pull off the third spot in New South Wales.

The thing that irritates me is that the subject of Speaker Snedden has once again been resurrected in the Senate—`Saint Snedden' of the House of Representatives. He was fairly neutral in his political approach. Everyone in that chamber knows why; because he hated Fraser. That is why he could be politically neutral. He was paid off with the Speaker's job. That was fair enough. All parties have done that over the years to get rid of a critic. But he was pretty neutral because he disliked Fraser almost as much as he disliked us. But it did not stop him from interfering in the design of this building to make sure that the Opposition executive party room was as small as possible. We got all sorts of complaints from members of the Opposition over this, but Speaker Snedden did that to punish us long term. All that was wrong with it was that we won the 1983 election and now those opposite have to cop that. Half the design of this building was perverted to suit Speaker Snedden and get revenge over Fraser and anyone else that he thought he could get revenge over. So those opposite need not put up Speaker Snedden as the great neutral Speaker and Presiding Officer.

Frankly, the whole issue of `Senate swill' is too much sensitivity from those opposite. It is either a pretence or those opposite are very puerile in their attitude. But let me move on to the second issue—objections to questions. Reading the Standing Orders—as we have on occasions with regard to questions—we all know just how useless the Standing Orders are in this regard because one really should not even make statements of facts or names unless it is absolutely necessary, or strictly necessary, to render the question intelligible.

A question is not allowed to contain arguments, inferences, imputations, epithets, ironical expressions or hypothetical matter. That is done here every day by those in opposition; we do not object to that. And a question should not ask for an expression of opinion. How often does that occur? A question should not ask for a statement of government policy or for a legal opinion. Maybe that is the one that is most knocked out here. Nor should a question refer to debates in the current session or proceedings in committee not reported to the Senate.

How often have we had an MPI listed and had eight or nine questions at Question Time referring to that MPI? It happens all the time. On the problem of whether Ministers are allowed to refer to Opposition policy, a lot of points have been made by, I think, Senator Kemp and Senator Bishop very selectively quoting rulings on this particular matter. If they care to go back and research it, they will find that nine times out of 10 the Presiding Officer, Labor or Liberal—be it Senator Condor Laucke, Senator Young, Senator Sibraa or Senator McClelland—ruled in favour of the person asking the question.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish!

—Before Senator Walters interjects, `Rubbish!', she should have a look at the record. I will just go through a few examples that I picked from the period 1980 to 1983. On 25 March 1980, Senator Hamer asked:

speech.para: Has the Minister representing the Prime Minister seen details of the proposals of the Australian Labor Party to create 100,000 jobs at a cost to revenue of $180m a year? What would be the effects on inflation of such a scheme? Would such a scheme in fact create more jobs? Has the Minister seen a record of comments of the former Labor Premier of South Australia, Mr Don Dunstan, that the ALP's basic assumption is not valid and that the level of unemployment could be expected to increase?

That is a direct question on ALP—the then Opposition—policy. It is good enough for the Liberals but it is not good enough for any Labor backbencher to ask such questions. But let us deal with the interjection, `Rubbish!', by Senator Walters. On 10 November 1981, Senator Walters said:

My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister noted that the Australian Labor Party's new defence policy is based on Australia's need for defence self-reliance? Can the Minister say whether this now represents endorsement of the Government's defence planning policy?
I will try to keep this one quick because I did quote it the other day. On 28 February 1982, Senator Hill said:
But is such a statement consistent with announced Federal Labor Party policy on uranium mining?
What about Senator Walters again? She is a definite recidivist on this issue. On 26 February 1980, she said:

My question follows that of Senator Wriedt and is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I preface it by reminding the Minister of an article in the
Sydney Morning Herald
of 4 February this year, in which the Opposition spokesman on energy stated that the Australian Labor Party's oil policy would be to adjust petrol prices in line with the consumer price index or with import parity, whichever was the lesser. Is this not a contradiction of Labor's previously announced policy to cut petrol prices? Further, how could the ALP justify its broken promise to the Australian motorist, given that it will not admit that import parity pricing encourages conservation and provides funds for further exploration?
A blatant example of questioning of an Opposition's policy. Or we could go to what Senator Young said on 16 September 1980:

Has the Minister for National Development and Energy seen further statements by Mr Keating of the Australian Labor Party that the Labor Party would freeze the price of petrol for 12 months and then adjust it moderately in accordance with the consumer price index? What effect would this have on the overall Australian crude oil situation, particularly when related to the Labor Party's policy for a resource tax?
We have Senator Teague jumping in on 8 September 1982 where he says:

I ask the Minister for Education whether his attention has been drawn to the statement made two days ago by the former Prime Minister, Sir William McMahon, on
PM
, that the first reason for the Liberal Party victory and the Australian Labor Party's collapse in the Flinders by-election was `the activities of Dawkins', the education spokesman for the Opposition, and the divisive policy on independent schools announced recently by the Australian Labor Party. What response has there been from Catholic schools and representatives of other independent schools by way of endorsement of the Government's firm commitment of support for all non-government schools?

talk.start.para: —Hurford was put in to replace Dawkins as a result of that question.

—Yes, but it is on Opposition policy. If Senator Teague wants to go back and debate the merits of a 10-year old policy, I dare say we will, but all I am showing is that when Senator Teague and others bleat away here at Question Time he did it in government as a backbencher trying to make his way up the greasy pole; so why blame anyone on this side for doing it? Why bleat on at Question Time and badger the President about it with points of order? We have another question here from Senator Noel Crichton-Browne on the Labor Party's policy on uranium. We have Senator Bonner on 16 February asking a question about the Labor Party's capital gains tax. There is a question by Senator Messner on Opposition policy on 31 March 1980. He is asking another direct question:

speech.para: Is it more likely that Mr Keating is seeking to mislead the people of Australia for political purposes?
And on he goes. It covers the whole ideological spectrum of the coalition. Senator Peter Baume asked this question:

Did the Labor Party's recent Federal Conference adopt a policy opposed to all new uranium mining? Does the new Labor policy announced by Mr Isaacs, the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory, confirm a split in the Labor Party over uranium mining—

et cetera. Senator Teague is mentioned in dispatches again on 16 November 1982. He was very diligent in asking about our policy. There is no rumour in the fact that he seeks to be a member of the Labor Party and wants to discuss it in here consistently. Occasionally, a point of order is raised. My colleague Senator Tate, from Tasmania, objected to Senator Teague's question on Labor Party policy and the President said:
There is no point of order. I call the Minister.
Consistently through half of these when any objection is raised the ruling is that these matters are in order.

talk.start.para: —What happened to the other half?

—In the other half there was no objection taken. They were far more relaxed, they were not as thin-skinned and they were not as gutless in those days; and we had such good policies we did not mind the Opposition debating them in here at all. It is only because the Opposition has such cruddy policies that it never wants the spotlight put on them. That is why those opposite are trying to repackage and paddle under water as quickly as they can at the moment.

para.tab: It should not be that Question Time simply becomes a consideration of Opposition policies at any one time. It is only fundamentally a correct question when the Government is asked whether it would adopt those policies. Some scope has to be allowed for that, but you, Mr President, have been quite consistent in asking the Minister to get back to the point. Therefore, there is a midway, and I believe you have ruled in a particular and correct way.

Mr President, at different times your rulings have brought grief to both sides of this House. You have managed to preside over this chamber with a great degree of impartiality in the time that you have held the post. You have annoyed both sides and you have also appeased both sides in your rulings. That is the way it should be. I often think that sometimes the objections taken by those opposite are meant more to disrupt the proceedings at a particular time. I do not say that that is a consistent pattern, but from time to time I believe that has also occurred. I acknowledge that it occurs on either side of the chamber when either party is in opposition. But it should be taken too seriously when and if it does.

I have no real comments on amendments and requests, which I think are covered somewhere in this documentation, because I have not read the papers in any detail. The question of motions for suspension of Standing Orders is one which we have debated here, not necessarily in a partisan way, because I think we can all see some of the problems indulged here. The first of two matters which I wish to address is the Prime Minister's criticism. I do not believe it is up to the President of the Senate to publicly defend the role of the Senate. Any individual senator can do that or senators can do it as a collective. If they want to do it, they can do it.

The second matter relates to questions that involve some reference to Opposition policy. Mr President, I believe you have allowed them in terms of whether the Government will adopt a particular policy, but you have also occasionally tried to bring a Minister back to the main substance of a question. I think those opposite who object are absolute hypocrites, having done it themselves. Sure, the junior woodchuck class that has come in since the coalition was last in government is allowed far more licence in these matters because it has no track record at which we can point. Three of them thought they could get away with that on another occasion, when they came from the House of Representatives, but we caught them out, too, by looking up their record in that place.

The record shows that the bleating over this issue of the other 11 or so who served here over a number of years from 1975 through to 1983 is nothing more than hypocrisy. They were in like Flynn when they had the chance on the government back bench from 1975 to 1983. I do not believe they have been converted on this issue. I would like to think that is the case, but I do not think it is. Mr President, I commend you for bringing down these rulings.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I wish to speak briefly on these documents. I really rise to speak to the ruling that you put down—`confirmed' might be another way of expressing it—on motions for suspension of Standing Orders. Before commenting on that, I should say that it is still the view of honourable senators on this side that the President does have a responsibility out of his office to uphold the reputation of this place, because the standing of this place is vitally important within the democratic process in Australia. When the institution is attacked, as it was by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), we expect a President, no matter which side of the Parliament the President comes from, to take some action. That matter has been debated, and I do not know whether it will progress any further than that.

para.tab: The second issue is the abuse of Standing Orders by Ministers in addressing Opposition policy during Question Time. I think the point that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has failed to appreciate is that occasionally when we were in government we asked such questions and occasionally they were objected to, but we did not subject the Opposition to the continual tactic of a whole stream of questions on Opposition policy. This Government and these Ministers have abused the Standing Orders by developing a whole string of questions on Opposition policy as a tactic to be used in literally every Question Time.

The Minister said that we are soft on taking the debate. The problem is that in Question Time we do not have the opportunity to take the debate. We want to debate policy; there has probably been no Opposition in history which has wanted to make political debate on policy and issues like this one. But the Standing Orders do not protect a Minister who wants to abuse his obligation to answer questions relating to the administration of government policy. That is why we have been continually taking points of order and why we will continue to do so. Mr President, we will ask that you keep Ministers within the Standing Orders and, as you say in your statement, that they are not permitted to use the Question Time procedure to debate Opposition policy.

The third issue that I want to mention, which has not really been dealt with in this debate, is the use of the contingent notice of motion in relation to suspending Standing Orders. Mr President, I want to raise it because, with respect, I do not agree with your opinion or your ruling. I do not seek to take the matter to formal dissent, but if I do not mention disagreement at this stage and it occurs again you or a future President may mention the fact that we did not rise to dispute it at the relevant time.

You have said, Mr President, that we have a precedent that, if more than one contingent notice of motion is moved while the Senate is under guillotine, as President you should disallow that because it in effect becomes an abuse of the restraint of the guillotine. I think we accepted that on the last time, somewhat reluctantly. We were even more reluctant, however, to accept it in relation to a senator from a third party because, if you allow one from one side of the chamber to move such a contingent notice, we could not really see any logical argument that would oblige you to disallow it with regard to a third senator.

On this occasion the Senate was not under the constraint of a guillotine. You have said, however, that, because the proceedings of the Senate had been suspended so that the Senate had returned to continue the same debate, you were under that constraint. But I do not see that constraint in the Standing Orders, provided that the motions were moved before the Senate got back into that debate, as they were in the instance that is in question, which was on 12 November. I do not see any limitation in the Standing Orders at all.

On that day, I moved a contingent notice of motion to suspend Standing Orders firstly to seek a Question Time, and that was defeated. Then, on a totally separate matter, I moved suspension of Standing Orders in order that we might condemn the Government for the high level of unemployment. It was a different motion and a positive motion—nothing to do with the suspension for Question Time at all. I cannot see any restriction within the Standing Orders on doing that and I do not think the argument you applied, using the precedent of the guillotine, works either.

It might be that there is a deficiency within the Standing Orders. It might be that this general contingent notice of motion could arguably require some further constraint and I am open to debate and persuasion on those matters, but I do place on record, Mr President, that I think your use of the precedent of the guillotine is an inappropriate precedent because it does not apply to these circumstances. Therefore, there was not the restraint that you believe there was in my moving the second contingent notice of motion in those circumstances.

talk.start.para:
—I know that the debate will continue after dinner, but I want to deal with two statements made by you, Mr President, and the criticism of the Senate by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Senator Ray, who stands there very laid back, talks slowly as though he has all right on his side and is meant to come across as someone who has been very reasonable, indeed is not telling the truth. He said that we were very touchy when the Prime Minister called the Senate unrepresentative swill and that we did not send a message to the House of Representatives. You know, Mr President, that that is not true.
We took the unprecedented step of censuring the Prime Minister, which was passed. Never before in the history of the Senate has that occurred. I do not see how Senator Ray could possibly claim that that was not a message.
—And we sent a message.

—Along with that censure, we sent a message to the Prime Minister. So I can assure those people who have just heard Senator Ray in such a laid-back fashion talking about this, and who think that it all sounded nice and reasonable and that when in government the Opposition certainly behaved in the same fashion, that that is not accurate. The President has just acknowledged that we did indeed send a message to the House of Representatives.

para.tab: Senator Ray also said that we had a new gimmick of holding up headlines. Mr President, again your memory will go back to Senator McLaren. You will remember the occasion, I am quite sure, when he held up a headline that was completely unparliamentary. And you will remember that when he was in opposition he got away with that because the President of the Senate at that stage was one of our lot and let him get away with it.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I would like to comment briefly on something you said; that is, it is not your job to defend the Senate. If it is not your job, whose is it? The job of the head of the family is to defend members of the family, whether they are right or wrong.

para.tab: The main reason for my rising is that, during his delivery, Senator Ray made a slighting remark about the President of the upper House in Western Australia, Clive Griffiths. He said that the upper House of Western Australia was hardly a democratic House. By way of implication, I took that to mean that the upper House is not elected by a one man, one vote system. —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 7 of 1992-93,
Efficiency audit—saving time and money with common-use contracts
.

speech.speaker: Parer Sen W.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: Briefly, the Auditor-General, as usual, has done an excellent job, considering his lack of resources. I think one of the outstanding features of the Auditor-General, and what most of us who are interested in the efficient operation of government look forward to, is the efficiency audits of the Auditor-General.

para.tab: The Government—and it is something that has generally received bipartisan support—has moved to having a financial management improvement program; in other words, let the managers manage. My overall view—and I say this simply from the experience of having also worked fairly substantially in the private sector in this area—is that one of the most exacting chores of any government or the private sector is the purchasing function. It is something that has basically been underrated in Australia.

It is not unusual to hear the comment—and I do not say this as any form of denigration; I say it because I believe that the profile of purchasing people should be lifted—`He is only a purchasing officer'. I have heard that said in both the private and public sectors, yet the total purchasing of the Government in Australia is about $10 billion, plus or minus 10 per cent. In other words, an improvement in, or a loss of, efficiency of 10 per cent represents $1 billion. So purchasing should be taken very seriously.

Purchasing attracts an incredibly high profile in Japan. Over the past 20 or 30 years, Japan has developed from a country that was devastated by war to the leading economic country in the world today. It had no resources to develop, simply its people and its work ethic. Naturally, one of the most important functions in Japan is to be able to purchase materials, commodities and whatever is needed to fuel its industrial machine. There are many lessons to be learned from the Japanese, because they attribute a very high status to those people involved in the purchasing function. I only point out that overview because, having experienced it and learnt from it, I have to say that the rest of the world could take a leaf out of their book.

With the financial management improvement program and letting the managers manage has come a diversification of the purchasing function to the extent that, as has been pointed out by the Auditor-General, throughout Australia today, within the Commonwealth there are—and apparently the figure is not entirely known—between 13,000 and 20,000 people organising purchasing for the Commonwealth. That is an enormous figure, particularly considering that purchasing is a very specialist function.

Purchasing is an area that is not only specialist but is also open to corruption because of the large amount of money involved. We have all heard over the years—I am not particularly pointing to recent years—anecdotal stories of people being entertained and specifications being written for a particular product. No doubt the company selling the product would look on that as a selling function, but one wonders about the efficiency of the purchasing process.

The Auditor-General pointed out that collective purchasing can be harnessed effectively by using what is called common-use contracts, which are estimated to save the Commonwealth about $60m. But offset against that is the cost of the staffing level of the 13,000 to 20,000 people throughout the various departments, which has been estimated by the Auditor-General to be $56m. That is an incredibly high figure for a purchasing function.

Returning to my earlier comment, it seems to me that, with something as critical as purchasing and with all the requirements of all the various departments, we should have a good look at people such as the Japanese, who are the experts in this field. I believe that there should be a centralised coordination role. I do not mean having a small handful of purchasing officers who turn into little Hitlers—these people must be well aware of what their customers require—but there should be some overview involved with the purchasing function.

In the past, this was a major part of the Department of Administrative Services, but with the FMIP program it has moved out into the various departments. I suppose it could be argued that this should either be done properly or it should not be done at all. But, again referring to the efficiency of the Japanese, it is worth looking at.

The other point made by the Auditor-General is that some 13,000 of these people hold Australian government credit cards. Only 35 per cent of them have any purchasing training whatsoever. I think this is fraught with danger. I do not say this in any political sense whatsoever; I say it in a straight management sense. It should be something that is very carefully looked at.

The Auditor-General makes 19 recommendations in his report. I will not refer to them all; I will just touch on a few. In respect of common-use contracts, the report talks about giving more time to complex common-use contracts and undertaking more detailed planning. On the face of it, common-use contracts have some appeal but, in practice—and from the discussions I have had with suppliers to the Government—it seems to me that there is a lot of avenue for improvement.

One of the problems with common-use contracts is that, just because a contractor is successful in getting on the list, it does not mean that he will be successful in selling any goods. I believe that the various departments should be more detailed in their specific budget requirements for the items that are purchased under common-use contracts; otherwise there is no incentive for them to be accurate. They can pull a figure out of the air, put it on the list, it gets accumulated, the department goes out for a common-use contract and that then becomes the basis on which departments deal with people who have made the list. That is one side of the coin.

On the other side of the coin there are those people who in the main try to tender in a way that gets them on the list. In other words, by no means do they offer their lowest price because by doing so they would be giving their opposition the inside running as to what prices they were quoting. I suppose, from the Commonwealth point of view, that has some

speech.para: merit because they know they can bargain down a bit, provided that the people in the other departments doing the purchasing know what they are doing. I think that is the important thing about it.

para.tab: I notice that the Audit Office recommends that DAS discuss with the Department of Finance the possibility of obtaining funding under community service obligations for those common-use contracts that appear to come under that category. If the common-use contracts with the 2 per cent commission that is paid are properly done and the various departments purchase under the common-use contracts, there should be no need to go back to the Budget and get the taxpayer to pay. In fact, there should be sufficient profit generated from those items of common-use contracts that do not fall under the category of community service obligations to pay for the running of the purchasing section of DAS.
The Audit Office's recommendation No. 14 states:

speech.para:
ANAO
recommends
that departments review the delegations given to officers to purchase on behalf of the department, with a view to restricting the number of such officers to those with a need to purchase and an adequate knowledge of Commonwealth purchasing requirements.

That just reinforces what I said earlier. It does not matter where one is, in which sector of the community, good purchasing people are a scarce community. If a department is lucky enough to have them, it should nurture them and encourage them. Not only are they a scarce commodity in any part of society, but also they can be very much involved in saving the government, and thus the taxpayer, an awful lot of money.

para.tab: As I said, I did not intend to speak long on this report. There are things that have to be confronted. I know an experiment has occurred within the Government. There have been massive changes. Generally, we have been supportive of them. But a lot more attention should be given to purchasing. As I said earlier, the Auditor-General has done an excellent job. He has highlighted areas that should be addressed by any government that is in control of such a massive purchasing function at the taxpayers' expense.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

RESPONSE BY MR D.E. HENNESSY AGREED TO BY MR HENNESSY AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(b) OF THE SENATE OF 25 FEBRUARY 1988

On 3 November 1992, Senator Watson, during the adjournment debate, made reference to evidence given to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on 21 March 1992 by a Mr Trevor Hennessy, Director, Queensland Government Superannuation Office. In the course of his speech he suggested that the Committee might have been "misled by this witness".
I presume the Senator intended to refer to the evidence I (Dale Edward Hennessy), Director of the Queensland Government Superannuation Office, gave on 21 February 1992.
As reflected in the Hansard of the Committee Hearings on 21 February 1992 in Brisbane, I stated-

"Our Government funds are fully funded, both from the employee and the employer perspective, and the funding is kept up-to-date. Both the employee and employer funds and contributions are assessed by the State actuary every three years.

This statement reflects, and was meant to reflect, that the superannuation schemes operated by the Queensland Government are fully funded in accordance with the recommendations of actuaries and, where applicable, the governing legislation. Whilst Senator Watson has taken exception with the funding of the Crown share of the benefits of certain of the Queensland Government's defined benefit schemes being in the Consolidated Fund, in my advice to the Committee I did not at any stage advise that this funding was held in a superannuation trust fund. The situation is clearly set out in my Office's annual report and, indeed, the Third Report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, titled "Super and the Financial System" acknowledged that the funding of the employer component of the Queensland Government's superannuation liabilities is held "in consolidated revenue" (Note (e) to Table 5, p.25).
From information available to me, including the report on the latest actuarial investigation of the Crown superannuation funding, I have no reason to believe I misled the Committee.
D.E. Hennessy
Director
Government Superannuation Office (Qld)

talk.start.para: —As previously indicated to the Senate, in matters of this nature the Committee does not judge the truth or otherwise of statements made by honourable senators or persons but, rather, it ensures that a person's submission, and ultimately the response recommended by the Committee, accord with the criteria set out in Privilege Resolution 5. talk.start.para: —I rise to respond to the tabling by Senator Teague of the thirty-ninth report of the Senate Committee of Privileges. This document was forwarded to the President and then on to the Chairman of the Privileges Committee, under the provisions of the Parliamentary Privilege Resolution, by the Director of the Queensland Superannuation Office, Mr Dale E. Hennessy.

para.tab: I wish to point out that this Senate provides a unique opportunity for people outside this chamber who have been referred to or named by senators to respond. Mr Hennessy has afforded himself the opportunity provided by this Senate Privilege Resolution of so responding and the matter is currently before the Senate. In fact, the statements by the Director and his Treasurer, Mr De Lacy, actually make very interesting reading. In that response he writes:

speech.para: . . . I did not at any stage advise that this funding was held in a superannuation trust fund.

By way of background, let me explain: Mr Hennessy was a witness to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and, in his presentation, he indicated that the Queensland superannuation funds were fully funded. It was not a question of whether the funds were a trust fund. But there is an expectation that senior members of the bureaucracy, not only of this Commonwealth Government, but also of the State governments, understand fully the terminology that they use and apply. In his wording and in his presentation, the impression was conveyed that those superannuation moneys were fully funded. In so doing, the Queensland Government—Mr De Lacy, the Treasurer, and indirectly Mr Hennessy—was given a great deal of credit in the media and elsewhere for something that is in fact not quite right. It is true that he may have misunderstood the terminology; that is indeed unfortunate. But in this response he did not seek to make that particular point.

para.tab: This ability for members of the public, including public servants, to respond in this manner is a very important privilege. In fact, it is a privilege that not even the House of Commons provides to outside people. It is about time that the Director of the Queensland Government Superannuation Office, Mr Hennessy, and Mr De Lacy, who reported extensively, criticising me in the Queensland Parliament—I note that I do not have the same right of response in the Queensland Parliament as Mr Hennessy has of responding here, so I take this opportunity of furthering the point I wish to make—recognised that Queensland, along with the Commonwealth and other States, has superannuation debt. It is about time the Queensland Government recognised that it has superannuation debt too. The statements acknowledge `the funding of the Crown share of the benefits of certain of the Queensland Government's defined benefits fund being in the Consolidated Fund'—honourable senators should note the words `Consolidated Fund'—and distinguish between this arrangement and having funding through a trust fund.

It is all very well for Mr Hennessy to say, `I did not say that I had it in a trust fund', but the point is that a consolidated fund is not a trust fund, and that is the point I have been making all the way along the line. This is an important clarification which I have been seeking. It adds in a very significant way to the evidence which was given by the Director when he appeared before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation during its Brisbane hearings earlier this year. The budget practices outlined in the submission to the President are not unusual; in fact, the submission reveals to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation that Queensland funds its obligations in employee superannuation on an emerging cost basis—just as the Commonwealth and all the other States do.

It is interesting that, subsequently, Mr De Lacy actually acknowledged this in a very indirect way in his lengthy rebuttal of my speech in the Queensland Parliament. What concerns me is the fact that they—particularly Mr De Lacy—still continue to believe that this is full funding when it is not. What is full funding? Full funding involves setting assets aside to cover liabilities as they emerge on a regular basis, not as they emerge at the end of a period when a person is about to retire, or something like that.

I will put it simply, by way of example. If the Queensland Government has 10 employees who are all entitled to 10 per cent employer contribution for one year, and if each had a salary of $30,000, the Government would need to set aside 10 per cent of $30,000 times 10 employees, which would

speech.para: equal $30,000 a year. This is what happens in a number of statutory or quasi government superannuation schemes, for example, Qantas employees, Telecom and the Australian National University, but it does not happen in Queensland, which is fair enough, and it does not happen in the Commonwealth, and we acknowledge that point. But the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation singled them out for special comment because of the misleading evidence they gave to the Committee. What happens in Queensland is a mix of obfuscation and round robin accounting.

para.tab: Let us take as an example two big schemes in Queensland: the State Public Sector Superannuation Fund and the Government Officers Superannuation Fund. According to the 1992 reports, which we have here, the first, the State Public Sector Superannuation Fund, had an opening balance of $142,000 on 30 June 1992, estimated receipts of $203,303,000, and—surprise, surprise—outgoings of $203,303,000. In other words, it has apparently received from the portfolio departments an amount equal to its emerging liability, and transferred to the Queensland Government Superannuation Office an identical amount equal to the emerging cost of retirees both past and present, fully funded. At the year's end, there will be a balance in the fund of $142,000.

The other scheme, the Government Officers Superannuation Fund, appears to have operated under a similar scheme of accounting. It has an opening balance of $104,000. It has $118,802,000 in receipts and—surprise, surprise—$118,802,000 payments to retirees. I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
pages 30 and 31 of the document from which I have quoted, the Queensland State Budget 1992, Budget Paper No. 2, Estimates of Receipts and Expenditure.
Leave granted.

speech.para: TRUST AND SPECIAL FUNDS 1992-93
ESTIMATES OF RECEIPTS AND EXPENDITURE
[TABLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 3800]

talk.start.para: —The total public sector superannuation debt in Queensland for 1992-93, according to the emerging cost principle, would be: for the Government Officers Superannuation Fund, approximately $119m; the Parliamentary Superannuation Fund, $3m; the Police Superannuation Fund—which, incidentally, is $277m in the red—$82m; the State Public Sector Superannuation Fund $203m; and the State Service Superannuation Fund $73m. That is a total of $479m.

para.tab: As honourable senators will note from pages 31 and 32 of the document, the total of all cash balances in the five superannuation funds is approximately $2.5m. The question that I ask is: is this sufficient to cover the superannuation debt? Only an actuary could say, but my hunch is that it falls short—not by thousands or hundreds of thousands, but by millions of dollars of unfunded liabilities.

However, the superannuation debt provision could have been made in some other section of the account, or a possible parking space for superannuation debt provisions—and it could be, but we do not know. For example, the Queensland Treasury Corporation Fund, I think, has a balance of $12.7m as at 30 June 1992. Unfortunately, this amount is not disaggregated and, in the scheme of things, is small in relation to superannuation debt, so it is unlikely that it covers the emerging debt burden.

Assuming that Queensland Public Service employee numbers and demographic characteristics remain at a steady rate, if the emerging Consolidated Revenue were of the order of $479m in the next 10 years, then the unfunded liability would be $4.79 billion. For 20 years, it would be more than $9 billion. This is the logic on which the other States, having made a true actuarial assessment, informed the Committee. I must say that it does worry me that the report brings in the words, `the actuary has examined this'. This raises some pretty serious issues. Perhaps we should be having a word with the Commonwealth Actuary.

talk.start.para: —`In accordance with the recommendations of actuaries'.

—I note the point that is made. The point is that I cannot see any actuary really giving credence to a fully funded superannuation fund. It is a particular quirk of accounting that is adopted in Queensland, but I think it is a quirk that is not satisfactory in the current debate in relation to unfunded superannuation liabilities. It is one that has to be acknowledged and taken note of. I believe that my statements on this matter during the last few weeks have exploded the myth that has been perpetrated and that Queensland, like all the other States, has superannuation funding liabilities, and the sooner the Queensland Government acknowledges this, the better.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.
