talk.start.para: —The Opposition will be supporting the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill 1992. The Bill amends the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991 to include as a schedule to the Act the agreement made on 11 May this year between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and a number of Premiers and Chief Ministers at a conference in Adelaide.

para.tab: The National Road Transport Commission was established early this year following legislation passed through the Parliament in December 1991. The present functions of the Commission are related to obtaining uniformity in road transport. It currently applies only to those vehicles over 4.5 tonnes, also known as heavy vehicles. Its functions include seeking uniform legislation, road charges and road user charges, principles for determining road charges and road user charges, and guidelines for the preparation of regulatory impact statements.

The additional functions that have been conferred on the Commission by the agreement of 11 May include the extension of the Commission's functions to include light vehicles, those being vehicles below 4.5 tonnes. It also includes: the assembly and publication of information on road related charges applying to light vehicles; assistance in developing indicators for assessing the performance of the road system and matters relating to that performance, such as evaluating the efficiency of our road constructions; the assembly and publication of information on road safety; and the monitoring of the use of alternative fuels.

The functions of the Commission will not, however, be extended to road charges or economic regulation of the transport industry for light vehicles. Clearly, this Labor Government does not want to lose any of its substantial taxing power over motorists. The Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) has said that the Commission has earned a reputation as a fair and independent body through its formal and informal consultation with both government and industry. Its recommendations on heavy vehicle charges have been received and approved by the ministerial council. The charging determinations have received support from a convincing majority of States. They have also received overwhelming support from the road transport industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Transport Workers Union.

However, the Government does not feel that this fair and independent body's functions should extend to determining road charges and road user charges into this area of the road transport industry. The Government is clearly not serious about getting as close as possible to the ideal charging system. In the Government's drive to achieve a fair and efficient road transport system, it is not prepared to sacrifice its taxing powers over the road users. Because of this, the charging scheme is not the best that it could possibly be, due to the constraints placed on the Commission by the Labor Government. This clearly shows that the Government is not serious about getting the costs of road transport down. These costs continue to be a burden on business. That is why we address that point with the benefits highlighted under the Fightback package.

It is worth noting that in its road user charge the Government has highlighted the fact that the 18c a litre excise is a notional charge, which basically means that it does not have anything whatsoever to do with road construction or road funding in general. It is merely another tactic of the Government to use the road users of Australia as milch cows. The Liberal and National parties believe that the road user charges should go to road funding. This is not the case with the Government's 18c a litre notional charge; it is clearly another general revenue tax to go to Consolidated Revenue.

In addition, the Government has said it will continue to index the tax component. That means it could increase the notional charge within a few years and continue to use road users as a source of general revenue. The Labor Government is retaining the option to increase this notional charge at its discretion. This could mean that the 18c could become 24c or could even go to 30c a litre. If current trends are any indicator, only 5c of that would continue to go to road funding. The Government's record on this issue is nothing short of appalling. As long as this continues, an adequate level of road funding cannot be assured, but an unnecessary burden on the road users to fund the Government's other various expenditures can be.

On the subject of road funding, the Government's record has been much less than commendable. The roads are a major infrastructure asset of our country, especially considering the size of our country and its population spread. This asset requires constant maintenance and upgrading, but the Government's commitment has been less than satisfactory. For all the Government's years in office, excepting 1992-93 since it is an election year and the Government needs votes, road funding has fallen dramatically in real terms.

This funding has fallen despite drastic increases of around 150 per cent in the revenue gained from fuel excise. The $2 billion roads funding program for this year only takes it back to where we were 10 years ago. However, fuel excise revenue will be around $7,300m this year. This means only 27 per cent of the fuel excise that road users pay goes to road funding. This compares with 66.6 per cent of the revenue collected from fuel excise that went to road funding in 1983-84, the year before the Labor Government came into office.

For a decade now the Government has neglected to provide sufficient funds for the maintenance and upgrading of the Australian road network. The motorists of Australia will not be fooled by the latest increase in road funding by the Government. If Labor has the chance, it will again cut funding, as it has in the past. It is quite apparent that this Government does not care much about roads, except when it comes to an election year. It has allowed roads to deteriorate over the last decade. It cares about roads only in an election year—and it does not look as though it will win this election anyway.

By not extending the functions of the NRTC to include the determination of charges for light vehicles, the Government has assured us that it will continue taxing motorists blind, regardless of whether those revenues go towards road funding. The coalition has made it clear that it will maintain the current level of road funding and that it will be funded from Consolidated Revenue. The whole Fightback package, of course, is totally funded, which cannot be said for the One Nation statement.

The NRTC has attempted to do its best to work around the constraints that have been put on it by the Government. The Liberal and National parties were concerned when the legislation was first introduced that the Commission was not given a wide enough range of powers to consider existing taxes that road transport pays. The Commission has basically gone ahead and done some of these things, to the vindication of the coalition, and looked at taxation issues anyway. We are pleased to see that the NRTC will have the power to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of road authorities. This was something that the Liberal and National parties were concerned about right from the beginning.

The other concern was that the Commission be able to assess the taxes and road related charges that have applied to light vehicles. This would allow for a more uniform and ideal charging system to be applied to this area of the industry. However, the Government has continued to withhold this power from the Commission and constrains its effectiveness in this area. Many commentators—in particular, the Australian Automobile Association—have argued with the coalition that light vehicles be included under the Commission's brief because it is difficult to determine a sensible and uniform charging system as long as the light vehicles are excluded. The Automobile Association supports the legislation but again, as with the Liberal and National parties, is disappointed that the constraints on the Commission remain in place. Clearly, the coalition has led the debate on this issue that has brought about the legislation before us today.

The coalition will take further steps towards providing fair and equitable taxes for Australian motorists. For too long now, the road users of this country have been milked for taxes to pay for the Government's failed economic policies. The coalition intends to abolish seven other taxes on business in addition to the general revenue tax that the Government highlights as a notional charge—in other words, the fuel excise levy goes. Three other taxes that impact directly on the road transport industry and motorists are the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and customs duty. This will save the road transport industry hundreds of millions of dollars a year. Furthermore, in the first term of a coalition government, there will be no new road user charges.

This point has to be made clearly, because people such as the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) have been running around the place making all sorts of claims about this hidden tax that was to come out. The shadow Minister, Mr Hawker, has made an announcement that there will be no new road user charges in the first term of a coalition government. A typical road transport operator will save about $44,000 a year under the coalition compared with Labor.

When one considers its impact on the cost of goods, bearing in mind the size of Australia and the fact that we do transport goods and services over vast distances, one can realise the effect this will have on the cost of goods before they reach the retailer or the consumer. A six-axle articulated truck will pay $4,000 per year in registration—and that is all. There will be no federal fuel tax on business and there is no GST on registration.

I believe that this is the critical difference between the tired, worn out and failed Labor Government which obviously has no policies whatsoever and the coalition with its Fightback plan. The coalition has a policy, as outlined in Fightback, to remove the fuel excise levy of 26c a litre. The reduction of 26c a litre will apply to every business across this nation. It represents a major reduction in business costs which will have profound multiplier effects, making business more competitive and, more importantly, leading to the creation of thousands of jobs.

Let us take, for example, a simple thing such as a loaf of bread. The fertiliser delivered to the farmer will be in trucks which are sales tax free, driven by petrol which will be excise free. When the farmer's produce is taken to the market, it will be sales tax and fuel excise free. The primary product will be processed in factories where payroll tax will have been removed and by machinery which will not have import duty on it. When the final product is distributed it will be done sales tax and excise tax free to the retail outlet. The cascading effect of these savings will produce goods which are lower in cost, benefiting not only the exporters but, equally as important, those who compete against imports on the domestic market. If anything has driven the importance of that home, it is the figure released today of some $2 billion of current account deficit.

I believe that there is no-one in society who does not agree that if we are to get this nation back on track, we must address the structural problems that have caused the economic crisis we are in. The only way to do that is to remove those taxes that those who supply goods into the Australian market do not pay but which our manufacturers, our secondary and tertiary processors, do have to pay. It is like putting them in a race with hobbles on to expect them to compete with importers. It is not a matter of goods coming from countries where there is cheap labour; it is a matter of our manufacturers and producers having to pay these input costs, under this Government, which make it impossible for them to compete on the domestic market. That is the major reason and the major basis for the Fightback program, and a major part of it is the total removal of the fuel excise.

That, briefly, is the coalition policy. If the Government has a policy, I believe that this is an opportunity to spell it out to the people of Australia who have suffered so much under `the recession we had to have'. As I mentioned earlier today in this chamber in the debate on the urgency motion, it appears that the only thing the Government is offering is more of the same, and that is something that cannot be tolerated, as it would be a disaster for this country.

talk.start.para: —In the introduction to my speech on this particular piece of legislation, I might just pick up on two things which Senator Parer has just said. Firstly, he mentioned the taxes which would be reduced under Fightback and, in particular, the payroll tax. Of course, Senator Parer would know very well, just as every other senator knows, that payroll tax is a State tax. I understand that Mr Kennett is already on record as saying that, given the plight of Victoria, he would be very loath to remove the payroll tax; and I would be very surprised if South Australia was interested in removing the payroll tax because of the parlous state of its economy.

para.tab: The second issue that Senator Parer was talking about was Australia's lack of competitiveness in relation to other countries because of the excise on petrol. I think Senator Parer should know as well as any other senator that of all the OECD countries, Australia has the third lowest petrol price and pays the second lowest rate of excise. I find it rather difficult to follow Senator Parer's logic if he suggests that that is a cause of our lack of competitiveness with respect to the other OECD countries.

The National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill, which we are debating tonight, ratifies the Commonwealth-State agreement on light vehicles—not heavy vehicles—made on 11 May this year. The light vehicles agreement complements the heavy vehicles agreement made last year which instigated the development of nationally uniform road laws for vehicles over 4 1/2 tonnes. The light vehicles agreement recognises that there cannot be nationally uniform road laws for some vehicles and not for others. Again, this marks the difference between the Australian Democrats and the Opposition which wants to refer everything back to State legislation. We recognise that in this area it is very useful to have national roads laws, national registration and a single system by which these things are regulated right across the country.

However, both these agreements—particularly the light vehicles agreement—ratified in this Bill fall far short of a truly national road law system. The heavy vehicles agreement has already demonstrated the inherent flaws in the new federalism process. National uniformity can only be gained by the enactment by the States and the Commonwealth of identical legislation covering their respective jurisdictions. If one government opts out, uniformity is lost. I stress again that that indicates the inherent flaw in the federalism line being pursued by both the Government and the Opposition in this respect.

We have already seen New South Wales refuse to accept the National Road Transport Commission's recommended heavy vehicle charges and announce that it will charge up to $3,000 extra for registration fees. The light vehicles agreement also requires the enactment of identical legislation in all jurisdictions to achieve national uniformity. However, it is a much less ambitious agreement than its heavy vehicles counterpart. It stops short of establishing a national car registration scheme, and it completely fails to introduce pay-as-you-drive road use charges for car owners, both of which would be absolutely in line with the declared market philosophy of the Opposition, but one which it fails to recognise.

This is despite the clear recommendations of the Interstate Commission in its 1990 report on road use charges and vehicle registration that there should be a national registration scheme with registration fees paid by way of increased petrol excise. It is despite more recent hints of support for such a system by the Minister for Resources, Mr Alan Griffiths, and also by the NRMA in New South Wales. No doubt the failure of the light vehicles agreement to lay the groundwork for a pay-as-you-drive national car registration scheme is due in no small part to the intransigence of the States and Territories. However, the Commonwealth is also responsible. It has failed totally to make a strong and public case for a measure which is squarely in the interests of Australia and Australians.

The Democrats, in our Getting to Work program of economic reform, have costed a pay-as-you-drive—I stress that—national car registration scheme. Under our scheme the States would scrap car registration fees and compulsory third party insurance premiums. The same revenue—and I stress that, because it has been misrepresented repeatedly by the Opposition—which relates to car registration and third party insurance, of about $2.9 billion per year would be collected instead through the petrol pump.

We estimate that petrol excise would need to rise by 16.5c per litre to provide this $2.9 billion, which would then be channelled back to the States according to the agreed formula. In other words, it would be a completely revenue neutral procedure to do what the Opposition declares is the fundamental basis of its philosophy, namely, user pays—the proper and appropriate allocation of resources, which is at the basis of the market system.

A formula would have to be found to accommodate private insurers in those States, such as New South Wales, in which they are allowed to offer compulsory third party policies. This could take the form of a rebate to those motorists wishing to take out a private policy. Preferably, it would allow private firms to receive a proportional amount of the petrol excise revenue for each motorist that they insure.

The advantages of such a scheme are obvious: drivers would pay road charges which were closely related to their actual road use, unlike the present system where one pays full charges even if one's car stays in the garage all year. Of course, many people buy a relatively larger car than they need because of the occasional use they make of that larger vehicle and are then forced to drive that vehicle all the time for purposes for which a much smaller car would be quite adequate, simply because they cannot afford to have a second smaller car and pay something like $600 to $800 per year in registration and third party insurance and simply leave that car in the garage. Under our proposal, the car which stayed in the garage would cost nothing while it was there; it would only cost something while it was being used.

It would also be impossible to evade registration and compulsory third party insurance charges. Every time one fills the tank, one pays. There would be no financial incentive to leave one's car unregistered. There would no longer be any point registering one's car in another State to avoid charges in one's own State because one would save precisely nothing. Instead of being hit with a bill amounting to several hundred dollars once a year, one's payments would be spread out, avoiding the household cash flow crisis which must affect many people who do not have large incomes, such as pensioners and other people who are in less pecunious circumstances.

There would be a greater incentive to conserve petrol by driving less, buying more fuel efficient cars and switching to low emission fuels such as natural gas and LPG or petrol-ethanol blends as they become available. One must observe that the Opposition is already on record as saying that the abolition of petrol excise under its Fightback proposal would make the adoption of LPG completely uneconomical. In that connection one can only observe that Australia is very deficient in fuels from which we make petrol but has large amounts of LPG available.

This conversion to alternative fuels would contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and we are the second or third world's worst in per capita greenhouse emissions. The road toll and the exorbitant cost of road accidents would also be reduced and our future oil import bill would be reduced. I would remind the Opposition that we currently import $3.1 billion worth of petroleum each year and that that amount will rise over time as we become less dependent.

talk.start.para: —How much do we export?

—That is not the point. The point is that, if we used less, we would be better off financially, and anybody with half a brain could see that that would be the situation. If we used less ourselves, we would have more to export, if that is the name of the game. With appropriate compensation schemes, drivers living in rural areas and on the urban fringe could also be protected from this impost.

para.tab: This last point deserves some elaboration. The Democrats believe that no pay-as-you-drive scheme should be introduced until a full social impact study has been performed to identify those motorists who would be unfairly penalised by increased petrol prices and compensation mechanisms put in place. In general, our scheme is fair and it is progressive, not like the regressive schemes of the Opposition.

Older people, young people and women who tend to drive smaller cars and drive shorter distances would be advantaged. Those who buy larger cars and drive greater distances would have to pay for their greater use of fossil fuel, for the pollution that it causes and for the damage occasioned to the roads. In other words, people on low incomes would generally pay less than people on higher incomes and less than they now pay under the fixed fee systems. For example, a pensioner driving a small car 2,000 kilometres per year would pay the equivalent of around $35 through the petrol pump for registration and compulsory third party insurance.

There are several modes of compensation which could be targeted at farmers and those in rural areas and on the urban fringe. For instance, tax rebates similar to those now delivered to farmers and others using diesel fuel; adjusted benefits for social security recipients; or a petroleum products freight subsidisation scheme, which is already in place, which could also be used to reduce petrol prices in remote areas.

Despite the worst efforts of the coalition to portray the scheme of the Democrats as a huge impost on rural people, in reality, rural people would have nothing to fear at all under our proposals. The coalition has made a great play of its proposal to abolish petrol excise and reduce prices by around 19c per litre and has contrasted its policy with ours in the usual irresponsible vote-buying fashion. However, as usual, it has deliberately and cynically misled the public about the true impact of its Fightback proposals. First, the coalition continually fails to acknowledge that we are the only party proposing to abolish all fixed car charges. Our scheme does not impose an additional impost; it replaces two old charges with a more responsible and equitable system.

Secondly, the coalition cannot bring itself to admit that for 70 per cent of Australian families, all in low and middle income brackets, the amount saved on petrol would be more than cancelled out by the overall cut in disposable income which Fightback would produce. What Dr Hewson giveth at the petrol pump, he taketh away in the supermarket. Thirdly, the coalition refuses to admit that its policy would cause a massive increase in petrol use, leading in turn to a blow-out in our oil import bill, increased greenhouse gas emissions and even greater health problems in our cities—a burden which is predominantly carried by Australian children.

While the coalition's policy is a sin of commission, Labor's policy is a sin of omission. It does not really want to encourage greater fuel use, but it has no policies to reduce it either. It is quietly sitting on the fence waiting for disaster to strike. I draw attention to Senator Button's replies to two of my questions last week. In one question I pointed out that 1,500 scientists, including 99 out of 198 living Nobel prize winning scientists, warned that we needed to address as a matter of urgency the problem of greenhouse. Senator Button said in answer to my question that the Government would not change its policy as a result of the urging by those scientists. On the very next day, when I pointed out the rising insurance costs, Senator Button again said that the Government would not change its policy because of rising insurance costs as a consequence of storm damage brought about by greenhouse climate change.

Melbourne University's Professor Bruce Knox has found that over the last 30 years the incidence of asthma-like breathing problems among Melbourne school children has risen from 19 per cent to 46 per cent. Japanese research links asthma attacks with nitrogen oxides—a major component of car exhaust fumes. Other research, by Victoria's Environmental Protection Authority, suggests a link between benzene in exhaust fumes and Melbourne's unusual high incidence of acute myeloid leukemia. One could go on about other trace materials which occur in petrol, something which the Opposition seems to have no care about at all. The Opposition would increase the cost of public transport fares by 15 per cent, reduce the amount of government expenditure on public transport, as a consequence of reduced government expenditure in general, and at the same time reduce the price of petrol—all of which would make the air pollution problems in our major cities absolutely horrific.

On current projections, smog levels in western Sydney are expected to rise by 50 per cent over the next 20 years. How much more will they rise under the coalition's policy? Has the coalition estimated the economic impact? I am sure it has not even begun to make a calculation of the air pollution impact of its changes in fuel prices. Has it run its computer models to predict exactly how many more children would contract respiratory disorders? I believe the answer is no, nor could it care, because it is looking purely at the bare economic indicators of production and consumption.

The coalition does not care about the suffering its policies would cause to our young people and Labor does not care enough to do anything about it either. Only the Democrats care enough to act. According to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, oil production in Australian fields in 2005 will be 20 per below the 1988 demand. Unless we cut demand, the result will be billions of dollar per year spent on imported oil, adding to a debt for which Australians will ultimately pay.

The coalition claims to support a 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2000. Its policy has been reduced to rubble by its plan to abolish petrol excise. Not only would this encourage wasteful driving and the purchase of gas guzzlers; but also it would strongly discourage the development of environmentally friendly alternative transport fuels.

One Australian firm, Manildra Pty Ltd, has married environmental and economic concerns by converting starch mill effluent to ethanol, which it mixes with petrol and diesel in a 10 per cent ethanol blend. The petrol blend is being sold from seven south coast petrol stations and has won high consumer acceptance, while the diesel blend is being trialled in Action buses. Meanwhile, the APACE research team at the University of New South Wales has developed an exciting new technique to turn wood fibres from such sources as plantation thinnings or even woody weeds into ethanol and lignin. So there are many alternatives which could come on-line, all of which would be discouraged by the policies of the Opposition.

Our policy of reducing and shifting car costs, from car ownership to car use, would have a substantial impact on petrol consumption as drivers took the opportunity to save fuel and bank the proceeds. According to the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, the five-year fuel price elasticity for cars is minus 0.66. Against a base price of 70c per litre, this would result in a 15.6 per cent cut in greenhouse gas emissions from car use before the year 2000.

The coalition's policies, by contrast, would cause greenhouse gas emissions from cars to rise by 17.9 per cent. Labor's sit-on-the-fence policies will do nothing one way or the other. Labor has absolutely no intention of reducing our future import bill and our greenhouse gas emissions, and the coalition is hell-bent on increasing them. Only the Democrats intend to fulfil our obligations to ourselves and our children.

—I am interested that Senator Macdonald has come in here very late in the piece and passed a remark like that.

talk.start.para: —Senator Coulter has certainly given the message to the people who live in rural and remote areas of Australia as to what the Australian Democrats think of them—they will increase their fuel by 16.9c a litre.
—Just what they need!

—That is right. Senator Coulter was quick to claim that the Democrats were responsible for getting the inquiry going into the effects of NRTC charging in rural and remote areas of Australia, but perhaps he could explain why his troops almost totally ignored the inquiry. To my knowledge, one Democrat senator turned up at one of the inquiries. They totally ignored the meeting we had today to look at the preliminary report. All they want to do to those areas, in their social engineering process for Australia, is bleed them and give them nothing in return.

para.tab: The main purpose of the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill is to give effect to the light vehicles agreement which came out of the meeting of the heads of government on 11 May 1992. It mainly involves bringing vehicles that are 4 1/2 tonnes or less into the orbit of the NRTC and includes drivers and other road users.
The principal functions that were given to the NRTC when it was set up late last year were to inquire and recommend on a number of matters including:

speech.para: (i)uniform Heavy Vehicle legislation;
(ii)road charges and road use charges;
(iii)principles for determining road charges and road use charges;
(iv)uniform methods of providing information by the States and territories to the Commission;
(v)guidelines for the preparation of regulatory impact statements concerning any proposed road transport legislation;
(vi)options in relation to the future operation of the Commission; and
(vii)Applications Orders (ie, orders by a Minister which would suspend the operation of the applicable road legislation in a particular zone).

Those functions have been around for quite a few months and the Commission's functions are now being extended to include light vehicles, the assembly and publication of information on road related charges applying to light vehicles, assistance in developing indicators for assessing the performance of the road system and matters related to that performance and, most importantly, the assembly and publication of information on road safety and the monitoring of the use of alternate fuels.

para.tab:
As has already been pointed out by Senator Parer, the Opposition is supporting these measures, though I have a few reservations. The NRTC will be given responsibility for the development of light vehicles but will not determine the charges, as has been already pointed out. When the NRTC started on 1 January, it had control over everything other than that and now intends to bring that in. Of course, the standard recommendation on charges does not come in until 1995, even though there are some recommended charges in place.
Under the Fightback package of the coalition in government, there will be no road user charge on that basis until 1 January 1996; of course, it may be on a different basis.

While I support the uniform standards—I have always supported uniform standards in speed limitations or mass limits—I have been hesitant to accept the recommended charges. The reason is—I have listened to industry and users around Australia—that costs, as I have said before, bear heaviest on those in rural and remote areas. These are areas that do not necessarily have the luxury of competition. The roads in those places are far worse than the roads in the metropolitan areas or the areas that are adjacent to them. The freight tonnages vary as loading on both legs of the journey happens in very few cases; mostly, transporters are loaded on only one leg of the journey.

New South Wales is still opposing the charges because it believes that road funding to it will decrease. However, Western Australia is opposing the charges because of its fears about the effect the increases will have on the rural and remote areas. New South Wales is in the unfortunate position of being a corridor State with a lot of traffic, and trucks not registered in that State, using its roads from north to south. I quite understand its concerns, but I appeal to it to look at the idea that, with uniform charging, trucks should come back and be licensed in New South Wales so it will pick up its fair share of registration.

In the case of Western Australia a lot of concessions are available. I have a list here, which I will not go through in my limited time this evening, but I have not seen any specific indication that some of those concessions are going to remain in place, though it is the prerogative of the State governments to determine that, and I am sure that Western Australia will agree in time to the uniform charges and uniform conditions. Western Australia has always agreed to uniform speeds and masses, but not the charges. When it does agree to them, I am sure it will look at the idea of concessions in certain restricted areas. I am the first to say that there are a lot of concessions available that should not necessarily be there. At present, Western Australia has concessions on trucks of up to 18-tonne capacity and on light vehicles used by farmers or in areas adjacent to the farms.

As I said, the coalition supports the Bill. Initially the coalition opposed the measures because of the lack of wide reference powers to consider existing taxes on transport. There is a lack of power to scrutinise the supply of roads. The Government is looking only at the demand-side evidence that road making is inefficient. Many organisations want the NRTC to include light vehicles. The Australian Automobile Association, for instance, wants that and has asked for the NRTC to take over the design rules. It has also asked for increased frequency, probably for safety of road worthiness checks. Some States, including Western Australia, do not have checks on safety and road worthiness regularly. Of course, this agreement does not extend to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989.

Until all parties have passed the legislation, what is the future of the Federal Office of Road Safety? It seems to have an undefined role at the present moment. I believe that it should stay, but it should have an advisory role only.

If I can get back to the NRTC and to reviewing tax and transport, this Government is still dodging the issue. We get red herrings such as there being no database to find out what taxes there are. The former Prime Minister—I read this somewhere as late as tonight—has admitted that road transport was taxed 3 1/2 times more than any other industry, yet the Government does not seem to recognise this fact. I know that the former Prime Minister was prone to saying things off the top of his head, but I do not think even he would have made such an incorrect statement if it were not somewhere near correct. I wish that the NRTC and the Government would stop using as a red herring the fact that there is no database to say that that information is not available.

Under the proposal of the coalition, on coming into government, an inquiry will be conducted into the taxes paid by the road industry, and that will be reflected in the road user charge coming in in 1996. The shadow Minister, Mr David Hawker, is on record as having said this.

We are supporting this legislation. The coalition will lessen the load on the road transport sector before 1996 which is when uniform charges, as recommended by the new committee, will be introduced. Many of the taxes will come off on 1 October 1994, such as the 26c per litre. I believe that the big winners will then be road transport and, of course, those people that use its services.

talk.start.para: —I rise in this debate to support the very worthwhile and clear comments of my colleagues Senator Parer and Senator Panizza in this debate. It is always a pleasure to follow people such as Senator Parer and Senator Panizza, who have a real understanding of what life is all about, particularly life out there in the real world—the world which produces Australia's wealth and which is made up of real people, doing real jobs and creating real wealth for Australia.

para.tab: As I was listening to the debate—not very intently after Senator Parer sat down—I heard what I assumed was someone from the Labor Party speaking. I thought that it was just some more of the old class-conscious, extreme, left wing claptrap that we are used to expecting from the Labor Party. It went on, and I realised that it was not someone from the Labor Party; it was the dulcet tones of the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter.

Senator Coulter went on with stuff that I think even the Labor Party gave away some 20 years ago: the sort of divisive arguments about ideological claptrap—that is all it can be called—such as separating the city from the country, which used to imprison the Labor Government; it still does to a certain extent. Mr Keating was most intent on introducing a consumption tax in 1985. Of course he was captured and imprisoned by the left wing of his Party; he was not allowed to do it. He now has to suffer the hypocrisy of speaking against the proposal for a consumption tax which he so roundly supported just a few years ago. But I have diverted from my comments on Senator Coulter's quite unbelievable contribution to this debate.

Senator Coulter made a speech full of inaccuracies. I intend to highlight just a few of them before getting on with what I want to say about the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill. Firstly, Senator Coulter suggested that Mr Kennett was on record as saying that he would not remove payroll tax because Mr Kennett needed the money. It just shows how little of our proposal Senator Coulter has understood. He has not bothered to read it or, if he has, he simply cannot understand it.

Our proposals regarding payroll tax are very clear; even a six-year-old could understand them. We intend to say to the States, `If you abolish payroll tax, we will compensate you for it'. If a State Government does not want to remove payroll tax—and we will not force it to—it will not get compensated. Of course, every State Government will abolish its payroll tax very willingly. Out of the funds that we will collect—and it is all costed and accounted for in Fightback—we will compensate the States for that.

Senator Coulter spoke at some length about OECD countries. He forgot to mention that, of all OECD countries, Australia probably has the biggest need for road transport and vehicles that use fuel, because Australia is such a vast and widely spread country. Senator Coulter seemed to quite conveniently overlook that point.

He then went on with a quite amazing `pay as you drive' proposal. He said that the Australian Democrats would abolish all taxes on vehicles, driving, fuel, registration, road user charges, et cetera, but collect it from the petrol pump by charging an additional 16.5c per litre on top of existing petrol costs. That is how the Democrats will supposedly fund road maintenance.

I do not have any personal ill will towards Senator Coulter, so on that basis I will give him a warning: please never come up my way. I know that he has been to Queensland peddling some of his quite idiotic policies on other issues, but now that he has said that he wants the people of North Queensland to pay an extra 16.5c per litre for their fuel, I say to him, `Please do not go there, the people of Queensland will lynch you'.

If Senator Coulter goes to Mount Isa and tells the locals that he will add 16.5c per litre on top of what they are already paying for fuel—as opposed to our proposal to remove 26c from what they are currently paying—they will lynch him. I do not bear him any personal ill will, so I send him the warning: please do not go to Queensland again.

It is okay if, like Senator Coulter, one lives in Adelaide. To go from one point to another anywhere in Adelaide is 20 or 30 kilometres at the most. If people want to see a specialist, go to the theatre or some of the major shops to do some shopping, they have to drive 20 to 30 kilometres at the most to get there, and it does not cost much in petrol.

talk.start.para: —And you can get public transport.

—And they can get public transport. But people who live in Hughenden, Ayr—where I live—Karumba, Bowen, Collinsville, Longreach or any of those sorts of places who want to see a specialist have to get in the car and drive for two, three or four hours and cover 200, 300, 400 or 500 kilometres.

para.tab: If one is paying the price for fuel that one currently pays, plus an extra 16.5c per litre, it will cost an enormous amount just to take one's kids to see the specialist, to school, to the theatre, to the ballet or to some other cultural performance. All those things which are a natural part of life where I, Senator Panizza and other people in remote and rural Australia live would cost a lot extra if Senator Coulter's proposals were ever to be implemented.

I know that no-one will ever take anything that Senator Coulter says seriously. My only fear, and the reason I raise it, is that the more he goes on with that sort of rubbish the more the Government—which gets anxious for money; it has a $50 billion hole to make up in its Budget over the next few years—is encouraged to look at those sorts of things. Already this Government collects 26c a litre in tax on fuel. Only about 6c or 7c a litre of that goes towards roads. The balance—about 20c a litre—is a pure tax.

All of the people where I live and where Senator Panizza lives pay their income tax, the same as everyone else in Australia. On top of that, we pay an extra 20c for every litre of fuel we use that goes to the general revenue. That is okay if we live in Brisbane or Adelaide and we can use public transport or drive just 10 kilometres to go to the specialist, to department stores or to the theatre—to do the normal things of life. But when one has to drive 200, 300 or 400 kilometres to do that, it is a real impost. It is very unfair and discriminatory against country dwellers that they have to pay 20c a litre for the general revenue—a 20c a litre tax—just for the privilege of living in those areas. Senator Coulter would have them pay an extra 16.5c a litre on top of that. I say to Senator Coulter: please do not go to North Queensland or to Western Australia because the people there will lynch you if you do.

Senator Coulter then went on to make some silly comment about LPG. We are not putting up the price of LPG. We are not adding any taxes to it. We are leaving it exactly as it is. We are simply removing the fuel excise from petrol and diesel. Senator Coulter then made what can only described as some typical Democrat statements. He started to equivocate, saying, `We are going to have this 16.5c a litre tax, but we will probably have a social impact study as well'—whatever that means; it is one of these Public Service, left-wing terms—`and if it impacts upon country people, we will probably do something; we will probably give some tax rebates or compensate them for it in some way'. He does not tell us how. He does not say what would then happen to the hole in the Budget that that sort of thing would create.

As I said, no-one takes any notice of what the Democrats say. My only fear is that, by raising these sorts of things, this Government—desperate for money as it is—is likely to take up those sorts of issues knowing that it will get the support of the Australian Democrats. I have almost taken up my time pointing out just some of the inaccuracies and stupidities of the issues that Senator Coulter raised.

I very quickly wish to indicate, as my colleagues have done, that we are supporting this Bill for the reasons that Senator Parer has mentioned. In spite of the continuing campaign of misinformation being carried on by the Labor Party, particularly the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in this case, we will not be introducing a road user charge in the first term of the Hewson government. We will be slashing transport costs completely. The Liberal and National parties have no new road user charges. A typical road transport operator will save about $44,000 per year under the coalition compared with what is currently paid. This will feed into cheaper prices.

In my role as the Liberal-National coalition spokesman for local government, I must say that that is a factor that local governments are very keen on. They understand that all of their trucking contractors, and there are a lot of those in local government, will be able to provide councils with much cheaper tender costs because all of those taxes that the truckie-type contractors currently pay—the fuel tax and the sales tax at 20 per cent on their trucks, tyres, windscreens and spare parts—will go. For the big fellows, the payroll tax will go, the training guarantee levy will go, and the superannuation guarantee will be pegged. So contractors will have substantially reduced costs: in the instance I cited, $44,000 for a 500 horsepower articulated rig. With that sort of saving, they can make real reductions in the cost of their businesses and a reduction in the tenders that they offer to councils and other people.

Under the coalition there will be real benefits and real cost reductions for the transport industry. Those benefits and cost reductions will of course flow on to our exports and our means of production. It is a great policy and something that will give a much needed boost to the trucking industry and to those sectors of the Australian economy which produce. In contrast, the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats want only to penalise the trucking industry and the productive sector and use them as a milch cow. The coalition is doing something about it. I am very pleased to be part of a team which has put forward such a far-sighted policy. I support the Bill.

talk.start.para: —As my colleague Senator Macdonald has explained in detail in the last few moments, this evening we have seen the Australian Democrats in their true colours as far as their policies are concerned. Over the last few months we have seen various Democrat senators running around rural South Australia feigning sympathy for rural people; feigning sympathy for farmers who currently find themselves in a disastrous plight because of a combination of dreadful policies from the present Labor Government, a downturn in commodity prices and, in some respects, because of poor seasons.

para.tab: That combination of factors, which as I said is, in part, the direct responsibility of this Labor Government, has seen many rural people left in a parlous situation. The Democrats have been running around feigning sympathy for these people and saying that Democrat policies will be of support to them. Yet tonight—and in fact earlier than that—we heard the Democrats, on the other hand, advocating a massive increase in fuel tax. They advocate an additional tax of 16c or so a litre. So the Democrats are telling people out in the electorate one thing and they come into this chamber, where they think people are not listening—as the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) acknowledges too—and say something completely different.

Of course, in the advocacy of this policy, they fail to recognise that Australia is a country of extremely long distances. Australia is a very large country with a relatively small population, separated by long distances. It is a country in which transport makes up a much higher proportion of the costs of goods in general than is the case in most other countries. That is because, in part, we have an excessive amount of taxation on the road transport industry, including fuel tax. Yet, as we have seen tonight, the Democrats are advocating an additional tax of 16c a litre, which would be an absolute disaster for people living in rural and isolated parts of Australia.

If the Democrats were to come to the electorate of Grey in the far north of South Australia and tell people that that is their policy, all the feigning in the world with regard to their sympathy for the disastrous situation in which rural people find themselves would be to no avail. They will have no support whatsoever. They would not be welcome in most of the other larger States with this sort of policy. I think it is incumbent on our side of politics—and it is even incumbent on the Government side of politics—to make the community at large aware of this ridiculous approach to taxation, and to road transport in particular, advocated by the Democrats. As I have said, if they come to Grey—which covers some 87 per cent of South Australia—and spout that nonsense we need have no fear of their winning any votes in that electorate because it is particularly dependent on road transport.

These comments have been made in the context of the debate this evening on the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill 1992, which the Opposition will not oppose. It seeks to provide a number of minor amendments to the Road Transport Commission Bill that was passed about a year ago. The major purpose of this legislation is to insert as a schedule to the Act an agreement which was reached earlier this year between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and a number of State Premiers. That agreement, signed by all States and Territories except Western Australia and Tasmania, arose from the urgent need to establish uniform standards for heavy vehicles to replace the differing rules that had existed in the various jurisdictions throughout Australia. This action has been long overdue.

The coalition strongly opposed the initial National Road Transport Commission legislation which was passed at about this time last year, because we believed that legislation did not give the newly established Road Transport Commission sufficiently wide reference powers to consider the existing taxes that road transport pays. We believe that, under this legislation, some of those reservations which we previously had have been in part, although not completely, addressed. Again, of course, the prevalence of those existing taxes on road transport simply brings into focus the idiocy of the Australian Democrats in proposing that yet another 16.5c a litre be added to the already heavy taxes that exist on fuel.

The coalition believes that the National Road Transport Commission will now have the power to help assess the performance of the road system and the efficiency and effectiveness of road authorities. That is certainly a long way down the track that we are advocating from the initial steps that were taken last year when the Government established this new Commission.

It is also my understanding that groups such as the Australian Automobile Association have urged all governments to include light vehicles in the Commission's brief. They support our view that it is wellnigh impossible to determine a sensible road charging and funding regime without their inclusion. The Australian Automobile Association also agrees that roadworthiness checks cost more than they are worth and, with its experience, particularly in regard to private passenger motor vehicles, it ought to know.

It is unfortunate that this Government has overburdened road users with a plethora of road use requirements and administrivia, which, according to the experts on general road use, do not significantly reflect a very wise use of taxpayer funding. Although I understand that the amendment in this legislation proposes to insert the May agreement into the Road Transport Commission Act 1991, and although the agreement provides the framework for uniform minimum standards in respect of light vehicles, it does not impose such standards.

The functions of the National Road Transport Commission are not to be extended to road charges or economic regulation of the entire industry. It is clear that the Government did not want to lose its influence over the exorbitant taxation which it continues to levy on motorists and the road transport industry, so it is really not overly serious about coming to grips with an ideal charging system. It is unfortunate that, at a time of deep recession when we need to reform our cost structures, the present Labor Government will not act to slash the cost of road transport as the Liberal and National parties will do when we come into government through the initiatives in our Fightback proposals.

Under a Hewson coalition government, there will be no new road user charges beyond those that are in the process of being implemented. As a result, a typical road transport operator will save nearly $44,000 per year under a coalition government compared with the cost of operating under the present government. That is largely due to our commitment to completely abolish fuel excise. That will save road transport users 26c a litre. That is an enormous saving when one considers the quantity of fuel which is used by major transport operators. By comparison, the Government is proposing road user charges of $4,000 for a typical truck, plus the continuation of those massive fuel charges of 26c a litre.

The key areas of this Bill concern the establishment of a national uniform legislation for light vehicles, that is, 4 1/2 tonnes and under, and for other road users, but it does not include road charges or any economic regulation of the transport industry. On the issue of light vehicle regulation, the Bill leaves open the opportunity for the National Road Transport Commission to have the power to decide Australian design rules and the frequency of safety and roadworthiness checks. The amending legislation also concerns an expansion of National Road Transport Commission powers, but the Commission remains hamstrung by this Govern-ment's not including any recommendations on road funding in this amending Bill.

Presently the functions of the Commission are concerned with obtaining uniformity in road transport, yet that applies only to heavy vehicles, that is, those vehicles of more than 4 1/2 tonnes. These functions relate to uniform legislation, road charges and road user charges, principles for determining road charges and road use charges, and guidelines for the preparation of regulatory impact statements. The additional functions conferred on the Commission by the May agreement between the Prime Minister and various State premiers include the extension of the Commission's functions to light vehicles, the assembly and publication of information on the road related charges applying to light vehicles, and the monitoring of the use of alternative fuels.

Although the coalition still has strong objections to the manner in which the Government handled the setting up of the National Road Transport Commission, basically the Commission will now at least be collecting information and statistics on differing charging regimes. This is certainly something that is long overdue. It is a shame that this present Government did not have the fortitude to go all the way and benefit the entire industry as a Hewson-led Liberal-National Party government will, in fact, do. The coalition will certainly not tax to death the road transport industry and, unlike the present Government, it will significantly cut costs with regard to the road transport industry, which even the Prime Minister has admitted has for long paid 3 1/2 times more tax than other industries. The Government's own Inter-State Commission recommended a reduction in the tax burden but, again, the present Government failed to implement that.

In addition to ensuring that the costs of road transport are substantially reduced, a Hewson government will maintain existing levels of road funding provided from Consolidated Revenue. So there are a number of initiatives which the coalition will take which will improve the operation of road transport in this country. We will reduce significantly the cost of road transport. We will maintain road funding to ensure that there is adequate provision of roads and we will certainly overcome a decade of neglect under this present Government. They are initiatives which Australia desperately needs because, as I said at the outset, road transport in particular makes up a major cost of production in Australia, a major share of the cost of goods, and, if we are going to be internationally competitive, we certainly need to reduce those costs. Although, as I said, we support this legislation, we do so with those caveats and reservations on the lack of initiative on the part of the present Government, which will be addressed by the next government elected, a coalition government.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleagues on the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill. I wish to talk about a number of aspects of the Bill from a Western Australian perspective, Western Australia being my home State. In terms of area, it is the largest State in Australia. It also has the greatest task in terms of transport, particularly when it comes to the grain industry, the wool industry and the mining industry. Transport, whether by road or its competitor, rail, is of enormous significance to Western Australia.

para.tab: Much of what I wish to say tonight has already been said by my colleagues, but some of it bears repeating. As I have already mentioned, the major problem with our transport industry in Western Australia, and our road transport industry in particular, is excessive taxing. The principal taxes are payroll tax, fuel excise and wholesale sales tax. Under this Government, these charges have increased consistently, particularly fuel excise and wholesale sales tax. Whether it be carting minerals, stock, grain or anything else that is required, we find that those industries are significantly disadvantaged.

We saw some of the most ludicrous things being done with stock carting in the amendments to the Sales Tax Act. If a stock crate was fastened to either a truck or a trailer that was being towed, it was exempt from sales tax. But if that stock crate was not part of the truck or trailer, sales tax is paid. It is really incomprehensible that a government could have such anomalies in charging a tax; namely, the wholesale sales tax.

The coalition, when in government, will adopt a very different position. We will remove that anomaly by virtue of the fact that wholesale sales tax will go completely. In addition, fuel excise will go completely, as will payroll tax. I recently discussed the matter of transport with three companies which operate in the road transport area in Western Australia. Their payroll tax bill was in excess of $500,000, which gives us some idea of the impact this tax has on them.

I will now refer to the taxing of this industry. I am personally involved in grain growing and producing wool and meat for market, whether it be cattle or mutton. Under the coalition policy the saving will be in the order of $1.20 to $1.30 per tonne. When that is added up, there are many thousands of dollars of savings for a typical Western Australian farm. One of the most important things about our ability to compete—some of our ability to compete was blown out of the water today by the irresponsible national strike, which was led by the ACTU—is to keep our costs down so that, when we sell our product internationally, we have an opportunity to maximise our penetration of various markets.

Under the coalition's plan, which is to change the taxing arrangements which apply to our road transport industry, there will be a direct flow-off to the rail system in Western Australia: payroll tax, fuel excise and wholesale sales tax will go. In addition to that, setting grain freights in Western Australia is done by what is known as a grain freights contract. That is established because Westrail in Western Australian is in a monopoly position in many of the transport areas. It is a fact that there is competition between the two as a defacto result of this contract.

The impact of the Liberal and National parties' transport policies and the removal of these taxes will flow through directly into the rail system. It will also create a reduction in costs of $1.20 to $1.40 per tonne. That will flow directly back to the producers of the various products which are carted on Westrail, giving them the same advantages. While this Bill is about the National Road Transport Commission, it has a much broader impact and effect than on just the transport industry.
In the remaining few minutes I have to address this Bill, I would like to comment on what Senator Coulter, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, said tonight about increasing fuel excise by 16.5c per litre. If that were put into place—if the Democrats could ever possibly attain power in this country, and heaven forbid that particular occurrence—it would mean that fuel excise, the direct tax by the Federal government, would increase to in excess of 40c per litre. That would put much of Western Australia right out of business. It would certainly mean that our iron ore industry could not compete with Brazil and countries such as that. It would certainly mean that our grain industry, in particular, and our livestock industry, in addition, would almost cease to exist, if that sort of cost burden were put on them.

talk.start.para: —I agree with you.
—I notice that Senator Sherry is not sitting in his right seat. He usually interjects from the wrong place; there is nothing unusual about what he is doing.
—Stop agreeing with him.
—If he would speak up a bit I might be able to hear him.
—You just told me not to.

—It is the first time I have known Senator Sherry agree with me in this place. It is a welcome change. This cost burden would put those industries right out of business. The typical cost of carrying a beast in the cattle industry in Western Australia is $35 to $40 a head. Imposing the types of charges that Senator Coulter has suggested tonight would certainly increase that by 10 to 15 per cent and maybe even more. The same would apply when carting wethers to market for the live sheep trade or mutton or lambs to the abattoirs for slaughter. A number of businesses would be put out of business.

para.tab: It is interesting that this should come up tonight, because last week I just happened to hear former Senator Jenkins on a radio talkback program in Western Australia.

talk.start.para: —It would have been an enlightening exercise!

—It was an enlightening exercise. I was fortunate enough to be able to intervene on the same program. I heard former Senator Jenkins claiming that it was the Democrats who were forcing the Government to address some of these issues and to examine expenditure in a full and proper manner. I thought I should make reference to that because, talking about examining expenditure in this place, I point out that it was the Democrats who combined with the Government last week to apply the guillotine and create a situation where, in the Committee of the Whole, there was not a proper examination of DEET; there was little examination of the Department of Industrial Relations; and there was no examination of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Of course, in this Bill tonight we are talking mainly about the impact of transport costs which fall very heavily on the primary industries.

para.tab: While we support this Bill, the challenge for the Government is to adopt the position of the Liberal and National parties, particularly in view of the disastrous current account figures we have seen today.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —In the second half of last century an Australian poet by the name of Barcroft Boake wrote a poem commencing with the lines:

speech.para: Out of the wastes of the Never Never—
That's where the dead men lie!
That's where the heat-waves dance forever—
That's where the dead men lie!

He was, of course, referring to the tyranny of distance which then, as now, was one of the greatest challenges faced by Australians seeking to explore and expand into the inland portions of our continent. In the time that has elapsed, that problem has changed very little. It is the enormous difficulty of transporting produce from the areas of regional Australia where it is produced and the cost and the difficulty of bringing consumer items out to regional Australia which are the major impediments to the further development of regional Australia and the further improvement of the opportunities of people who live in those areas.

para.tab: The National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill, addressing, as it does, the issues of national road regulations and national road user charges, is a perfect opportunity to discuss those very important issues and the impact that they have on the lives of the people who live outside our capital cities. As I have said before in this chamber—and it is no news to honourable senators on this side of the chamber—80 per cent of this nation's merchandised export earnings are produced by the one in six Australians who live outside the capital cities.

If we are to get regional development, if we are to expand industry outside those few cities that scatter the eastern shores of this country, it is absolutely critical that we are able to make genuine improvements in the cost of transport. The cost of transport is a major problem for industries wishing to start up in regional Australia because it means that every single item, every single business input, that gets transported there is hit with the cost of road transport. The more the cost of road transport increases, the more difficult it becomes to generate new industries outside the cities.

For these reasons, those of us on this side of the chamber in the National and Liberal parties are firmly committed to the abolition of fuel tax. That means a reduction in the operating costs for road transport users of some 26.2c a litre on every single litre of fuel that they use, diesel or petrol. It means an end to the burden of enormous transport costs on developing industries in regional Australia. It means a start to the end of the enormous differences that currently exist between those who live within the cities and those who do not. This is some 2 1/2 years after the first report of the Inter-State Commission came out, the so-called Butcher committee, which recommended massive increases in road user charges. The Government was initially quite willing to support that recommendation.

It was the National Party, my colleague Senator Boswell and I, who first took up the issue of the Inter-State Commission's report and who first went around regional Australia and said, `Look what will happen to industry in regional Australia if this report is allowed to be put into place'. That is why we were committed then, and we are committed now, to reducing road transport charges throughout this country. I am very pleased to see that the Government recognised the sense of what we were saying and recognised—to the credit of some of the people who sit on the other side of the chamber—that if we are to even out the inequalities that currently exist between people who live in different parts of this country we have to reduce the cost of road transport.

I ask honourable senators: why is it that in this country industry is concentrated in a few centres whereas in other countries—for example, the United States—industry exists in small towns from one end of the country to the other? The reason for that disparity, of course, is the enormous cost of road transport in Australia which penalises industries that wish to set up outside the major capital cities. Therefore, what we must do, if we are to achieve the full potential of this nation, is to reduce the cost of road transport. That is why we in the National Party are particularly pleased to see that the Fightback package picked up our initiative of the abolition of fuel tax and, on top of that, the abolition of the 20 per cent wholesale sales tax which is currently on the transport industry.

I recognise the entry into the chamber of my Senate leader, Senator Ron Boswell, who, as I said, was so instrumental in getting the commitment of the coalition to keep road user charges down. It is particularly important because that is a commitment that we will take to the electorate in this election campaign—that after the election there will be no increase in road user charges for heavy vehicles. That is a commitment that those who sit opposite us in this chamber cannot make and have refused to make time and time again. It is not that they have not been challenged to; it is that they cannot make that commitment because they do not have the necessary commitment to developing regional Australia.

So what we are saying on this side is that we offer an alternative to the continued decline of regional Australia; we offer an alternative to the decline of primary industry which has been massively hit by enormous road user charges—and that is an alternative which will reduce the cost of transport and make feasible again processing and value-adding industries in regional Australia. Most importantly, it is a policy that recognises that a road that goes from the coast to somewhere in inland Queensland does not exist just for the benefit of the people in inland Queensland on one end of it, but that it is of benefit to all Queenslanders, especially when it is used to get our important exports to the coast where they can be shipped overseas to turn around this nation's balance of payments problem. That is why we have a commitment to fund the road system out of the Consolidated Revenue.

I ask honourable senators, and I ask those who may be listening to this telecast, to compare that approach with the approach that is offered by the Government. What is the approach offered by the Government? It is an approach that says, `We are ripping something like $6,500m a year out of road users in this country through the fuel tax, and we are returning about one-quarter of that amount of money to the roads system'.

talk.start.para: —What would the Democrats do?

—As Senator Panizza quite rightly interjects, what would the Democrats do? The Democrats, of course, would add 16.5c a litre to the cost of fuel used by every single motorist in this country. Yet they come in here and say, `People in regional Australia will not be affected because we are going to have, perhaps, some special consideration for people who are farmers'. They have not made a commitment, but they have said, `We will look into it'. Of course, what they will not do is anything to reduce the transport costs of those farmers and the people who live in regional Australia.
—We could go back to the horse and cart.
—We could go back to the horse and cart, and I think there would probably be some people who sit amongst the Democrats who would find that an attractive proposition.

para.tab: But what we propose on this side of the chamber is an era of development, an opportunity to take the industries out of the cities and back into regional Australia, to take the jobs and the opportunities back into regional Australia. At a time when this Government's failed economic policies have delivered to regional Australia enormously high levels of unemployment—levels that approach 20 per cent, for example, in the seat of Richmond in northern New South Wales—how can this Parliament refuse to do something about the abolition of fuel tax and the reduction of wholesale sales tax on the transport industry? How can we, as senators who represent our States, face our constituents with clear consciences when we go into regional Australia if we allow policies to continue that penalise the people who live outside the capital cities? That is why those of us in the coalition are absolutely committed to ending fuel tax and ending what is, in fact, a tax on people who live outside our major cities.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —I am sorry that Senator O'Chee has gone to all the trouble of having a haircut in the mistaken belief that tonight's debate is being televised. I regret to inform him that it is not; we are only on the radio as usual.
—Good thing for you, very good for you.

—What a brilliant riposte from Chicken Little. I was about to say that, consistent with the actions of a number of speakers who actually dropped off the speakers list tonight—which would have been very good advice for Senator O'Chee to have taken—I will not waste the time of the Senate by responding to the over the top, rhetorical flourishes of Senator O'Chee, which were overdone as usual. Regrettably, he is no better today than he was the first day he walked into this Senate.
—Still twice as good as you could ever be and you will not even acknowledge the interjection because you know it is true.
—Senator O'Chee is a five-year-old.
—That is five years better than you.

—This is brilliant stuff. This Bill is, in fact, a straightforward piece of legislation. Tempted by the prospect of actually getting out of here before midnight tonight—which is a very tantalising prospect these days in the Senate—I do not intend to reiterate the Government's position which has already been put in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, except to make two fundamental points.

para.tab: The first point is that the coalition in a statement issued by its shadow Minister, the honourable member for Wannon, on Thursday 29 October, made it very clear indeed that the road user charges it is talking about agreeing to will in fact apply only in the first term of a coalition government, leaving wide open the question as to what happens after that. The reason why that is a matter of concern for those who have some interest in the broad philosophical approach of the coalition is the full cost recovery as enunciated in the Fightback document.

talk.start.para: —It will be introduced after the first Hewson government. You get that right.

—I wonder precisely what that means. But we cannot conduct this debate by interjection. It is highly disorderly and I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President. Recently we have seen just how conveniently and quickly the coalition changes its policies, which is why it is a relevant issue.
—What?

—In response to the startled interjections opposite, I will tell the Senate. In the Fightback document, the coalition commits itself to full cost recovery of the safety regulatory charges as they impose on the general aviation industry. Just recently I drew attention to that matter in Question Time.

para.tab: The coalition has been pursued for some time by the peak bodies which represent the light aircraft industry and the general aviation industry. It took the coalition a very considerable time—about six months—to realise that more than 90 per cent of the fuel excise which is collected on avgas is remitted immediately to the Civil Aviation Authority in direct payment for the services it provides to the general aviation industry. Of course, the coalition was blissfully unaware of that. Having been pursued by the light aircraft peak bodies, the coalition has recently replied to them and told them, in direct contradiction of the policy statement in the Fightback document, that it will be funding the safety regulatory costs to the light aircraft industry from general revenue.

This is an indication as to how the National Party tail can certainly wag the dog when it is convenient, because it raises the question of just how flexible and changeable this Fightback policy document is. That immediately opens up yet another hole—albeit a small one compared with the holes in the coalition's defence policy, for example; but a hole nevertheless—of $23m in the Fightback document in respect of the removal of fuel excise from the aviation industry. It is a matter of some concern to me when I see that these commitments are limited in terms of their effect.
The other curious point is that, in a speech to the NTF conference in September this year, Dr Hewson said:

speech.para: To the extent that we do introduce a road user charge, we will free up that money—
that is the money collected by the road user charge—
and have that money available for further cuts in taxation in other areas.

I find that curious because, one month later when the coalition finally enunciated its policy on road user charges with an attachment that set the maximum charges per vehicle, the honourable member for Wannon clarified the charges that the coalition would introduce. He said, `A six-axle articulated truck will pay $4,000 a year in registration. That is all'. Interestingly, less than a month before, the Leader of the Opposition made it clear that the road user charges, which were then being finally considered by the coalition and announced by the honourable member for Wannon, `will free up that money and have that money available for further cuts in taxation in other areas'.

talk.start.para: —That is right.

—I would certainly like some clarification. The road user charge of $4,000 that was just announced is a registration fee charged by the State jurisdiction. I am interested to solicit further details from the Opposition—because some clarification will have to be given on this—on whether a Federal Liberal government intends then to collect those State registration charges which are collected as State revenues. If the State revenues are collected by a Federal Liberal government then, interestingly, to make up the difference the States will no doubt increase their own fuel franchise fees—or, as they call them in the Northern Territory, business franchise fees, to pretend that they do not actually charge a local excise on fuel. That is a matter of detail which the Opposition will now have to clarify.

para.tab: It is a fact, as speakers have alluded to during this debate, that this is a straightforward piece of legislation which is widely supported by all of the industry groups that are involved in the road transport industry. I thank the Opposition members who spoke in the debate for their support of the legislation and I commend it to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
