debate.title:
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1992
SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
SALES TAX IMPOSITION (IN SITU POOLS) BILL 1992

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by
Senator Tate
:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating cognately Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992, Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and Sales Tax Imposition (In Situ Pools) Bill 1992. The first Bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992, will bring significant changes to and introduce the concept of offshore banking regulations. There will be changes to the capital gains tax regime, particularly to the notorious terrible twins M6 and M7, and there will be changes to the penalties for late payment of tax and changes to the disability support pension, bereavement payments and changes to the textile clothing and footwear special allowance.

para.tab: The new term is `offshore banking'. This refers broadly to the intermediation by a resident institution of financial transactions between non-residents and non-resident lenders. An offshore banking unit or an OBU, as it is more commonly referred to, is the unit within the bank that manages these transactions. Under existing Australian law, an OBU may also borrow from residents in foreign countries but its lending is restricted to non-residents and other OBUs—and this is the significant feature of an OBU transaction. We might recall that in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement earlier this year the Government announced its intention to tax income derived by offshore banking units from borrowing and lending to non-residents at the concessional company income tax rate of only 10 per cent.

Further, it was decided after extensive consultation with the banking and finance industry to extend the scope of these activities, the income of which would attract the concessional rate. When this Bill was first released, it caused a number of submissions from the industry pointing out the anomalies and inadequacies especially with a number of stated objectives. The Government believes that this Bill will promote the development of a viable offshore banking centre in Australia at a time when activities are likely to be shifted from Hong Kong to elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region as well as helping to integrate Australia more closely with the Asia-Pacific growth economies by becoming the expanded financial centre of the region. The Opposition supports this.

I am happy to say that the Government has listened in part to a number of the submissions given to it on this Bill and has introduced and circulated further amendments during the debate in the lower House as well as in the Senate only recently. I am also pleased that the Government consulted with several sections of the industry. The Australian Taxation Office and the banking industry met on several occasions to discuss the proposed overseas banking unit legislation.

However, it has been brought to my attention that in order for an OBU to operate in the most efficient manner a number of small issues still need attention. In order to manage foreign currency trading positions, it is vital that the overseas banking units be allowed to deal with a domestic banking unit or DBU at market rates. The industry has informed me that without this ability to deal between the OBU and the domestic banking unit it is unlikely that the banking industry will be inclined to place significant amounts of business within the OBU. For example, the domestic banking unit would be allowed to trade US dollars and Japanese yen with the overseas banking unit. For this purpose, the bank's treasury division must be considered separate from the overseas banking unit and allowed to trade with the overseas banking unit.

A potential for tax avoidance could arise; however I believe that the case for separation is substantial. The explanatory memorandum clearly states that an OBU is to be treated as if it is a separate bank. Further, section 121C of the legislation allows internal deals between the overseas banking unit and a foreign branch of the same bank. Therefore, to allow the OBU to deal with the domestic banking unit would merely be an extension of the principle to allow for internal deals between the overseas banking unit and the Australian branch of the same bank.

The coalition intends to move an amendment at the committee stage. We apologise that the initial amendment that was issued related to the second printing and since that time a third printing has been presented to the other chamber. The Opposition will be pursuing only the first amendment, to enable this offset to be made. Without the amendment, the overseas banking unit would not be in a position to offset a currency exposure on a transaction with a non-resident with a hedge taken locally to offset that risk. It is, therefore, an incentive to transact that business in Australia. The Tax Office could be at an auditing disadvantage, particularly if that sort of business were conducted in Singapore, because the secrecy provisions in the banking legislation preclude the passing on of information in respect of a transaction in and out of Singapore.

Ultimately, the Australian bank must hedge its position back to Australian dollars. A bank could suffer currency risks where it is unable to efficiently manage because of differing tax rules for the OBU versus the domestic banking unit. Therefore, the final Australian dollar hedge will have to be undertaken within the main bank where the OBU has the underlying currency exposure and the main bank has the matching hedge. Each has an exposed position. The logical solution is to permit the overseas banking unit to enter into a hedge with the main bank, the result of the hedge being to close out the exposed position of each of the OBUs and the main bank and to return them both to a fully hedged position. Profit shifting or avoidance schemes will not result. I think this is the fear that the Tax Office had.

The explanatory memorandum states that the level of penalties associated with the new self-assessment provision will apply where profit shifting has occurred between classes of income with different taxing rights. Under this regime, the maximum penalty will be 90 per cent—quite a deterrent. If the level of penalty is reached, the penalty may include the loss of licence to operate as an OBU. So the loss of an OBU involves the whole of the branch, not just a particular segment.

The OBU must deal at market rates with its foreign associate companies, foreign branches and, if permitted, the domestic banking unit. If deals between the overseas banking unit and the domestic banking unit are done at off-market rates to shift profits, the penalty that I referred to can be applied where an OBU deals with a foreign branch or a foreign associate at off-market rates. So it is no easier for the overseas banking unit to deal at off-market rates with a domestic bank than it would be for an offshore branch or a subsidiary. Therefore, the Tax Office will be able to audit more easily the deals between the overseas banking units and the domestic banking units than deals in which a counter party is located offshore, because the Tax Office merely has to walk into the local office and examine all the records per se.

It has also been brought to my attention that, although the Government has had extensive consultations with the banking industry, one other part of the general business community has been ignored. In particular, I refer to the submissions that the Government and the Opposition have received from the Life Insurance Federation of Australia. Unfortunately, no answer or acknowledgment has been given by this Government to its submissions. I think that is discourteous, to say the least.

The life insurance industry believes that this Bill should have allowed life companies and other relevant funds and management institutions to have some access to the proposed new overseas banking units arrangements on the same basis as banks and foreign exchange dealers. This approach would ensure neutral treatment of different financial institutions and consistency with the Government's objective of promoting Australia as an expanded financial centre for the Asia-Pacific region.

The rationale for the LIFA approach is based on the following reasons. Firstly, life companies and fund managers generally provide a full range of financial services to non-residents with a particular emphasis on funds management, which is their core business activity. Secondly, the discriminatory application of the proposed tax concession between different institutions will immediately place life offices and other relevant institutions at a competitive disadvantage in the provision of international financial services.

Thirdly, in the medium term there could be an adverse impact on the competitiveness of life companies in the domestic funds management market. Fourthly, the proposed legislation will encourage the excluded institution to continue to provide international financial services for offshore centres to the detriment of the Australian revenue. Fifthly, a more even-handed approach in this area would enable life companies to compete effectively with both domestic and foreign banks while achieving the Government's objectives of establishing a viable regional financial services sector in Australia.

I think it has been submitted that the discriminatory application of the proposed tax concessions between life companies and other relevant institutions is a competitive disadvantage in the provision of financial services to non-residents. This will clearly lead to distortions in the financial sector in Australia. I look forward to hearing, in the name of giving all who submit submissions a fair hearing, the Parliamentary Secretary's response to the issues that I have raised in terms of the request made by the life insurance industry.

The second major issue which is covered by this Bill is the new capital gains tax provisions contained in amendments to those two sections of the Income Tax Act known as the terrible twins, sections 160M(6) and (7). These two sections have been described as unworkable, difficult if not impossible to understand, and unduly complicated, by many tax experts including various High Court judges. It was as a result of the Hepples case decision that the Government was forced to redesign the provisions of sections 160M(6) and M(7). I have raised the difficulties associated with these two sections several times in this chamber and I urge any interested readers or listeners to this debate to pursue this issue because I do not believe the Government has yet got it right.

The changes before us today can be described as perhaps the most important capital gains tax changes since part IIIA, the capital gains provisions, was introduced. The changes are meant to clarify these two sections, 160M(6) and (7), after the High Court could not agree in the noted Hepples case decision that applied particularly in the area of restrictive covenant payments. The amendments will provide that where a person creates a right in another person, the capital gains provisions can now apply to tax any consideration the person receives for creating that right. For example, the amendments make it clear that a payment received by a person for entering into a restrictive covenant, exclusive trade tie or similar agreement, will now be taxable under the capital gains provisions.

I note that the explanatory memorandum says that a draft of the amendments has been discussed with the tax representatives of the various legal and accounting professions with a view to ensuring that the desired clarity is achieved. I am not sure with whom the discussions were held, but two noted experts in taxation—I am referring to the Tax Institute of Australia and Mr Geoffrey Lehmann, who writes in a weekly column in the
Business Australian
—have raised several problems with the new amendments. I refer the Government to page 21 of the
Australian
of Friday, 27 November for a fuller discussion of the problems as perceived by Geoffrey Lehmann. He states:

speech.para: If this legislation is passed, get yourself a visa to Singapore.

I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate Mr Lehmann's article in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The article read as follows
—

speech.para: The Phantom of the Australian Taxation Office

para.tab: In June, the Government introduced capital gains tax amendments which are still before Parliament. There has been a surprising silence about their true implications. The explanatory memorandum circulated by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, said the amendments "are not expected to have any significant impact on revenue".
In fact, if they are conscientiously applied by the Australian Taxation Office they could apply to a myriad of transactions in a harsh and unpredictable manner.

The reason for this extraordinary situation is that the amendments create phantom capital gains. They have a legitimate objective. In past years, a favourite tax ploy was for employees to receive a large lump sum from their employer for an agreement or restrictive covenant not to compete. Such payments are not taxable as ordinary income as they are capital.
CGT legislation was announced on September 19, 1985, and introduced in May 1986. It applied to disposals of assets acquired after September 19, 1985.

Those responsible for the original legislation appear to have been greedy. They wanted to catch payments on restrictive covenants from the date of the announcement, although this had not been adequately foreshadowed. So they devised two provisions, sub-sections 160M(6) and (7), which became known as the terrible twins.

These purported to tax fictional disposals of assets transferred on their creation. The legislative words were fuzzy and mysterious, but they conformed with the verbal formula of the Treasurer's 1985 announcement which referred to disposals of assets. Meanwhile, the explanatory memorandum for the legislation explained what it all meant and listed several transactions, such as restrictive covenants, which were taxed by the terrible twins.
If there was a plan to introduce retrospective taxation by stealth, it blew up. In fact, it blew up twice.

There were protests about the retrospective aspect and the obscurity of the legislation. So, after initial intransigence, the law was changed to tax gains on asset creations only from when the legislation was introduced. Then, in the past 12 months, the High Court could not agree which of the terrible twins taxed restrictive covenants. So an employee, Mr Hepples, escaped tax-free. In the meantime, other smart employees jumped into the gap and got tax-free amounts under restrictive covenants.

Amended 160M(6) and (7), introduced in June, amply cover the gap. Unfortunately, the amendments apply to many innocent transactions also. The ATO tried to perfect the fuzzy language of former 160M(6), instead of simply listing the transactions which it wanted to tax.

I shall try to make the explanation which follows as untechnical as possible. New sub-section 160M(6) is to apply where there is a creation of an asset by one person that vests the asset in another person.

A capital gain will be attributed to the first person equal to the value of the "consideration" he or she receives. If there is no consideration and the parties are at arm's length, another provision, which might otherwise operate, will not attribute to the first person a capital gain equal to the value of the created asset. "Consideration" is a term of contract law. When I pay a dollar for an ice cream, the dollar and the ice cream are the mutual consideration flowing between the vendor and me. Consideration can be money, property or a promise.

However, under CGT law, consideration has a slightly narrower meaning and includes only money or property. Promises that are not property are not consideration for CGT purposes. The explanatory memorandum for 160M(6) correctly claims that it does not apply to an employment contract where John Jones contracts with Brown Manufacturing to be manager of Brown's sales division for two years solely on a commission basis.

The explanatory memorandum states: "John receives no inducement or other payment for entering into the contract . . . John has created an asset (viz, the rights of Brown under the contract to require John to perform his duties as sales manager . . . ) which, on its creation vests in Brown. John is taken to acquire, own and then dispose of the asset to Brown. However, as John receives no consideration in respect of the disposal . . . he will not have a capital gain . . . as a result of creating the asset.

The explanatory memorandum does not give a full explanation. John does receive consideration for contract law purposes—Brown's promise that John will be sales manager for two years. But this is not property, as it is non-assignable, so it is not "consideration" for CGT purposes and there is no capital gain.

New 160M(6) is a minefield. The explanatory memorandum indicates that a payment for withdrawing an objection to a town planning application could be assessable. What if I withdraw an objection, because the developer promises to build a retaining wall so my land is not undermined? Proposed 160M(6) possibly assesses me on the value of the wall even though my real benefit may be nil.

It will also apply to companies which transfer tax losses within the company group. These are clearly assets under an amended definition, and group companies are not at arm's length, so a gain equal to the market value of the loss will be attributed. This defeats the purpose of the group loss legislation.

Technology licensors may be taxed, when they grant a licence, on a gain equal to the value of the future income stream. A legislative provision that is supposed to prevent double taxation may not operate here, as it only applies when the future income "has" or "will" be received as a "result" of the disposal, which in this case is the technology licence.
If the future income is merely a possibility, and dependent on future manufacturing activities, it is not clear whether double taxation is prevented.
If this legislation is passed, get yourself a visa to Singapore.

para.emphasis: Geoffrey Lehmann is a partner of Price Waterhouse

speech.para: I will summarise what Mr Lehmann says. Amendments 160M(6) and M(7) do adequately cover the tax free amounts obtained under restrictive covenants. Unfortunately, they also apply to many innocent transactions. The Tax Office has attempted to perfect the fuzzy language of the former 160M(6) instead of simply listing the transactions which it wants to tax and, consequently, has created a minefield of unintended consequences. The article also states:
New sub-section 160M(6) is to apply where there is a creation of an asset by one person that vests the asset in another person.

para.tab: A capital gain will be attributed to the first person equal to the value of the "consideration" he or she receives.

debate.title:
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1992
SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
SALES TAX IMPOSITION (IN SITU POOLS) BILL 1992

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —Mr Lehmann continues:

speech.para: If there is no consideration and the parties are at arm's length, another provision, which might otherwise operate, will not attribute to the first person a capital gain equal to the value of the created asset.

The explanations in the explanatory memorandum and the Bill surrounding this concept of consideration I believe are fuzzy, with the consequence that, on examination of the examples given, more questions are really raised than answered. Geoffrey Lehmann notes:

The explanatory memorandum indicates that a payment for withdrawing an objection to a town planning application could be assessable. What if I withdraw an objection, because the developer promises to build a retaining wall so my land is not undermined?
This is another problem. He continues:
Proposed 160M(6) possibly assesses me on the value of the wall even though my real benefit may be nil.

para.tab: It will also apply to companies which transfer tax losses within the company group. These are clearly assets under an amended definition, and group companies are not at arm's length, so a gain equal to the market value of the loss will be attributed. This defeats the purpose of the group loss legislation.

Technology licensors may be taxed, when they grant a licence, on a gain equal to the value of the future income stream. A legislative provision that is supposed to prevent double taxation may not operate here, as it only applies when the future income "has" or "will" be received as a "result" of the disposal, which in this case is the technology licence.
If the future income is merely a possibility, and dependent on future manufacturing activities, it is not clear whether double taxation is prevented.

speech.para: The Tax Institute also takes up the theme as to whether or not double taxation is prevented in relation to the disposal of an asset where the disposal gives rise to rights which in themselves are assets for the purposes of part IIIA. The most common example is in the case where a taxpayer has received compensation in relation to the loss or destruction of assets otherwise subject to capital gains liability. The concern is that the legislation is asset specific, not transactions specific.

para.tab: With regard to the amended definition of an asset, the Tax Institute further notes that the extension of the amendments to encompass non-proprietary rights is unwarranted and adds a considerable degree of uncertainty to the law. So I urge the Government to examine carefully the comments from both these sources of taxation expertise because I believe it is inappropriate to leave the taxpayer in a state of uncertainty, especially in a climate of self-assessment where the taxpayer is required to determine his own tax liability.
Before I leave this Bill, I would like to raise one final point. The Bill has significant retrospective operation. It states:

speech.para: 29(1)Subject to this section, the amendment made by this Division (other than paragraph 23(g)) apply to the construction or creation of assets after 25 June, 1992."
I also have to raise my objection to this retrospectivity, but the coalition generally welcomes other changes to the Bill.

para.tab: I am also concerned that it gives rise to the prospect of double taxation, not necessarily between 160M(6) and 160M(7) but between either of those provisions and other sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is because of these sorts of problems that I believe the redrafting of these two sections should perhaps have been referred to an expert such as the Government referred to in the case of the foreign investment funds legislation when it called in Professor Arnold, a noted law expert from overseas.

We have come across the scenario of passing legislation that was not right once before. We are now passing legislation that a number of experts—including the Taxation Institute of Australia—have had severe reservations about. While the Opposition will not be calling for an amendment or referring these sections to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs because of the timing, I believe that it is incumbent on the Government, given the warnings that have been issued tonight by both people in this chamber and other professionals, to have these two sections very closely looked at by an independent expert before this Bill receives royal assent. To do less than that is quite unfair. In view of comments by the judiciary in the past about these provisions, we have to be especially careful.
The Senate also has before it a number of sales tax Bills. Because of the impact of the guillotine, I will not be able to address those issues, and I regret that.

talk.start.para: —There is no guillotine. That is dishonest.
—In response to the issue raised by Senator Kernot, no speaker can talk for more than 20 minutes, so that is the guillotine.

speech.speaker: Kernot Sen C.

talk.start.para: —In response to Senator Watson's last comment, there may be a 20-minute speaking limit, but as many senators who wish to speak can speak; there is no guillotine.

para.tab: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and the Sales Tax Imposition (In Situ Pools) Bill 1992 being debated this evening fall into two categories. On the one hand, we have a series of technical changes to the new sales tax law and the reimposition of the tax on the concrete shell of swimming pools, which was ruled invalid earlier this year by the High Court. On the other hand, we have the various income tax changes contained in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992.
The major sales tax initiative in this package is the reintroduction of a 20 per cent sales tax on the concrete shell of pools and spas

speech.para: constructed in situ. This is a fair tax proposal, because prefabricated pools and spas are already taxed at 20 per cent. There is a distinct competitive advantage currently applying to in-ground pools which are constructed on site. Since these are often more expensive than the prefabricated ones, this exemption is probably regressive in its distributional impact. Consequently, we assume that removing the exemption will be progressive in its impact.

para.tab: This question was dealt with by Parliament in 1986. The measure was passed to impose a tax from that time, but the High Court ruled in the Mutual Pools case in February this year that the original tax had been improperly passed. Consequently, the tax, which had been improperly collected, had to be refunded. This was an extraordinary situation. Special legislation was required to ensure that the person who bore the tax—either the pool builder, the pool purchaser or both jointly—actually received the refund. I do not want to revisit that debate; I simply want to put this legislation in context.

The High Court ruled that the tax was unconstitutional on a technicality. The result of that decision is particularly unjust, as taxpayers will have to refund about $40m, which could have been used for other purposes. However, there is little dispute that the decision is correct. Phil Cleary knows what it is like to be caught on a constitutional technicality. It simply shows that, although the Australian Constitution has generally served this country well, there are many areas in need of reform and modernisation. The States grants legislation will give me an opportunity to elaborate on that issue.

The High Court decided that, although this Parliament has the power to tax the shells of swimming pools, the Constitution requires that there must be a separate imposition Act. The Government is proposing to meet that condition with this legislation this evening. The Australian Democrats support the proposal.

A number of other minor sales tax amendments are proposed. Two relate to amendments which I previously moved: the first for smaller oil companies, such as Caltex and Ampol, which are not able to take advantage of the deemed manufacturer provisions; and the second to overcome an anomaly in the sales tax treatment of certain kinds of microchips known as EPROM. These amendments improve the drafting of my original amendments without disturbing their operation or intent.

The other matters relate to technical amendments concerning credits. The most noteworthy of these is the proposal to remove the anomaly whereby wheelchairs and spectacles are exempt from sales tax yet parts used to repair these items are taxable.

The legislation will make these parts free of sales tax as well. I congratulate the Government on this decision. It is not one of these great Democrat bower bird ideas, is it? I wonder whether it was not also politically inspired by the leak of the draft document from the Cole committee which canvassed imposing a GST on these and other items. Whatever the reason, we welcome it.

Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992 contains a range of income tax measures. A massive reduction in interest rates has meant that the statutory rate of penalty for the late payment of tax and other related penalties, which stands at 20 per cent, is deemed to be too high. This rate is reduced to 16 per cent from 1 October. The 16 per cent rate is high enough to discourage the non-payment of tax but also recognises that the 20 per cent rate is punitive, given current interest rate levels. We also have some technical amendments to the Bill to ensure that when recipients of a disability support pension or other similar benefits reach the age pension age, they will be taxable but will be eligible to receive a pensioner rebate.

The so-called terrible twins of the capital gains tax, sections 160M(6) and (7), are completely rewritten to overcome what is to many an incredible decision of the High Court—another one—in the Hepples case. The capital gains tax is structured so as to tax assets when they are disposed of. Such a disposal test necessarily contemplates a prior acquisition of the asset. The difference in value between the acquisition and disposal, suitably discounted for inflation during the holding period, is then subject to tax.

The terrible twins were introduced to cover respectively the situations where, firstly, an asset is created by the act of its disposal, and hence cannot be caught by the general provisions—examples are where a person creates an asset by granting a lease or an option—and, secondly, where certain capital payments are received which would not otherwise be taxed. This applies where an act or transaction takes place in relation to an asset or an event affecting an asset.

The explanatory memorandum to the original Bill clearly stated the intention that restrictive covenants would be caught, although the Hepples decision means that the provisions have to be amended. The incredible thing about the Hepples case—I think it is unique in Australian tax law history—was that a majority of the High Court judges thought that the amounts in question were properly taxable but they could not agree unanimously on why the amounts were taxable and under which provisions. It sounds like a case of deja vu. Hence, no tax was paid. I will not force the Senate to endure a technical explanation of the new provisions; I merely hope that the new legislation is successful in reaching its target.

The major matter in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is an initiative from the One Nation statement. This is to provide a concessional income tax regime for offshore banking in Australia. This measure, unlike another one in the news at the moment—the matter of tax deductibility of personal superannuation—has not come out of the blue. Mr Keating looked at it in 1986 when the interest withholding tax was abolished for offshore banking transactions. He rejected it at that time. It has been on the agenda of the banks ever since.

The actual measures before us are very different from those announced in February. Senator Watson has already explained these in some detail, so I will spare the Senate any repetition. But I do think it is important to get on the record that the original proposals were to be revenue positive to the tune of $5m per year, yet through consultation the range of transactions covered by the concession has been expanded and this Bill is now estimated to cost $30m per annum.

The proposals relate to offshore banking units or OBUs. I will give honourable senators a piece of historical trivia. In times gone by, it would have been inconceivable that the conservative parties would be supporting legislation introduced by a Labor government to provide a tax preferred status to an OBU. As many honourable senators might be aware, especially those from New South Wales Labor, OBU was a huge issue in the early decades of this century. It referred to the proposal to create one big union which would unite all the workers of the nation and eventually the world. They would then overthrow the evil capitalists and everybody would live happily ever after.

That OBU was not successful and, unfortunately, the financial OBUs with which this legislation deals have not been successful either. The reason that the Australian OBUs have not been successful is that they are not competing on a level international playing field. Our main regional competitors in this field are Hong Kong and Singapore. Singapore has had a concessional income tax regime for many industries, including financial services, for many years, and they are a shining example of government guidance of successful economic development policies. Hong Kong has always been a low tax jurisdiction. So to compete in the industry we have to have a competitive tax system. Clearly, this Bill will achieve this. The States have also played their part, with the New South Wales Government abolishing some stamp duties and the Victorian Government announcing its intention to do the same.

In approaching this legislation, the Democrats have had to balance what we see as the disastrous consequences of financial deregulation generally—and speculation—and our opposition to those decisions, with the need to legitimise government intervention in the pursuit of industry policy objectives. Clearly, this proposal is an exercise in strategic trade theory.

The Bill deliberately introduces a distortion which is designed to attract financial transactions to Australia which would not otherwise occur here. The reason is to generate employment in the provision of financial services—something Australians are very good at—and to build Australia, most probably Sydney, into an international financial centre. The rapidly approaching reversion of Hong Kong to the People's Republic of China creates a great opportunity to poach business and investment, irrespective of the stated intentions of the Chinese Government.

It seems to me that the Liberal Party always condemns government intervention. It is opposed to such distortions on principle because it says, I think it could be argued, that there is no role for government in industry policy.

Senator Watson interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Not according to Senator Watson's free market policy. I welcome Senator Watson's support, but it is a little hypocritical of him to support such a favourable regime for financial services.

para.tab: Australia is still racked by recession. Today's balance of payments figures are an unmitigated disaster and the outlook for the world economy is looking bleaker than at any time for years. So any policy which attempts to create local activity and employment deserves the support of this Senate. But we need to match the other tax concessions, or to provide some equivalent incentives, to make Australia competitive in the other industries where we want Australia to develop. With that in mind, I move the following second reading amendment:

At end of motion, add ", but the Senate calls on the Government to take a more interventionist approach to taxation policy, and industry policy in general, so as to create sustainable jobs and engender a recovery in Australia.".

speech.para: I look forward to future legislation in this vein from the Government, particularly in the area of renewable energy. I say to Senator McMullan that, if it is good enough for the banks, it is good enough for other strategically important industries.

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen R.F.

talk.start.para: —Tonight senators speaking on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992 and previous Bills have been brief. I will seek to emulate their brevity so that we do not have to sit too late, but there are a number of matters I need to deal with in summing up the second reading of this Bill. Firstly, I should thank all speakers and the Senate for supporting this legislation.

para.tab: There are some important but agreed parts of this legislation that have not been significantly referred to; for example, the amendments to the treatment of disability support pensions, the special needs support pensions, bereavement payments and the textile, clothing and footwear special allowance, which I think are changes which are welcomed and should be noted once again for the record, as with the proposals to reduce the rate of penalties for late payments and related penalties from 20 per cent to 16 per cent.

With regard to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), it is clear that the principal changes relate to the CGT amendments and offshore banking units, and I will come back to each of those. In the course of so doing, I make it clear now that the Government will be moving an amendment, which has been circulated, to the offshore banking units section of the legislation when we get to the committee stage, but first I will deal with the provisions of the legislation.

The Sales Tax Imposition (In Situ Pools) Bill 1992, which is being discussed in conjunction with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), is fundamentally about reimposing the 20 per cent tax on pools constructed in situ. Senator Kernot outlined the history and the rationale. Fundamentally, she did so accurately, and I have nothing to add. It also makes some other changes. I note with amusement her adoption of my bowerbird analogy, and I hope that I never need to use it again. I welcome the support for the Bills, and at this stage there is no need to go further with them. I hope that they get a speedy passage.

There are, however, some important issues with regard to the capital gains tax section and the offshore banking unit section. I will refer to the capital gains tax section first. It falls into two parts, and I will come back to Mr Lehmann's concerns in a moment. In general, there is some concern that in the course of clarifying the meaning of subsections 160M(6) and 160M(7) we have not made some of the policy changes people would like to have seen made. We had no intention of so doing. It was in no way the intention of these changes; they are intended not to change policy but to clarify the operation of the section as it was always intended to operate prior to the decision of the High Court.

The object of the original subsections 160M(6) and (7) was to assess capital payments not received as a result of the disposal of an asset. That is really what drives our difference with Mr Lehmann's article. He is sometimes a little iconoclastic, but I understand the problems with people having to write interesting newspaper articles about matters that are arcane and, for most, dry as dust.

talk.start.para: —So how do we speak on them every night?

—Yes, and even worse, people have to listen. One can hear radios clicking off all around the country at the mention of one of the three of us getting up to speak; people go out for a cup of tea, I think. There is a little journalistic licence in the article, but I understand the thrust of what Mr Lehmann was trying to put.

para.tab: I want to make three points in response. Firstly, it was not intended that the sorts of capital payments that the section was to deal with should be restricted to those mentioned in the original explanatory memorandum. They were examples. The present amendments are designed to clarify the means by which such payments will be assessed. It is a restatement of the general principle in a way that is intended to be, and I think is, clearer. But it is not appropriate—and certainly the Government was not, and is not, attracted to the proposition—that we should move to adopt a list system; that is, we list the payments that are to be covered. The concern would be that that might constitute an invitation to design transactions that are not covered by the list.

The problem with purporting to list all that which is covered is that it therefore means that, if something can be developed that does not fit that description, by definition, it is not covered, although the principle may be the same. If we look at the broad question of the way in which the modernisation of the tax Act will develop, as a general approach it is better to go to the principles, rather than to try to cover all the possible examples in the legislation.

With regard to the offshore banking units, there has been a lot of discussion in the public and in the Parliament in response to One Nation and, in the nine months subsequently, about the provision. I will not reiterate all that. I strongly support the proposal. I have strongly supported the proposal for six years. Senator Kernot may have touched upon a subliminal reason, some sort of hankering for the international workers of the world to remerge, but I doubt it very much. It is a proposal that I supported when Neville Wran, Nick Whitlam and others were trying to get the proposal up in the early 1980s, without success, and I am pleased that it has succeeded now.

With all such proposals, which I strongly support, there is a question of balance. It does not just mean that, because we wish to see an internationally competitive tax regime in Australia for offshore banking, every change that might be beneficial to offshore banking ought to be done; a balance needs to be struck. The industry has strongly argued that viability of an Australian offshore banking regime depends on Australia's ability to compete on an even footing with other countries in our region that already provide a broad range of concessions. That is broadly true. The Government shares that view, but it is also concerned to balance that by ensuring that Australia's domestic revenue base is protected; that is, we do not go to changes which endanger the revenue beyond that which is necessary to encourage offshore banking. It is a difficult balance to strike. We are moving into a new area and we need to proceed very cautiously and in a very considered way.

That essentially underpins the Government's concern about the Opposition's amendment. If I speak on it now, it will save time in the committee stage, when I can be brief. The Government does not accept the proposed amendment. It thinks that there is an unacceptable level of risk that income can be shifted from the 39 per cent tax category to the 10 per cent tax category and, similarly, that losses could be created and applied against the 39 per cent tax category. If this form of internal dealing were allowed, it would be impossible for the Tax Office auditors to check whether transactions were properly booked.

The Reserve Bank has given advice that this sort of internal dealing is not necessary in order to enable a bank to effectively manage its currency risk. It has also advised that it would be impracticable to try to monitor whether such transactions were done at market value because normal trade volumes, which are very significant, would make such transactions very difficult to identify. Experienced Tax Office auditors have confirmed that advice. To save some time in the committee stage—although I am sure that I will be able to say some of that again—I just put that on the record now. Senator Watson will still, of course, proceed with his amendment, but that is why the Government is not supporting it.

I will say something very briefly about the second reading amendment, without taking much time. It seemed to me at first reaction to be a very strange time to be moving it. Apart from the fact that it is a strange time to be moving it at 11 o'clock at night, I rather meant that it is a strange time in the evolution of Australian tax policy. We have before us an example of the approach to which Senator Kernot is referring. In her speech in support of the amendment, she did say, `If you have made this small step, why not take a giant leap?'. That is why the second reading amendment flows from the offshore banking provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4).

The problem is that there is no necessary correlation between being more interventionist and achieving economic improvement. I have said many times in this Senate—and I repeat now—that I am a long way from being one of the Senate's purists about the interrelationship between tax and industry policy. As with matters of environmental and social policy, when the cost benefit is right I am prepared to look at using the tax system for those other purposes. I have made it clear, and One Nation makes it clear, that the Government is prepared to look at those sorts of initiatives. It has done so with regard to a number of matters flowing from One Nation, most of which have passed this Senate, and once we conclude tonight the offshore banking will have done the same.

The problem in Australia is that too often we look at the tax system as the first and easiest way to achieve those objectives because, firstly, there is a fascination with tax exemption and, secondly, it is often seen as costless. We make this incentive and there is no government outlay, but there is a cost to revenue. The difficulty is that it is often a cost to revenue that cannot be accurately predicted, as with the assistance to the film industry. So there are cases for being interventionist—whether one would say more or less is a value judgment—and there are cases when the Government should use the tax system or other measures to achieve its economic, environmental and social objectives. I do not think it is a question of saying that it should have general or blanket application. We should make a cost benefit and decide.
Each time we do it we add complexity; each time we do it we add compliance costs; and each time we do it we run the risk of unforeseen consequences and revenue costs which we cannot necessarily predict.

We do not accept the second reading amendment. I think the Government should continue to strike a balance on a rational cost benefit basis about when and if we should use tax policy. I will not refer to whether we should be using industry policy. It is hardly what we should do under a second reading amendment about the tax laws. Whether we should use taxation policy more or less will depend on the circumstances as they arise from time to time. We should continue to give practical application to the cost benefit principles that ought to be applied to deciding whether we will amend the tax policy on any particular occasion. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Liberal-National Party coalition, I move the following revised amendment dated 30 November 1992, relating to overseas banking units:

"(e) trading in currency or options or rights in respect of currency with any person, including the OBU owner, a person related to the OBU owner, or with the domestic banking unit within the same company as the OBU, where the currency is not Australian currency; or''.

That affects proposed paragraph 121B(4). I also seek the leave of the Committee to incorporate in
Hansard
the reasons for the amendments that we have proposed, given that these items are of a fairly technical nature. Rather than reading and explaining at length the reasons for these amendments, I seek leave to incorporate them in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

speech.para:
The document read as follows
—
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (NO.4) 1992
Reasons for amendments proposed by Senator Watson for the Opposition
Amendment No. 1
In order to manage foreign currency trading positions, it is vital that the overseas banking unit (OBU) be allowed to deal with the domestic bank (DBU) at market rates.

For example, the domestic banking unit should be allowed to trade US Dollars/Japanese Yen with the overseas banking unit. The Bank's treasury division (DBU) for this purpose must be considered separate from the OBU and allowed to trade with the OBU.
The ATO position is that a potential for tax avoidance could arise. However, the case for separation is quite substantial:

para.tab: 1.The explanatory memorandum clearly states that an OBU be treated as if it is a separate bank.

2.The legislation allows internal deals between the OBU and a foreign branch of the same bank (see Section 121C). It is merely an extension of this principle to allow for internal deals between the OBU and the Australian Branch of the same bank (ie the DBU).

3.Without the amendment as suggested the OBU would not be in a position to offset a currency exposure on a transaction with a non-resident with a hedge taken locally to offset the risk. It is therefore an incentive to transact that business in Australia, and further the ATO could be at an auditing disadvantage, especially in Singapore, and where the secrecy provision in the banking legislation precludes the passing of the information in respect of transactions in and out of Singapore.

4.The bank must ultimately hedge its position back into Australian dollars. A bank could suffer currency risks which it is unable to efficiently manage because of the differing tax rules for the OBU/DBU. Therefore, the final Australian dollar hedge will have to be undertaken within the main bank where the OBU has the underlying currency exposure and the main bank has the matching hedge, it can be seen that each has an exposed position.

The logical solution to this is to permit the OBU to enter into a hedge with the main bank, the result of the hedge being to close out the exposed position of each of the OBU and the main bank and return them both to a fully hedged position.

speech.para: Anti-avoidance

The explanatory memorandum states that the level of penalties associated with the new self assessment provisions will apply where profit shifting has occurred between classes of income with different taxing rights. Under this regime the maximum penalty will be 90%. Where this level of penalty is reached, the penalty may include the loss of license to operate an OBU.

The abovementioned proposed amendments will not allow for profit shifting or avoidance schemes. The OBU must deal at market rates with its foreign associated companies and foreign branches and, if permitted the DBU. If deals between the OBU and DBU are done at off market rates to shift profits then the abovementioned penalty provisions can be applied where an OBU deals with a foreign branch or foreign associate at off market rates. It is no easier for the OBU to deal at off market rates with the DBU than it would be with an offshore branch or subsidiary. Furthermore, the ATO will be able to more easily audit deals between the OBU and the DBU than deals where a counterparty is located offshore

talk.start.para: —I am disappointed that the Government does not intend to support these amendments, because without them the domestic banks will be unable to reach their full potential in terms of the advantages that should have been available through the creation of overseas banking units. The domestic banking units will now be quite reluctant to deal in currencies where there is any significant risk whatsoever. Ultimately, the bank must hedge its position back into Australian dollars. Without the amendment, the bank could suffer currency risks which it is unable to manage efficiently because of the differing tax rules for the overseas banking units vis-a-vis the domestic banking units. Therefore, the final Australian dollar hedge will have to be undertaken within the bank's main treasury where the overseas banking unit has the underlying currency exposure.

para.tab: The logical proposition, and this is implied in the explanatory memorandum, is that the DBU can deal with the OBU. From the point of view of anti-avoidance, the explanatory memorandum states that the level of penalties associated with the new provisions are quite severe. The maximum penalty is 90 per cent or even the loss of licence. The proposed amendments in the Bill will not allow for profit shifting or avoidance and the OBU must deal at market rates with its foreign associated companies.

We pointed out that it is much easier to check those transactions even though they will be technical and voluminous. But there will be very little to check if the Singapore banking legislation forbids the exchange of such information. We believe that such transactions would be more expeditiously carried out here in Australia where the Taxation Office can check the transactions. True, there might be a lot of them, but I venture to say that the transaction would be recorded when the transaction initially takes place and any subsequent creative accounting would be picked up. The penalties for such creative accounting would be very severe. I regret that the Government has taken this, what I call over-cautious approach.

While I am on my feet I will also refer to the problems of 160M(6) and (7). I did not indicate in my contribution to the second reading debate that I hope that before this Bill receives royal assent the Government will refer these revised provisions to an expert, such as Professor Arnold, in view of the comments from the Tax Institute and Geoffrey Lehmann's article. We have had criticism enough of this Parliament enacting legislation that does not stand up in court. As this is our second attempt at this legislation, and given the fact that there has been severe criticism of it, I believe it is not unreasonable for us to ask for an independent review before this matter receives royal assent.

For example, we could have requested that a committee look at it, but we throw it back into the Government's own court. These significant issues have been raised. We believe it is incumbent on the Government—it has been given due warning—to get it right. In view of the provisions of 160M(7) particularly, I call on the Government to issue rulings and determinations immediately to clarify this catch-all provision. I point out that subsections 160M(6) and (7) are the catch-all provisions relating to assessability in the capital gains area. Therefore, it is necessary for these rulings and determinations to be issued.

I must compliment the Taxation Office on issuing a plethora of such rulings in recent times. Not everybody agrees with them, but at least it puts some certainty into the law which I think is necessary in a self-assessment environment. When we sought changes to the capital gains provisions before the Government sought to redraft the legislation, we were not seeking policy changes at all; we merely wished to clarify the outstanding issues.

There are still some problems with the legislation and some of these are unintended. For example, under the legislation, it is possible that a wedding gift could be given by an admirer to the bride but, rather than cash, it could be something which would add to the value of their house—say, a verandah. Technically, under these sorts of provisions, that situation could arise.

There are still difficulties with what is known as part disposals and the lack of capital base. The principal problem that arises in this area relates to easements. That issue needs to be examined, particularly from the point of view of a tax ruling or a determination. Without a legislative base, we still have an unsatisfactory situation.

I will refer briefly to the reasons why we did not support the Democrats' second reading amendment about a more interventionist approach to taxation policy. Again, we disagree with both the Government and the Democrats. We believe that so many of the problems within the Income Tax Assessment Act—its volume, complexity and its difficulties—have arisen through using the taxation legislation as a vehicle for so many desirable causes of the time. This applies not only to social policy but also to industry policy. Quite often, specific legislation is a much better vehicle for handling such problems. On behalf of the Opposition, I say that we regret that neither the Government nor the Democrats will be supporting our amendment.

talk.start.para: —I took the opportunity of putting the Government's position on the amendment in the second reading debate, so I will not repeat that. I will use this opportunity to respond to some of the points Senator Watson made about capital gains tax. I suspect it was his way of getting around the 20-minute limit on speeches in the second reading debate. He made some second reading type comments in relation to the CGT in the committee stage. That is perfectly valid; we are dealing with the Bill as a whole and those clauses are before us.

para.tab: The hardest thing in introducing and explaining new clauses, particularly in complex areas—in this instance tax law, but also in other areas of the law—is to persuade people what will not happen. One can never prove what will not happen and people of imagination are always capable of finding horrors that might flow if certain interpretations were to be taken. In response to that, on the basis of the advice the Government has received, it thinks most of the worst fears that people have about what might happen under 160M(6) and 160M(7) will not eventuate.

On the more specific level, on consultation, rulings and determinations, I am advised that a meeting of the capital gains tax subcommittee of the taxation liaison group will be held on Wednesday. A number of issues have been raised and will be discussed. At the moment, I think that is the appropriate forum for that consultation to continue. I expect that, flowing from that conversation and consultation, rulings and determinations will start to flow relatively quickly thereafter, without putting a specific date on it. I understand the concerns people have about that and I would hope that that would be the case. For the reasons outlined in the second reading debate, we will not be supporting the amendment.

talk.start.para: —I indicate to Senator Watson that it is my understanding that the Opposition's amendment possibly creates a loophole for domestic banks, that there are possible huge revenue consequences. I wonder whether Senator Watson could tell us what sort of financial impact this amendment would have. We are not far removed from the Westpac letters and the foreign exchange accounts and the consequences surrounding them. I agree with the Government that it really is better to err on the side of caution until we have had more time to think about this matter and to examine the revenue implications. I have had a copy of this amendment for only one hour—it is like what Senator Watson said about the RSPCA amendments—and I do not think I have had sufficient time to give it due consideration.
—Senator Watson, I have before me one amendment on the front page and then some reasons on the next page. Is there one amendment only?
—There is one amendment. I sought leave to incorporate the reasons for the amendment and leave was granted.
—That is all right. During the committee discussions the term `amendments' has been used occasionally. That is the reason for my confusion.

—To respond to Senator Kernot, I did indicate that the lack of acceptance of this amendment would mean that the domestic banking units would not be able to reach their full potential because of the potential exposure to risk. Ultimately, the domestic banking units must hedge basically back to Australian dollars. It is much easier for that to occur domestically rather than elsewhere around the world.

para.tab: I think that artificially changing the transactions to create a profit shifting on artificial tax loss is not on. The Australian banks have a good record of not being in the practice of tax avoidance. The penalties in this area of profit shifting from the 10 per cent for losses artificially to the 39 per cent regime are very high—90 per cent—and can ultimately lead to the loss of the licence itself, which no bank would be prepared to forgo.

While the intention of creating an overseas banking unit philosophy and enshrining it in legislation is to create a level playing field to enable Australian institutions to share in these sorts of transactions, the bringing to Australia from Hong Kong and Singapore of this sort of business will be thwarted as a result of this legislation not being accepted. It is true that they will be able to engage in items without risk.

All these things do involve an element of risk. Senator Kernot indicated how much this would actually cost. I would foresee that the additional business and the revenue derived from it would ultimately offset that loss. Banks, of course, do not enter transactions in the knowledge initially of losing money. Any subsequent bookkeeping entries that might transfer at that loss-profit shifting exercise is simply not on, because of the punitive provisions that are there for so-called profit shifting. The banks would be very remiss if they started to engage in this sort of activity and would be wide open in an audit. If any of these sorts of issues are to be raised, I believe it is a lot easier for the transactions to be carried out in Australia rather than overseas.

Finally, there are two matters to which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) has failed to respond. Firstly, there is the issue of the concerns that were raised by the Tax Institute and put by Geoffrey Lehmann in last Friday's
Business Australian
about 106M(6) and (7), the terrible twins, and the suggestion of an examination by an independent person before the Bill receives royal assent. Secondly, the Parliamentary Secretary did not respond to the issue of the opening up of the OBU facility to the life insurance industry. Would it be possible for the Parliamentary Secretary to respond, as I think at the time of this debate Mr Dawkins had not yet responded to the industry?

talk.start.para: —My remarks with regard to the tax liaison group examination of 160M(6) and (7) were intended to be a response to Senator Watson's point about reference to an independent expert. In other words, to be more explicit, we do not intend to send it to an outside expert for a Professor Arnold-type consultation—if I can use that shorthand which I think everybody who is involved in this debate will understand. We intend to give the legislation royal assent as it stands, but we certainly intend to talk and consult with people about it and about the rulings and determinations which need to flow to assist people in, firstly, calming some of their fears, which I think it will do, and, secondly, advising them of how it might work.

para.tab: It is not the current intention of the Government to extend OBU provisions to insurance companies. I have been involved in some discussions, as has the Treasurer. If subsequently a case can be established as evidence emerges, that might be a matter that can be re-examined on some future occasion, but it is not the Government's current intention to extend OBUs to insurance companies.
Amendment negatived.

I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to be moved to this Bill and seek leave to incorporate my explanatory comments with regard to the amendments.

para.tab: Leave granted.

speech.para: Mr. President, on behalf of the Government I move the amendments being circulated.
To protect the revenue, the proposed OBU concessional tax regime contains certain interest deeming provisions which relate to the use of borrowed funds to buy shares in a subsidiary.

Their purpose is to prevent tax benefits arising where an Australian parent company gets tax deductions with a tax effect of 39% when it borrows funds and then uses the funds to capitalise a subsidiary, thereby enabling it to derive income taxable at 10% by carrying on offshore banking activities.

If an OBU subsidiary engages in both domestic activities and offshore banking activities, however, the deeming provision could have an unintended consequence of resulting in a stream of interest being imputed on the funds used in the domestic part of the business.

These amendments will ensure that deemed interest income can arise only where paid up capital provided by an Australian parent company is used by the subsidiary in the performance of offshore banking activities.
Mr. President, I would make the general comment that the Government's decision to introduce a concessional offshore banking regime in Australia has been applauded by the banking and finance industry.

These amendments are another example of the Government's willingness to swiftly respond to legitimate industry concerns which are brought to its notice so that we can all get on with the job of establishing Australia as a viable offshore banking centre.
The amendments will not have any financial impact.
I commend the amendments to the Senate.

proctext.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 27 August 1992:

para.tab: (1) Has the `Black Spots' road program been evaluated yet and the evaluation published; if not, when will an evaluation be completed and published.
(2) If the evaluation has not been completed, what evidence supports the Minister's claim on 18 August 1992 that the program is `highly cost effective'.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) and (2) The effectiveness of black spot treatments is widely accepted and documented in Australia and overseas. The program provides clear benefits both in terms of road safety and employment opportunities.
The program requires nominated projects not only to have an established history of fatal and serious crashes, but also a benefit cost ratio of at least 2:1.

The Australian Road Research Board has provided advice of cost effective traffic engineering treatments which have either high or medium potential. These are used as a guide by States and Territories in framing programs. The majority of the projects have had "high" potential, with average benefit cost ratios in the order of 4:1.

A comprehensive evaluation of the program by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics (BTCE) has commenced and will continue into 1993. In the interim, the BTCE has undertaken to provide a preliminary indication of effectiveness for a sample of black spot treatment sites in Victoria and New South Wales. This analysis should be completed early in 1993.
Because at least one year's post treatment data is required for rigorous analysis, only projects which were completed before July 1991 are being considered in the Victorian and NSW sample.
The level of serious road trauma in Australia over the past four years has fallen by about 30 per cent. The economic savings alone would be as high as $1800 million a year.

asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 12 October 1992:

para.tab: (1) By what amount has the Family Law Court Budget been reduced in the current Budget.
(2) Has there been any reduction in the amount of money available to the Chief Justice for the administration of the Family Court and, in particular, its circuits; if so, please give details.
(3) What is the cost of the administration of the Family Support Agency and what are the details of this cost.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) I assume that the honourable senator's reference to the Family Law Court is a reference to the Family Court of Australia.

In the 1992-93 Budget it was provided that total outlays would be reduced from $71.065m in 1991-92 to an estimated outlay of $69.822m in 1992-93—an amount of $1.243m. Salaries and administrative expenses for the Court would be reduced from $48.547m in 1991-92 to $45.062m in 1992-93.
The principal reasons for a reduction in salaries and administrative expenses in 1992-93 are—
(i) the Family Court borrowed from 1992-93 allocations for expenditure incurred in 1991-92. The amount involved is $1.185m;
(ii) the Efficiency Dividend applies to the Court's running costs appropriation as it does to other similar budget-funded Departments and agencies; and

(iii) the Court's running costs were adjusted because the Commonwealth Government Final Consumption Expenditure deflator (CGFCE) applicable to budget-funded agencies generally had been estimated at 4.6% when preparing the 1991-92 Budget, but was in fact only 2.1%.

A review of the present workload and activity levels of the Family Court of Australia has been recently completed. As a result of that review it is proposed that the appropriation for the Family Court of Australia for 1992-93 will be increased, in accordance with the Running Costs rules, by $3.207m—being $2.022m for present workload and activity levels and waiver of the requirement to repay the amount of $1.185m borrowed by the Court in 1991-92.
